- Alternative keyboards and input devices
- Eye tracking systems
- Refresh
audits.why_it_matters:
Different disabilities require different assistive technologies:
- Low vision users need magnification and high contrast
- Motor impairments require voice control, switches, or alternative inputs
- Learning disabilities benefit from text-to-speech
- Deafblind users need braille display support

An application may work well with screen readers but fail with other
assistive technologies. Comprehensive AT compatibility ensures the
widest possible user access.

audits.name: ARIA Role Attribute Correctness
audits.description:
This audit examines ARIA role attributes to verify they are used
correctly according to the WAI-ARIA specification. The audit checks:

- Only valid ARIA roles are used
- Roles are applied to appropriate element types
- Abstract roles are not used directly
- Role changes are not made on focusable elements dynamically
- Required context roles are present (e.g., listitem in list)
- Required owned elements exist (e.g., menu owns menuitems)
- Presentational roles don't hide interactive content

Roles
audits.why_it_matters:
ARIA roles communicate element purpose to assistive technologies.
Incorrect role usage can:
- Misrepresent element purpose entirely
- Break expected keyboard interaction patterns
- Cause screen readers to misinterpret page structure
- Create accessibility barriers where none existed before
- Override correct native semantics with incorrect ones

Correct role usage enables complex UI patterns to be accessible,
but incorrect usage is worse than no ARIA at all.

audits.name: Screen Reader Compatibility Testing
audits.description:
This audit conducts comprehensive testing with multiple screen reader
technologies to verify application accessibility. Screen readers are
the primary assistive technology for blind and low-vision users.

Testing covers:
- NVDA (Windows, free) - most popular free screen reader
- JAWS (Windows, commercial) - industry standard, enterprise use
- VoiceOver (macOS/iOS) - native Apple screen reader
- TalkBack (Android) - native Android screen reader
- Narrator (Windows) - built-in Windows screen reade
audits.why_it_matters:
Screen reader testing is essential because:
- Automated tools catch only 30-40% of accessibility issues
- Different screen readers interpret markup differently
- Real user experience can only be verified through testing
- Browser and AT combinations have varying behaviors
- Dynamic content often fails silently in automated tests

Without screen reader testing, critical accessibility issues may
go undetected, creating barriers for blind users who depend on
these technologies for all computer inte

audits.name: Valid HTML Markup
audits.description:
This audit validates HTML markup to ensure it conforms to specification
and will be correctly interpreted by assistive technologies. Per WCAG
Success Criterion 4.1.1 (Parsing), content implemented using markup
languages must have elements with:

- Complete start and end tags (where required)
- Proper nesting according to specification
- No duplicate attributes
- Unique ID values within the document

The audit uses automated validation tools to check HTML output against
the HTML5 specification an
audits.why_it_matters:
Valid HTML ensures:
- Assistive technologies can reliably parse page structure
- Browser accessibility APIs receive correct information
- Screen readers can navigate and announce content correctly
- Keyboard navigation works as expected
- ARIA attributes function properly

Invalid HTML can cause:
- Screen readers to skip content or announce incorrectly
- Keyboard focus to become trapped or lost
- Accessibility tree to misrepresent page structure
- Different browsers to interpret markup inconsist

audits.name: Abbreviation Explanation Audit
audits.description:
This audit verifies abbreviations and acronyms are explained
per WCAG 2.1 SC 3.1.4 Abbreviations (Level AAA).

The audit covers:
- Technical acronyms (HTML, CSS, API)
- Industry-specific abbreviations
- Organization acronyms
- Shortened words (e.g., "approx.")
- Use of <abbr> element
- Glossary or definition availability
- First-use expansion patterns
- Screen reader pronunciation
audits.why_it_matters:
Unexplained abbreviations create barriers for:

- Users with cognitive disabilities
- Non-native language speakers
- Users unfamiliar with domain terminology
- Screen reader users (abbreviations may be mispronounced)
- New users to a field or industry

Even common abbreviations like "FAQ" or "ASAP" are not
universally understood.

audits.name: Consistent Identification Audit
audits.description:
This audit verifies components with the same functionality are
identified consistently per WCAG 2.1 SC 3.2.4 Consistent
Identification (Level AA).

The audit covers:
- Icon consistency (same icon = same function)
- Button label consistency
- Link text consistency
- Form input labels
- Error message patterns
- Action button naming
- Aria-labels and accessible names
- Visual indicator consistency
audits.why_it_matters:
Consistent identification helps users understand functionality:

- Same icon should mean same action everywhere
- Same button text should produce same result
- Users learn patterns and expect consistency
- Inconsistency creates confusion and errors
- Screen reader users rely on consistent labeling

When the same function is labeled differently in different
places, users cannot reliably predict what will happen.

audits.name: Consistent Navigation Audit
audits.description:
This audit verifies navigation mechanisms are consistent across
pages per WCAG 2.1 SC 3.2.3 Consistent Navigation (Level AA).

The audit covers:
- Primary navigation menu position and order
- Secondary/utility navigation consistency
- Footer navigation consistency
- Breadcrumb implementation
- Search functionality placement
- User account menu position
- Mobile navigation patterns
- Navigation within multi-step processes
audits.why_it_matters:
Consistent navigation is critical for user orientation:

- Users with cognitive disabilities rely on predictable layouts
- Blind users build mental models of site structure
- Motor-impaired users benefit from predictable link positions
- All users navigate more efficiently with consistency
- Inconsistency causes confusion and disorientation

When navigation moves or changes order between pages, users
must relearn the interface repeatedly.

audits.name: Error Suggestion Audit
audits.description:
This audit verifies error messages provide helpful suggestions
for correction per WCAG 2.1 SC 3.3.3 Error Suggestion (Level AA)
and SC 3.3.1 Error Identification (Level A).

The audit covers:
- Form validation error messages
- Input format suggestions
- Required field messaging
- Password requirement guidance
- Date/time format help
- Search and filter error states
- API/server error handling
- Inline vs. summary error display
audits.why_it_matters:
Unclear error messages frustrate all users but especially:

- Users with cognitive disabilities struggle to understand vague errors
- Users with learning disabilities need specific guidance
- Non-native speakers need clear language
- Screen reader users need errors associated with fields
- All users benefit from actionable suggestions

Error messages that only say "Invalid input" leave users
guessing what to fix.

audits.name: Language Identification Audit
audits.description:
This audit verifies language identification per WCAG 2.1:
- SC 3.1.1 Language of Page (Level A)
- SC 3.1.2 Language of Parts (Level AA)

The audit covers:
- HTML lang attribute on root element
- Valid BCP 47 language tags
- Language changes marked with lang attribute
- Multi-language content handling
- Language direction (dir attribute)
- Embedded content language
- Programmatic language identification
audits.why_it_matters:
Screen readers and other assistive technologies use language
identification to:

- Select correct pronunciation rules
- Apply appropriate text-to-speech voice
- Handle language-specific processing
- Support multi-language content

Without language identification:
- Screen readers mispronounce content
- Braille displays may show incorrect characters
- Translation tools cannot function properly
- Users cannot understand synthesized speech

audits.name: Reading Level Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates content readability per WCAG 2.1 SC 3.1.5
Reading Level (Level AAA), ensuring content is accessible to
users with varying reading abilities.

The audit covers:
- Text complexity and sentence structure
- Vocabulary and technical term usage
- Reading grade level analysis
- Availability of simplified versions
- Supplementary content (illustrations, summaries)
- Technical documentation readability
- Error messages and user guidance
- Legal and policy content accessibility
audits.why_it_matters:
Many users have difficulty with complex text:

- 21% of US adults read at basic or below basic level
- Cognitive disabilities affect text processing
- Non-native speakers struggle with complex language
- Dyslexia affects ~10% of the population
- Aging can affect reading comprehension

Clear, simple writing makes content accessible to the
widest possible audience.

audits.name: Component Identification Consistency
audits.description:
This audit examines user interface components that have the same
functionality to verify they are identified consistently across the
application. Per WCAG Success Criterion 3.2.4 (Consistent Identification),
components with the same functionality must have consistent:

- Text labels
- Icon usage
- Accessible names (aria-label, alt text)
- Visual appearance
- Behavior

The audit focuses on common patterns like:
- Search functions (search boxes, search buttons)
- Print/download/share functionality
audits.why_it_matters:
Consistent identification enables users to:
- Recognize familiar functionality without relearning
- Build reliable mental models of the interface
- Navigate efficiently using learned patterns
- Avoid confusion from inconsistent labeling

For users with cognitive disabilities, consistent identification is
essential for successful interface use. Screen reader users particularly
benefit from consistent accessible names, as they cannot see visual
similarities between components. Inconsistent identif

audits.name: Navigation Consistency Across Pages
audits.description:
This audit examines navigation mechanisms that appear across multiple pages
to verify they maintain consistent relative order and placement. Per WCAG
Success Criterion 3.2.3 (Consistent Navigation), navigational mechanisms
that are repeated on multiple pages must occur in the same relative order
each time, unless the user initiates a change.

The audit evaluates:
- Primary navigation menus
- Secondary/utility navigation
- Breadcrumb trails
- Footer navigation links
- Search functionality placeme
audits.why_it_matters:
Consistent navigation is critical for:
- Users who rely on spatial memory to locate navigation elements
- Screen reader users who learn the page structure once and expect it
  to remain stable
- Users with cognitive disabilities who may become confused by
  changing layouts
- Low-vision users using screen magnification who navigate to
  remembered locations

Inconsistent navigation forces users to relearn the interface on each
page, dramatically increasing cognitive load and reducing efficiency.

audits.name: On Focus Behavior Predictability
audits.description:
This audit examines user interface components to ensure that receiving
keyboard focus does not trigger unexpected changes in context. Per WCAG
Success Criterion 3.2.1 (On Focus), when any UI component receives focus,
it must not initiate a change of context such as:
- Automatic form submission
- Opening new windows or dialogs
- Navigation to different pages
- Significant content changes
- Focus moving to different components

The audit analyzes JavaScript event handlers, framework components, an
audits.why_it_matters:
Unexpected context changes on focus create significant barriers for:
- Keyboard-only users who navigate sequentially through interfaces
- Screen reader users who may lose their place in the page
- Users with cognitive disabilities who rely on predictable behavior
- Users with motor impairments who may accidentally trigger focus events

Unpredictable focus behavior can cause users to inadvertently submit forms,
navigate away from content they were reading, or lose their orientation in
the applica

audits.name: On Input Behavior Predictability
audits.description:
This audit examines form controls and input elements to ensure that
changing their settings does not automatically trigger unexpected context
changes. Per WCAG Success Criterion 3.2.2 (On Input), changing the setting
of any user interface component should not automatically cause a change
of context unless the user has been advised of the behavior beforehand.

Context changes include:
- Navigation to a different page
- Opening new windows
- Submitting forms automatically
- Significantly changing
audits.why_it_matters:
Unexpected context changes when interacting with form controls can:
- Prevent users from reviewing their selections before submission
- Cause accidental form submissions with incorrect data
- Disorient users who expect to complete forms before any action occurs
- Make interfaces unusable for screen reader users who may not realize
  their selection triggered navigation
- Create particular difficulties for users with motor impairments who
  may accidentally trigger selections

Users expect to hav

audits.name: Content Depth Analysis Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates content depth and comprehensiveness, examining
topical coverage, word count adequacy, multimedia usage, expert insights,
supporting evidence, and comparison with competing content. It assesses
whether content thoroughly addresses user intent and provides complete
answers to searcher questions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Search engines increasingly favor comprehensive, in-depth content that
fully satisfies user intent. Shallow content loses rankings to competitors
offering more complete coverage. Google's Helpful Content system rewards
content created to help users, not just to rank. Content depth is correlated
with higher rankings, longer time-on-page, lower bounce rates, and more
backlinks - all positive SEO signals.

audits.name: Content Duplication Audit
audits.description:
This audit identifies duplicate content issues including exact duplicates,
near-duplicate pages, internal duplicate content, and external content
scraping/plagiarism. It examines URL parameters causing duplicates,
www/non-www issues, HTTP/HTTPS variations, trailing slash inconsistencies,
and canonical tag implementation for duplicate management.
audits.why_it_matters:
Duplicate content confuses search engines about which version to index
and rank, diluting ranking signals across multiple URLs. This wastes
crawl budget, splits link equity, and can result in the wrong version
(or no version) appearing in search results. While not a direct penalty,
duplicate content significantly hinders SEO performance and can be
mistaken for content manipulation.

audits.name: Content Freshness Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates content freshness across the website, examining
publication dates, last modified indicators, update frequency, schema
markup for dates, and content staleness patterns. It assesses whether
content is being kept current, how freshness signals are communicated
to search engines, and identifies stale content requiring updates.
audits.why_it_matters:
Content freshness is a ranking factor for certain query types, particularly
those with "freshness demand" (news, trending topics, recurring events).
Google's "Freshness Update" algorithm favors recently updated content for
time-sensitive searches. Stale content can lose rankings to competitors,
provide outdated information to users, and signal neglect to search engines.
Regular updates signal an active, maintained website.

audits.name: Orphan Page Detection Audit
audits.description:
This audit identifies orphan pages - pages that exist on the site but
have no internal links pointing to them. It compares crawl data with
sitemap URLs, log file analysis, and analytics data to find pages that
are discoverable only via direct URL or external links, not through
normal site navigation.
audits.why_it_matters:
Orphan pages are difficult for search engines to discover and crawl
efficiently. Without internal links, these pages receive no link equity
from the rest of the site and are often deprioritized in Google's crawl
and index. Users cannot find orphan pages through navigation, meaning
valuable content may be effectively hidden. Orphan pages also indicate
poor information architecture.

audits.name: Thin Content Detection Audit
audits.description:
This audit identifies thin content pages - those with insufficient,
low-quality, or auto-generated content that provides little value to
users. It examines word counts, content-to-code ratios, boilerplate
percentages, and content quality signals to find pages that may trigger
Google's thin content filters or Helpful Content system penalties.
audits.why_it_matters:
Google's algorithms specifically target thin content as low-quality.
Sites with significant thin content can be demoted site-wide under
the Helpful Content system. Thin pages waste crawl budget, dilute site
quality signals, and provide poor user experience. They can prevent
otherwise good content from ranking well due to site-wide quality assessment.

audits.name: Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS) Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS) performance,
a Core Web Vital that measures visual stability. CLS quantifies
how much visible content shifts unexpectedly during the page
lifecycle. It evaluates current CLS scores, identifies layout
shift sources, analyzes shift causes, and provides stability
optimization recommendations.
audits.why_it_matters:
CLS is a Core Web Vital that directly impacts search rankings.
High CLS (over 0.25) creates frustrating experiences where users
may accidentally click wrong elements, lose reading position, or
find the page disorienting. Good CLS (under 0.1) provides a stable,
predictable visual experience.

audits.name: First Contentful Paint (FCP) Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines First Contentful Paint (FCP) performance,
which measures when the first text, image, or canvas is rendered
on screen. FCP is an important user-centric metric that indicates
when users first perceive the page is loading. It evaluates current
FCP scores, identifies render-blocking resources, and provides
optimization recommendations.
audits.why_it_matters:
FCP is the first signal to users that the page is loading. Fast
FCP (under 1.8 seconds) reassures users their request is being
processed. Slow FCP (over 3 seconds) creates uncertainty and
increases abandonment. FCP is a diagnostic metric that helps
understand the critical rendering path performance.

audits.name: First Input Delay (FID) Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines First Input Delay (FID) performance, a Core
Web Vital that measures interactivity. FID quantifies the delay
between a user's first interaction (click, tap, key press) and
the browser's response. Note: FID was replaced by Interaction to
Next Paint (INP) as the Core Web Vital for responsiveness in
March 2024, but FID remains relevant for historical analysis.
audits.why_it_matters:
FID measures how quickly a page responds to user interaction.
Long FID (over 300ms) frustrates users as the page feels
unresponsive or "frozen." This typically occurs when the main
thread is blocked by JavaScript execution. Good FID (under 100ms)
provides a smooth, responsive experience.

audits.name: Interaction to Next Paint (INP) Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines Interaction to Next Paint (INP) performance,
the Core Web Vital that replaced FID in March 2024 for measuring
responsiveness. INP measures the latency of all user interactions
throughout the page lifecycle, not just the first one. It evaluates
current INP scores, identifies slow interactions, analyzes causes
of input delay, and provides optimization recommendations.
audits.why_it_matters:
INP is a Core Web Vital that directly impacts search rankings.
Unlike FID which only measures the first interaction, INP captures
responsiveness throughout the user session. Good INP (under 200ms)
means interactions feel instant. Poor INP (over 500ms) creates
a sluggish, frustrating experience where the page feels broken.

audits.name: Largest Contentful Paint (LCP) Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines Largest Contentful Paint (LCP) performance,
a Core Web Vital that measures loading performance. LCP marks
the point when the largest image or text block becomes visible
within the viewport. It evaluates current LCP scores, identifies
the LCP element, analyzes causes of slow LCP, and provides
optimization recommendations.
audits.why_it_matters:
LCP is one of Google's Core Web Vitals and directly impacts search
rankings. Good LCP (under 2.5 seconds) indicates pages load quickly
for users. Poor LCP (over 4 seconds) creates a negative user
experience and can hurt rankings. LCP is particularly important
for mobile users with slower connections.

audits.name: Time to First Byte (TTFB) Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines Time to First Byte (TTFB) performance, which
measures the time from when a user requests a page to when the
first byte of the response arrives. TTFB is a foundational metric
that affects all subsequent performance metrics. It evaluates
server response times, identifies bottlenecks, and provides
infrastructure optimization recommendations.
audits.why_it_matters:
TTFB represents the sum of redirect time, DNS lookup, connection
time, TLS negotiation, and server processing time. High TTFB
(over 800ms) delays everything else - FCP, LCP, and interactivity.
Good TTFB (under 200ms) gives pages a head start on rendering.
TTFB is especially important for performance in distant regions.

audits.name: Geo-Targeting Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates geographic targeting implementation including
ccTLD usage, subdomain/subdirectory structure for regions, Search
Console geo-targeting settings, CDN configuration, server location,
and IP-based redirects. It assesses how effectively the site targets
specific geographic regions for search visibility.
audits.why_it_matters:
Geographic targeting signals help search engines understand which
countries or regions specific content is intended for. Incorrect
geo-targeting can result in content appearing in wrong regional
search results, being outranked by local competitors, or missing
key international markets. Proper geo-targeting is essential for
businesses operating in multiple countries or targeting specific regions.

audits.name: Hreflang Implementation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates hreflang tag implementation for websites targeting
multiple languages or regions. It examines HTML link elements, HTTP headers,
and XML sitemaps for proper hreflang annotations, validates language/region
codes against ISO standards, checks for bidirectional linking (return tags),
and identifies x-default implementation for international fallback.
audits.why_it_matters:
Hreflang tags tell search engines which language and regional versions of
pages to show users based on their location and language preferences.
Incorrect implementation leads to the wrong language version appearing in
search results, duplicate content issues across language versions, and
wasted crawl budget. Proper hreflang is essential for international SEO
success and user experience for global audiences.

audits.name: International URL Structure Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates URL structure strategy for international websites,
examining the choice between ccTLDs (example.de), subdomains (de.example.com),
subdirectories (example.com/de/), and parameter-based approaches. It assesses
URL consistency, language/region indicators in URLs, canonical URL handling,
and internal linking structure across regional versions.
audits.why_it_matters:
URL structure is fundamental to international SEO architecture. The chosen
approach affects crawl efficiency, link equity distribution, geo-targeting
signals, and management complexity. Inconsistent URL structures confuse
search engines and users, dilute link authority, and create indexing
problems. A well-planned international URL structure enables better
rankings in regional search results.

audits.name: Language Targeting Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates language targeting implementation including HTML
lang attributes, Content-Language headers, language-specific URLs,
language detection and switching mechanisms, and content translation
quality signals. It assesses how effectively the site communicates
content language to search engines and users.
audits.why_it_matters:
Proper language targeting ensures search engines serve the correct
language version to users and correctly index multilingual content.
Incorrect language signals lead to wrong language versions appearing
in search results, frustrated users bouncing immediately, and lost
traffic from international markets. Language targeting is foundational
to international SEO success.

audits.name: Regional Content Quality Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the quality and regional relevance of localized
content across different language and regional versions. It examines
translation quality, cultural adaptation, regional keyword optimization,
local terminology usage, currency/unit localization, and content
parity between regional versions.
audits.why_it_matters:
High-quality regional content is essential for international SEO success.
Poorly translated or culturally inappropriate content leads to high bounce
rates, low engagement, and poor conversion rates in international markets.
Search engines can detect low-quality translations and may rank
competitors with better localized content higher. Regional content quality
directly impacts trust, brand perception, and revenue in international markets.

audits.name: Anchor Text Distribution Audit
audits.description:
This audit analyzes anchor text distribution across internal and external
links to ensure a natural, diverse pattern that supports SEO without
triggering manipulation signals. It examines exact-match vs branded vs
natural anchor ratios, over-optimization patterns, and anchor text
relevance to target pages.
audits.why_it_matters:
Anchor text provides context to search engines about the content of
linked pages. Over-optimized anchor text (excessive exact-match keyword
anchors) can trigger algorithmic penalties as it signals manipulation.
Conversely, descriptive anchor text helps pages rank for relevant terms.
A natural anchor text profile includes branded, generic, naked URL, and
contextually varied anchors alongside targeted keywords.

audits.name: Backlink Quality Assessment Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the quality, relevance, and authority of backlinks
pointing to the website. It examines referring domain authority, link
relevance, anchor text distribution, link velocity, toxic link identification,
and competitive backlink gap analysis to assess off-page SEO strength.
audits.why_it_matters:
Backlinks remain one of Google's most important ranking factors. However,
link quality matters far more than quantity - a few high-authority, relevant
links outweigh hundreds of low-quality links. Toxic or spammy backlinks
can trigger algorithmic penalties or manual actions. Understanding backlink
profile strength relative to competitors is essential for SEO strategy
and identifying link building opportunities.

audits.name: Broken Link Detection Audit
audits.description:
This audit identifies broken links (404 errors) on the website including
internal links pointing to non-existent pages, external links to dead
resources, and broken image/resource references. It also identifies
soft 404s (pages that return 200 but are effectively error pages).
audits.why_it_matters:
Broken links create poor user experience, causing frustration when users
click expecting content and find nothing. They waste link equity that
could flow to live pages. Search engines view excessive broken links as
a sign of poor site maintenance, which can affect quality assessment.
Broken external links to your site (lost backlinks) waste acquired authority.

audits.name: Internal Link Equity Distribution Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates internal linking structure to understand how
link equity (PageRank) flows through the site. It examines link depth,
internal link distribution, pillar-cluster strategies, navigation
structure, and identifies pages receiving insufficient or excessive
internal link equity relative to their importance.
audits.why_it_matters:
Internal links distribute ranking power throughout the site and help
search engines understand page relationships and importance hierarchy.
Poor internal linking wastes authority on unimportant pages while
starving critical pages of link equity. Strategic internal linking
can significantly boost rankings for target pages without requiring
additional external backlinks.

audits.name: Nofollow Strategy Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the strategic use of rel="nofollow", rel="sponsored",
rel="ugc", and related link attributes. It examines whether nofollow is
being used appropriately for paid links, user-generated content, and
untrusted sources, while ensuring valuable internal links are not
inadvertently nofollowed.
audits.why_it_matters:
Proper use of nofollow and related attributes maintains compliance with
Google's link guidelines and prevents potential penalties for unnatural
links. Conversely, inappropriate nofollow usage (on internal links or
valuable editorial links) wastes link equity. Google introduced sponsored
and ugc attributes to provide more specific signals about link types.

audits.name: Google Business Profile Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates Google Business Profile (formerly Google My Business)
optimization for local search visibility. It examines profile completeness,
category selection, NAP accuracy, photos, posts, Q&A, reviews, attributes,
and Google's local pack ranking factors to maximize local search presence.
audits.why_it_matters:
Google Business Profile is the most important factor for local pack
rankings - the prominent map results shown for local searches. An
optimized GBP can dramatically increase local visibility, phone calls,
website clicks, and in-store visits. 46% of Google searches have local
intent, and businesses in the local pack receive the majority of clicks.
GBP is also critical for voice search results.

audits.name: Local Citation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates local business citations - mentions of business
name, address, and phone (NAP) across directories, review sites, social
platforms, and industry-specific listings. It assesses citation quantity,
accuracy, consistency, and coverage on key platforms critical for local
search rankings.
audits.why_it_matters:
Citations are a foundational local ranking factor. Consistent citations
across authoritative directories validate business information to search
engines and increase local visibility. Inconsistent or inaccurate citations
confuse search engines and users, potentially harming local rankings.
Citation building remains one of the most effective local SEO strategies.

audits.name: Local Business Schema Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates structured data markup for local businesses,
examining LocalBusiness schema (and its subtypes), PostalAddress,
GeoCoordinates, OpeningHoursSpecification, and related schemas that
help search engines understand business information for local search
results and rich snippets.
audits.why_it_matters:
Structured data helps search engines understand and verify business
information, potentially leading to enhanced search result displays
(rich snippets) with hours, reviews, and location information. While
not a direct ranking factor, proper schema markup supports local SEO
by providing clear signals about business type, location, and services.

audits.name: NAP Consistency Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates Name, Address, and Phone (NAP) consistency across
the website, Google Business Profile, social media, directories, and
all online mentions. It examines formatting consistency, abbreviation
usage, phone number formatting, and address standardization to ensure
search engines can confidently connect all mentions to the same business.
audits.why_it_matters:
NAP consistency is a fundamental local ranking factor. Search engines
use NAP matching to validate business legitimacy and connect citations.
Inconsistent NAP creates confusion - Google may not recognize mentions
as the same business, diluting local ranking signals. Even minor
variations (St vs Street, LLC vs not) can impact citation recognition.

audits.name: Review Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates online review management practices across Google,
Yelp, Facebook, and industry-specific review platforms. It examines
review quantity, rating trends, response practices, sentiment analysis,
review generation strategies, and policy compliance to optimize local
search rankings and reputation.
audits.why_it_matters:
Reviews are a significant local ranking factor and heavily influence
consumer decisions. 93% of consumers read online reviews before
purchasing. Review quantity, velocity, diversity, and ratings all
impact local pack rankings. Review response signals engagement and
customer service quality. Poor review management directly impacts both
rankings and conversion rates.

audits.name: Mobile Friendliness Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates website mobile-friendliness by examining responsive
design implementation, touch target sizing, font legibility, viewport
configuration, and mobile-specific rendering. It assesses compliance
with Google's mobile-first indexing requirements and Core Web Vitals
metrics on mobile devices.
audits.why_it_matters:
Google uses mobile-first indexing, meaning the mobile version of content
is used for indexing and ranking. Sites that are not mobile-friendly face
significant ranking penalties. With over 60% of searches occurring on
mobile devices, poor mobile experience directly impacts traffic, engagement,
and conversion rates. Mobile-unfriendly sites see higher bounce rates
and lower time-on-site metrics.

audits.name: Mobile Page Speed Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates mobile page speed performance including Core Web
Vitals (LCP, FID/INP, CLS), Time to First Byte (TTFB), First Contentful
Paint (FCP), and mobile-specific optimizations. It analyzes render-blocking
resources, JavaScript execution, image optimization, and caching strategies
from a mobile perspective with constrained CPU and network conditions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Page speed is a direct Google ranking factor, with mobile speed being
particularly critical since the mobile-first indexing update. Google's
Core Web Vitals are now part of the Page Experience signal that affects
rankings. Slow mobile pages have significantly higher bounce rates -
53% of mobile users abandon sites that take over 3 seconds to load.
Mobile page speed directly impacts conversions, engagement, and revenue.

audits.name: Responsive Design Implementation Audit
audits.description:
This audit comprehensively evaluates responsive web design implementation,
including CSS media queries, fluid grids, flexible images, breakpoint
strategy, and layout adaptability. It examines how content reflows and
adapts across mobile, tablet, and desktop viewports to ensure consistent
user experience and SEO performance.
audits.why_it_matters:
Responsive design is fundamental to mobile-first indexing success. Google
evaluates how well content adapts to different screen sizes when determining
rankings. Poorly implemented responsive design leads to layout shifts,
content clipping, and user frustration. Sites with broken responsive
layouts see higher bounce rates on mobile and lower engagement metrics
that negatively impact SEO rankings.

audits.name: Touch Element Sizing Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates touch target sizing and spacing for interactive
elements on mobile devices. It examines buttons, links, form inputs,
and other tappable elements to ensure they meet minimum size requirements
(48x48 CSS pixels) and have adequate spacing to prevent mis-taps.
The audit covers both visual design and CSS implementation.
audits.why_it_matters:
Google flags tap targets that are too small as mobile usability errors
in Search Console, which can impact mobile search rankings. Small touch
targets cause user frustration, accidental taps, and accessibility issues
for users with motor impairments. Proper touch target sizing is essential
for mobile usability, accessibility compliance (WCAG), and SEO health.

audits.name: Viewport Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines viewport meta tag configuration across all HTML
pages to ensure proper mobile rendering. It validates the viewport
meta tag syntax, settings (width, initial-scale, user-scalable), and
consistency across the site. Proper viewport configuration is fundamental
to mobile-first indexing and responsive design.
audits.why_it_matters:
The viewport meta tag controls how mobile browsers render pages. Without
it, or with incorrect configuration, browsers assume a desktop-width
viewport and scale down, making content unreadable. This is a primary
mobile-friendliness signal - pages without proper viewport configuration
will fail Google's mobile-friendly test and face ranking penalties in
mobile search results.

audits.name: Content Quality Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates content quality factors that influence SEO
performance and user engagement. It assesses content depth and
comprehensiveness, originality (duplicate content detection),
readability metrics, E-E-A-T signals, content freshness, multimedia
integration, and alignment with search intent for target queries.
audits.why_it_matters:
Google's core ranking systems heavily weight content quality through
the Helpful Content System. Thin, duplicate, or low-quality content
can trigger site-wide ranking suppression. High-quality content that
demonstrates expertise and satisfies user intent ranks better, earns
more backlinks, and generates higher engagement and conversions.

audits.name: Heading Hierarchy Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines HTML heading tag usage (H1-H6) across the website
for proper hierarchical structure and SEO optimization. It evaluates
single H1 usage per page, logical heading hierarchy (no skipped levels),
keyword inclusion in headings, heading length, and semantic correctness.
Proper heading structure helps both search engines and users understand
content organization.
audits.why_it_matters:
Heading tags provide a semantic outline of page content for search
engines and assistive technologies. Proper hierarchy improves content
comprehension, accessibility, and can influence rankings. Multiple H1s,
skipped heading levels, or empty headings signal poor content structure
and can negatively impact both SEO and user experience.

audits.name: Internal Linking Strategy Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the internal linking structure across the website.
It evaluates link distribution (orphaned pages, over-linked pages),
anchor text optimization, contextual linking practices, navigation
structure, PageRank flow patterns, link depth to important pages,
and broken internal links.
audits.why_it_matters:
Internal links distribute PageRank throughout the site, help search
engines discover content, establish content hierarchy, and guide
users to related content. Poor internal linking can result in orphaned
pages that never get indexed, important pages that don't rank due to
insufficient internal link equity, and poor user navigation experience.

audits.name: Keyword Optimization Assessment
audits.description:
This audit examines keyword usage and optimization across the website.
It evaluates keyword placement in critical elements (title, H1, URL,
first paragraph), keyword density (target 1-2%), semantic keyword
variations (LSI keywords), keyword cannibalization between pages,
and alignment between page content and target search queries.
audits.why_it_matters:
Proper keyword optimization helps search engines understand page
relevance for specific queries. Under-optimization means missing
ranking opportunities; over-optimization (keyword stuffing) can
trigger spam penalties. Strategic keyword placement and natural
integration maximize search visibility while maintaining content
quality.

audits.name: Meta Description Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines meta description tags across the website for
optimization. It evaluates description length (120-160 characters
optimal), uniqueness across pages, call-to-action inclusion,
keyword usage, and compelling copy that encourages clicks.
While not a direct ranking factor, meta descriptions significantly
impact click-through rates from search results.
audits.why_it_matters:
Meta descriptions appear as the snippet text in search results,
directly influencing whether users click on your result. Well-crafted
descriptions with clear value propositions and calls-to-action can
significantly improve CTR. Poor or missing descriptions result in
Google auto-generating snippets, often with suboptimal text.

audits.name: Title Tag Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines HTML title tags across the website for SEO
optimization. It evaluates title length (50-60 characters optimal),
uniqueness across pages, keyword placement, brand consistency,
clickability for search results, and proper HTML implementation.
Title tags are one of the most important on-page SEO elements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Title tags are the primary text displayed in search engine results
and browser tabs. They directly influence click-through rates and
are a significant ranking factor. Poorly optimized titles (too long,
missing keywords, duplicates) reduce search visibility and traffic.
Compelling, well-structured titles improve both rankings and clicks.

audits.name: Breadcrumb Schema Implementation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines BreadcrumbList structured data implementation
for navigation and search result enhancement. It evaluates schema
completeness (itemListElement, position, name, item), accuracy of
breadcrumb paths, consistency with visible breadcrumbs, URL validity,
and proper nesting structure per schema.org specifications.
audits.why_it_matters:
Breadcrumb structured data enables Google to display breadcrumb
navigation in search results instead of raw URLs, improving click-
through rates and helping users understand page context. Proper
implementation also reinforces site hierarchy understanding for
search engines and improves navigation accessibility.

audits.name: JSON-LD Implementation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines JSON-LD (JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data)
structured data implementation specifically. It evaluates JSON syntax
validity, @context and @type declarations, property naming, script tag
placement, multiple schema handling, and dynamic JSON-LD generation
for JavaScript frameworks.
audits.why_it_matters:
JSON-LD is Google's preferred format for structured data due to its
separation from HTML content and ease of implementation. Incorrect
JSON-LD implementation (syntax errors, invalid contexts, improper
nesting) results in the structured data being ignored entirely.
Proper implementation ensures consistent rich result eligibility.

audits.name: Open Graph Tag Implementation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines Open Graph (og:) meta tag implementation for
social media optimization. It evaluates required tags (og:title,
og:type, og:image, og:url), optional enhancements (og:description,
og:site_name), image specifications (dimensions, format), and
implementation consistency across page types.
audits.why_it_matters:
Open Graph tags control how pages appear when shared on Facebook,
LinkedIn, and other social platforms. Without proper OG tags, these
platforms may display incorrect titles, images, or descriptions,
reducing click-through rates from social shares. Well-optimized
OG tags improve social engagement and referral traffic.

audits.name: Rich Snippet Eligibility Assessment
audits.description:
This audit assesses whether structured data implementation meets
Google's requirements for rich result display. It evaluates required
and recommended properties for each schema type, content policy
compliance, technical requirements, and actual rich result appearance
in search. Different rich result types have specific requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Rich results (star ratings, FAQ dropdowns, recipe cards, product
details) dramatically increase visibility and click-through rates
in search results. However, having structured data is not enough -
it must meet specific requirements for each rich result type.
Failing eligibility requirements means wasted implementation effort.

audits.name: Schema Markup Implementation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines Schema.org structured data markup implementation
across the website. It evaluates schema type selection, property
completeness, nesting accuracy, format consistency (JSON-LD vs
Microdata), validation errors, and alignment with Google's structured
data guidelines for rich result eligibility.
audits.why_it_matters:
Structured data helps search engines understand page content and
can enable rich results (star ratings, FAQs, breadcrumbs, products)
in search results. Proper implementation increases click-through
rates by 20-30% through enhanced search listings. Invalid or
incomplete markup is ignored, wasting implementation effort.

audits.name: Twitter Card Implementation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines Twitter Card meta tag implementation for optimal
appearance when content is shared on Twitter/X. It evaluates card
type selection (summary, summary_large_image, player, app), required
and optional meta tags (twitter:card, twitter:title, twitter:description,
twitter:image), image specifications, and fallback to Open Graph tags.
audits.why_it_matters:
Twitter Cards control how pages appear when shared on Twitter/X.
Proper implementation increases engagement with shared content
through rich previews with images, titles, and descriptions.
Without Twitter Cards (or Open Graph fallback), tweets with links
appear as plain URLs, dramatically reducing click-through rates.

audits.name: Canonical URL Implementation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the implementation of canonical URLs across the
website to ensure proper handling of duplicate or similar content.
It verifies self-referencing canonicals, cross-domain canonicals,
HTTP/HTTPS and www/non-www canonicalization, parameter handling,
pagination canonicalization, and consistency between canonical tags
and HTTP Link headers.
audits.why_it_matters:
Without proper canonical implementation, search engines may see
multiple versions of the same content as duplicates, diluting
ranking signals and potentially causing the wrong URL to rank.
Canonical tags consolidate link equity and crawl budget to your
preferred URLs, improving overall search performance.

audits.name: Crawlability Assessment
audits.description:
This audit examines whether search engine crawlers can effectively
discover, access, and navigate through all important pages on a website.
It evaluates crawl budget efficiency, identifies crawl blockers, assesses
internal link architecture, analyzes JavaScript rendering requirements,
and checks for orphaned pages that cannot be discovered.
audits.why_it_matters:
If search engines cannot crawl your website effectively, your pages
will not be indexed and will not appear in search results. Poor
crawlability can result from blocked resources, JavaScript rendering
issues, crawl budget waste on low-value pages, broken internal links,
or overly complex site architecture. Addressing crawlability issues
is the foundation of all SEO efforts.

audits.name: Indexability Assessment
audits.description:
This audit examines whether pages that search engines can crawl will
actually be added to the search index and appear in search results.
It evaluates indexing directives (meta robots, X-Robots-Tag), identifies
duplicate content issues, checks for thin content, assesses canonical
tag implementation, and analyzes Google Search Console index coverage.
audits.why_it_matters:
A page that is crawled but not indexed will never appear in search
results. Common indexability issues include noindex directives,
duplicate content, thin content, canonicalization errors, and
manual penalties. Understanding and resolving indexability issues
ensures your important pages can compete for search visibility.

audits.name: Redirect Chain Analysis Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines redirect implementations across the website to
identify chains, loops, and improper redirect status codes. It evaluates
301 vs 302 usage, redirect chain length, redirect loops, internal
redirects from internal links, HTTP to HTTPS redirects, and the impact
on page load time and crawl efficiency.
audits.why_it_matters:
Redirect chains waste crawl budget, dilute PageRank, slow page loads,
and can confuse search engines about the canonical URL. Each redirect
in a chain adds latency and risks losing link equity. Redirect loops
cause pages to be inaccessible. Using the wrong redirect type (302 vs
301) can prevent proper PageRank transfer.

audits.name: Robots.txt Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the robots.txt file configuration to ensure it
properly guides search engine crawlers. It validates syntax according
to RFC 9309, checks for common misconfigurations, verifies sitemap
declarations, evaluates bot-specific rules, and identifies directives
that may unintentionally block important content.
audits.why_it_matters:
Robots.txt is the first file search engines check when crawling a
website. Misconfigurations can completely block search engines from
accessing your content, waste crawl budget on unimportant pages, or
expose sensitive areas. A properly configured robots.txt optimizes
crawl efficiency and protects private content.

audits.name: URL Structure Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines URL structure and design patterns across the
website for SEO optimization. It evaluates URL length, readability,
keyword inclusion, folder hierarchy, use of hyphens vs underscores,
URL parameters, trailing slashes, case sensitivity, and consistency
of URL patterns across the site.
audits.why_it_matters:
Well-structured URLs improve user experience, click-through rates
in search results, and help search engines understand page content
and site hierarchy. Poor URL structure can create duplicate content,
confuse users, and miss keyword opportunities. Clean URLs are also
easier to share and link to.

audits.name: XML Sitemap Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines XML sitemap implementation to ensure it properly
communicates site structure to search engines. It validates XML format
according to the sitemaps.org protocol, checks URL validity and status,
verifies lastmod accuracy, assesses sitemap completeness against actual
site content, and reviews sitemap index structure for large sites.
audits.why_it_matters:
XML sitemaps help search engines discover and understand your site
structure, particularly for new pages, deep pages, or pages with
limited internal linking. Properly configured sitemaps can accelerate
indexing, communicate page importance via priority and changefreq,
and provide accurate lastmod dates to trigger re-crawling.

audits.name: Async Communication Practices Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates asynchronous communication effectiveness:
- Documentation-first communication practices
- Async decision-making processes
- Written communication quality
- Timezone-aware practices
- Balance of async vs sync communication

It assesses whether teams can collaborate effectively without
requiring real-time presence.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor async communication causes:
- Blocking dependencies on people's availability
- Exclusion of distributed team members
- Interruption-heavy work environments
- Decision delays waiting for meetings
- Knowledge locked in synchronous conversations

Effective async communication enables distributed teams, respects
deep work, and creates better documentation as a side effect.

audits.name: Escalation Path Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates escalation paths for:
- Technical problems and blockers
- Incident escalation during emergencies
- Organizational and people issues
- Cross-team coordination needs
- Executive escalation for critical decisions

It assesses whether people know how to escalate, escalation
works in practice, and escalations are resolved effectively.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor escalation paths cause:
- Extended incidents when help isn't reached
- Festering problems that should have been escalated
- Escalation anxiety preventing appropriate action
- Unclear accountability for resolution
- Issues ping-ponging without resolution

Clear escalation paths enable rapid response to problems
and appropriate engagement of decision-makers.

audits.name: Incident Communication Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates communication during incidents:
- Internal incident coordination
- Status page and external communication
- Stakeholder notification
- Post-incident communication
- Communication templates and playbooks

It assesses whether incidents are communicated effectively
to reduce confusion and maintain trust.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor incident communication causes:
- Confusion during response slowing resolution
- Stakeholders surprised by customer reports
- Customers losing trust from lack of updates
- Internal chaos from unclear coordination
- Repeated questions distracting responders

Effective incident communication enables coordinated response,
informed stakeholders, and maintained customer trust.

audits.name: Meeting Effectiveness Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates meeting practices:
- Meeting necessity and purpose clarity
- Preparation and agenda practices
- Time management and punctuality
- Decision capture and follow-up
- Meeting load and distribution

It identifies meeting waste and opportunities to improve
meeting effectiveness or reduce meeting burden.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor meeting practices cause:
- Significant time waste (often 30%+ of work time)
- Fragmented calendars preventing deep work
- Decisions made but not captured or followed up
- Meeting fatigue and disengagement
- Exclusion of those who can't attend

Effective meetings have clear purpose, engage participants,
and produce documented outcomes.

audits.name: Stakeholder Communication Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates communication with non-engineering stakeholders:
- Product management alignment
- Business/leadership updates
- Customer communication practices
- Status and progress reporting
- Technical translation for non-technical audiences

It assesses whether engineering effectively communicates status,
risks, and needs to stakeholders.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor stakeholder communication causes:
- Misaligned priorities between engineering and business
- Surprises when projects are delayed or fail
- Technical debt accumulation from ignored risks
- Eroded trust between engineering and stakeholders
- Decisions made without engineering input

Effective stakeholder communication ensures alignment,
appropriate expectations, and informed decision-making.

audits.name: Engineering Culture Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the overall engineering culture including stated values vs.
lived values, collaboration patterns, autonomy and ownership, how
decisions are made, how quality is prioritized, work-life balance,
and the overall environment for engineers. Evaluates both explicit
cultural artifacts and implicit cultural norms.
audits.why_it_matters:
Engineering culture determines whether talented engineers thrive or
leave. Strong cultures attract and retain talent, enable high
performance, and drive innovation. Dysfunctional cultures create
churn, reduce productivity, and accumulate technical debt as short-term
thinking dominates. Culture is the foundation on which all other
engineering practices are built.

audits.name: Failure and Postmortem Culture Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the organization's culture around failure and learning,
focusing on postmortem practices. Evaluates whether failures are
treated as learning opportunities or causes for blame, whether
postmortems are conducted blamelessy, whether action items are
completed, and whether learning is shared broadly.
audits.why_it_matters:
Organizations that learn from failure become more resilient over
time. Blameless postmortems surface root causes that would otherwise
remain hidden. Blame-oriented cultures drive fear, hiding, and
repeated failures. The difference between high-reliability organizations
and others is fundamentally about how they treat failure.

audits.name: Innovation Time Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses whether engineers have dedicated time for innovation,
experimentation, and self-directed projects. Evaluates policies
like 20% time, hack days, or innovation sprints, and more importantly,
whether these policies are actually used and valued. Examines outcomes
of innovation time to assess effectiveness.
audits.why_it_matters:
Dedicated innovation time enables engineers to explore new technologies,
solve problems creatively, and develop ideas that wouldn't emerge from
backlog-driven work. Many significant innovations (Gmail, Slack, etc.)
emerged from engineer-driven exploration. Without innovation time,
organizations optimize for short-term delivery at the cost of long-term
improvement.

audits.name: Psychological Safety Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses psychological safety within engineering teams using Edmondson's
framework. Evaluates whether team members feel safe to take interpersonal
risks including asking questions, admitting mistakes, proposing ideas,
and challenging the status quo without fear of embarrassment, punishment,
or negative career consequences.
audits.why_it_matters:
Google's Project Aristotle identified psychological safety as the most
important factor in high-performing teams. Without psychological safety,
engineers hide mistakes (leading to bigger failures), avoid asking
questions (leading to poor decisions), and don't share innovative ideas
(limiting improvement). Psychological safety is foundational to learning,
innovation, and quality.

audits.name: Technical Debt Attitude Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the organizational attitude and practices around technical
debt. Evaluates how technical debt is identified, tracked, communicated
to stakeholders, and prioritized against feature work. Examines whether
teams have authority and time to address debt, and whether leadership
understands and supports debt reduction.
audits.why_it_matters:
Technical debt, if unmanaged, accumulates interest that slows all
future development. Organizations that ignore technical debt eventually
reach a point where progress becomes extremely difficult. The attitude
toward debt determines whether it's managed proactively or allowed to
compound until it creates crises.

audits.name: API Documentation Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates API documentation across dimensions:
- Completeness (all endpoints/operations documented)
- Accuracy (documentation matches implementation)
- Usability (examples, error codes, tutorials)
- Accessibility (findable, navigable)
- Currency (kept up to date)

It covers REST APIs, GraphQL schemas, gRPC services, event schemas,
and other programmatic interfaces.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor API documentation causes:
- Integration delays and failures
- Support burden from consumer questions
- Misuse leading to outages
- Inability to adopt APIs
- Shadow APIs when developers build alternatives

Good API documentation enables self-service integration, reduces
support burden, and promotes API adoption.

audits.name: Architecture Documentation Assessment
audits.description:
This audit assesses architecture documentation quality across:
- System context diagrams and boundaries
- Component diagrams and interactions
- Data flow documentation
- Integration patterns and APIs
- Decision records and rationale
- Non-functional requirements and constraints

It evaluates whether documentation enables understanding, evolution,
and maintenance of the system architecture.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor architecture documentation leads to:
- Wrong decisions from incomplete understanding
- Duplicate systems built when existing ones unknown
- Integration failures from misunderstood boundaries
- Technical debt from lost architectural intent
- Slow onboarding and knowledge transfer

Good architecture documentation enables teams to understand systems,
make informed decisions, and evolve architecture appropriately.

audits.name: Decision Record Assessment
audits.description:
This audit assesses the practice of documenting technical decisions:
- Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) or equivalent
- Decision context and drivers
- Options considered and trade-offs
- Rationale for chosen approach
- Consequences and follow-up

It evaluates whether decisions are captured in a way that enables
understanding and appropriate revision.
audits.why_it_matters:
Undocumented decisions lead to:
- Repeated debates about settled questions
- Reversal of decisions without understanding context
- Lost knowledge when decision makers leave
- Inability to know when decisions should be revisited
- Cargo-culting patterns without understanding why

Documented decisions enable organizational learning, informed
evolution, and efficient onboarding.

audits.name: Documentation Freshness Assessment
audits.description:
This audit assesses documentation currency:
- Last update dates vs system changes
- Documentation review cadence
- Stale document detection
- Documentation maintenance process
- Version alignment between docs and systems

It identifies documentation that has drifted from reality
and evaluates processes to keep docs current.
audits.why_it_matters:
Stale documentation causes:
- Incorrect actions based on outdated information
- Lost trust in documentation leading to avoidance
- Wasted time discovering docs are wrong
- Dangerous operational mistakes
- Cumulative drift until docs become useless

Fresh documentation maintains credibility and enables safe,
efficient operations.

audits.name: Onboarding Documentation Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates onboarding documentation quality:
- Environment setup guides
- Architecture and system overviews
- Development workflow documentation
- Access provisioning guides
- First contribution guides
- Team practices and conventions

It assesses whether new engineers can become productive without
excessive hand-holding from teammates.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor onboarding documentation leads to:
- Extended time to productivity for new hires
- Excessive burden on existing team members
- Frustration and poor early experience
- Inconsistent knowledge transfer
- Hidden assumptions that trip up newcomers

Good onboarding documentation accelerates productivity, reduces
burden on the team, and improves new hire experience.

audits.name: README Quality Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates README file quality across repositories:
- Existence and visibility
- Project description and purpose
- Getting started instructions
- Usage examples
- Configuration documentation
- Contribution guidelines
- Maintenance status indicators

READMEs are the front door to projects and often the first
documentation new users encounter.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor READMEs lead to:
- Confusion about what a project does
- Inability to get started quickly
- Reduced adoption of internal libraries
- Repeated questions to maintainers
- Abandoned projects appearing maintained

Good READMEs enable self-service understanding, reduce support
burden, and improve project adoption.

audits.name: Runbook Completeness Assessment
audits.description:
This audit assesses operational runbook quality and coverage:
- Incident response procedures for each service
- Common troubleshooting guides
- Operational procedures (deployment, rollback, scaling)
- Escalation paths and decision trees
- Recovery procedures for failure scenarios

It evaluates whether on-call engineers can effectively respond
to incidents using available documentation.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incomplete runbooks lead to:
- Extended incident durations while engineers figure things out
- Incorrect actions that worsen incidents
- Knowledge loss when experienced engineers leave
- Inconsistent incident handling quality
- Increased stress and burnout for on-call engineers

Complete runbooks enable faster incident resolution, reduce
cognitive load on responders, and ensure consistent handling.

audits.name: Documentation Accessibility Assessment
audits.description:
This audit assesses documentation accessibility:
- Can people find documentation when needed?
- Are access permissions appropriate?
- Is documentation in consistent locations?
- Are formats accessible and readable?
- Does search work effectively?

It evaluates whether documentation exists but is practically
inaccessible due to discoverability or access issues.
audits.why_it_matters:
Inaccessible documentation is as bad as no documentation:
- People waste time searching or recreating
- Important information goes unused
- Knowledge silos persist despite documentation
- Frustration leads to documentation avoidance
- Investment in documentation is wasted

Accessible documentation enables self-service and reduces
dependency on asking others.

audits.name: Knowledge Retention Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates knowledge retention practices:
- Offboarding knowledge transfer processes
- Documentation handoff requirements
- Succession planning practices
- Knowledge continuity during transitions
- Historical knowledge preservation

It assesses whether the organization systematically retains
knowledge when people change roles or leave.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor knowledge retention leads to:
- Permanent knowledge loss when people leave
- Repeated learning of solved problems
- Orphaned systems no one understands
- Inability to maintain or evolve past work
- Organizational amnesia losing past lessons

Effective retention preserves organizational learning and
enables continuity despite personnel changes.

audits.name: Knowledge Sharing Practice Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates knowledge sharing practices including:
- Formal knowledge sharing mechanisms (tech talks, brown bags)
- Documentation practices and habits
- Code review as knowledge transfer
- Pairing and mentorship programs
- Cross-team collaboration practices
- Post-incident and retrospective learning

It assesses whether the organization actively promotes knowledge
flow or allows silos to form.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor knowledge sharing leads to:
- Duplicated effort across teams
- Repeated mistakes from unshared learnings
- Slow onboarding and skill development
- Fragile systems dependent on individual knowledge
- Innovation stagnation from isolated teams

Active knowledge sharing accelerates learning, reduces redundancy,
and builds organizational resilience.

audits.name: Search and Discoverability Assessment
audits.description:
This audit evaluates search and discovery capabilities:
- Documentation search effectiveness
- Code search capabilities
- People/expertise search
- Service/API discovery
- Cross-platform search integration

It assesses whether people can find what they need quickly
when they don't know exactly where it is.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor search and discoverability:
- Wastes time looking for existing resources
- Leads to duplicate work when existing solutions unfound
- Forces reliance on asking others
- Makes documentation investment worthless
- Slows onboarding and problem-solving

Effective discovery enables self-service and scales knowledge
access as organizations grow.

audits.name: Tribal Knowledge Risk Assessment
audits.description:
This audit identifies knowledge that exists only as "tribal knowledge":
- Undocumented system behaviors and workarounds
- Historical context for decisions
- Operational procedures held in heads
- Institutional knowledge about why things are done
- Relationships and informal processes

It assesses the risk of losing this knowledge and prioritizes
documentation or knowledge transfer efforts.
audits.why_it_matters:
Tribal knowledge creates severe organizational risk:
- Knowledge lost when people leave
- Inability to maintain systems when experts unavailable
- New team members cannot become effective
- Decisions made without critical context
- Hidden single points of failure

Capturing tribal knowledge builds organizational resilience
and enables scale without dependency on specific individuals.

audits.name: Continuous Improvement Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the organization's continuous improvement culture and practices
including how improvements are identified, how they're prioritized against
feature work, whether improvements are executed and measured, and whether
there's a systematic approach to getting better over time.
audits.why_it_matters:
Continuous improvement is essential for long-term competitiveness and
developer satisfaction. Organizations that continuously improve become
more efficient and effective over time, while those that don't stagnate
and accumulate process debt. Improvement is not automatic; it requires
intentional practice and investment.

audits.name: Developer Experience Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses developer experience across multiple dimensions including
flow state, cognitive load, and feedback loops (the DevEx framework).
Evaluates tooling quality, development environment, build and test
times, documentation, and overall developer satisfaction and productivity.
audits.why_it_matters:
Developer experience directly impacts productivity, quality, and
retention. Research shows that developers in high-DevEx environments
are 2x more productive and significantly less likely to leave.
Poor DevEx creates friction, frustration, and accumulated technical
debt as developers work around painful processes.

audits.name: DORA Metrics Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the four key DORA metrics that predict software delivery
performance: deployment frequency, lead time for changes, change
failure rate, and mean time to recovery. Evaluates whether these
metrics are tracked, understood, and used to drive improvement.
audits.why_it_matters:
DORA research spanning 7+ years and 30,000+ professionals shows that
these four metrics strongly predict both organizational performance
and employee satisfaction. Elite performers deploy on-demand (multiple
times per day), with lead time < 1 hour, change failure rate < 15%,
and MTTR < 1 hour. Organizations that don't measure can't improve.

audits.name: Feedback Loop Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the effectiveness of feedback loops throughout the development
lifecycle including technical feedback (build results, tests, linting,
production monitoring) and human feedback (code reviews, retrospectives,
performance reviews). Evaluates feedback speed, quality, and whether
feedback actually drives improvement.
audits.why_it_matters:
Fast, high-quality feedback loops are essential for learning and
improvement. DevEx research shows that feedback loop speed is one of
the top three factors affecting developer productivity. Slow or
low-quality feedback delays learning, allows problems to compound,
and frustrates engineers.

audits.name: Quality Metrics Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the quality metrics tracked including defect rates, escaped
defects, test coverage, code quality scores, and customer-reported
issues. Evaluates whether quality is measured systematically, how
metrics are used to drive improvement, and whether quality is
balanced against velocity.
audits.why_it_matters:
Quality metrics provide visibility into product health and engineering
effectiveness. Without measuring quality, organizations can't know if
they're improving or declining. Tracked quality metrics enable data-driven
decisions about where to invest in prevention, testing, and process
improvement.

audits.name: Team Velocity Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses how team velocity is measured, interpreted, and used for
planning and improvement. Evaluates whether velocity is understood
as a planning tool (not a performance metric), whether comparisons
across teams are avoided, and whether velocity is stable and predictable.
audits.why_it_matters:
Velocity, when properly used, enables predictable planning and helps
teams identify improvement opportunities. When misused (as a performance
metric, for cross-team comparison, or as a target), it creates perverse
incentives, gaming, and burnout. Understanding proper velocity use is
critical for sustainable delivery.

audits.name: Change Management Process Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the change management process covering how changes are
classified, reviewed, approved, and tracked. Examines the balance
between governance rigor and developer velocity. Evaluates whether
the process scales appropriately with risk level or applies uniform
overhead regardless of change scope.
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective change management protects production stability while
enabling velocity. Overly bureaucratic processes slow delivery and
encourage workarounds, while insufficient process leads to avoidable
incidents. The best organizations use lightweight, risk-proportionate
change processes that expedite routine changes while adding scrutiny
for high-risk modifications.

audits.name: Code Review Process Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the code review process including review assignment, turnaround
time, quality of feedback, reviewer load distribution, and impact on
both code quality and developer experience. Examines whether reviews
serve as effective quality gates while avoiding becoming bottlenecks.
audits.why_it_matters:
Code review is one of the highest-leverage activities in software
development. Effective reviews catch bugs before production, spread
knowledge across the team, and mentor junior developers. However,
dysfunctional review processes create bottlenecks, breed resentment,
and paradoxically reduce quality as reviewers rubber-stamp to clear
queues. Google research shows that code review is the primary way
developers learn codebases and spread best practices.

audits.name: Deployment Process Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the deployment process from both technical and organizational
perspectives. Examines deployment frequency, deployment autonomy (who
can deploy), deployment coordination practices, rollback procedures,
deployment windows, and the overall confidence and stress level
associated with deployments. Evaluates whether deployments are routine
non-events or high-stress ceremonies.
audits.why_it_matters:
DORA research consistently shows that deployment frequency is a key
predictor of both organizational performance and developer satisfaction.
Elite performers deploy multiple times per day with low stress, while
low performers batch large releases that carry high risk. The ability
to deploy frequently and safely depends on both technical capabilities
and organizational factors like trust, ownership, and process clarity.

audits.name: Development Workflow Assessment
audits.description:
Examines the complete development workflow from task assignment through
code merge. This includes branching strategy, commit practices, pull
request workflows, code review gates, CI integration, and merge
procedures. Evaluates both the documented process and actual team
practices to identify friction points and improvement opportunities.
audits.why_it_matters:
An efficient development workflow directly impacts team velocity,
code quality, and developer satisfaction. Poor workflows lead to
context switching, merge conflicts, delayed feedback, and accumulated
technical debt. Research from DORA shows that elite performers ship
code to production multiple times per day with a change failure rate
under 15%, enabled by streamlined workflows.

audits.name: Incident Management Process Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the complete incident management lifecycle including detection
and alerting, triage and escalation, response coordination, stakeholder
communication, resolution, and post-incident review. Evaluates both the
documented process and actual incident response capability through
review of recent incidents and interviews with responders.
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective incident management minimizes customer impact, reduces
responder stress, and accelerates organizational learning. Poor
incident management extends outages, burns out on-call engineers,
and fails to prevent recurrence. MTTR (mean time to recovery) is
a key DORA metric that correlates with overall software delivery
performance.

audits.name: Retrospective Practice Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the effectiveness of team retrospectives including how
frequently they occur, how well they're facilitated, whether all
voices are heard, what actions emerge, and critically, whether
those actions are actually completed. Evaluates retrospectives as
a learning and improvement mechanism rather than just a ceremony.
audits.why_it_matters:
Retrospectives are the primary mechanism for team-level continuous
improvement. Effective retrospectives surface problems early, build
shared understanding, and drive incremental improvements. Ineffective
retrospectives waste time, breed cynicism, and allow problems to
fester. The difference between high-performing teams and others often
lies in how well they learn and adapt through reflection.

audits.name: Bus Factor Analysis
audits.description:
Bus factor analysis identifies critical knowledge dependencies where
the loss of one or two individuals would significantly impact the
organization's ability to:
- Maintain and evolve systems
- Respond to incidents effectively
- Make key technical decisions
- Continue normal operations

This audit combines code analysis (commit history, code ownership),
organizational data (on-call coverage, escalation paths), and
interviews to identify single points of failure.
audits.why_it_matters:
Low bus factor creates existential risk for systems and teams:
- Unexpected departures can halt critical projects
- Incidents become crises when the only knowledgeable person is unavailable
- Knowledge loss is permanent when undocumented
- Remaining team members face impossible knowledge transfer burden

Organizations with healthy bus factors are resilient to change
and provide better work-life balance by not over-relying on individuals.

audits.name: Cross-Functional Team Assessment
