audits.description:
This audit assesses whether stream-aligned teams have the cross-functional
capabilities needed to deliver value end-to-end, including:
- Frontend and backend development skills
- DevOps and infrastructure capabilities
- Quality assurance and testing expertise
- Product and design involvement
- Data and analytics skills where needed

It identifies excessive dependencies on external teams that slow delivery.
audits.why_it_matters:
Teams that lack cross-functional capabilities face:
- Handoff delays waiting for other teams
- Coordination overhead reducing velocity
- Fragmented ownership leading to quality gaps
- Reduced autonomy limiting innovation

Truly cross-functional teams can own features end-to-end, make decisions
quickly, and deliver value to customers without extensive coordination.

audits.name: On-Call Rotation Health Assessment
audits.description:
This audit examines on-call rotation practices to assess:
- Rotation frequency and coverage adequacy
- Load distribution fairness across team members
- Skill coverage during on-call shifts
- Escalation path effectiveness
- Impact on engineer well-being and retention

It identifies unsustainable patterns and gaps in incident response capability.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor on-call practices create multiple risks:
- Burnout and attrition from unfair or excessive load
- Incident response failures when skills don't match problems
- Extended outages when escalation paths are unclear
- Team morale issues from perceived unfairness

Healthy on-call rotations enable reliable incident response while
maintaining engineer quality of life and team sustainability.

audits.name: Skill Coverage Assessment
audits.description:
This audit maps the technical and domain skills present on engineering
teams against the skills required to:
- Build and maintain their owned systems
- Respond to incidents and on-call situations
- Evolve the technology stack appropriately
- Onboard and train new team members

It identifies gaps, concentrations, and areas needing investment.
audits.why_it_matters:
Skill coverage gaps create operational risk:
- Systems become unmodifiable when no one understands them
- Incidents escalate when on-call lacks relevant expertise
- Technical debt grows when teams can't modernize
- Velocity drops when external help is constantly needed

Proactive skill coverage management enables resilient, capable teams
that can independently own their systems end-to-end.

audits.name: Team Autonomy Assessment
audits.description:
This audit examines the decision-making authority of engineering teams:
- Technical decisions they can make independently
- Approval gates and escalation requirements
- Freedom to experiment and innovate
- Ownership of their systems and processes

It identifies barriers to autonomy that slow delivery and reduce
team engagement.
audits.why_it_matters:
Low autonomy creates significant organizational drag:
- Decision bottlenecks delay delivery
- Engineers become disengaged when unable to decide
- Innovation stalls when experimentation requires approval
- Talented engineers leave for more autonomous environments

High-performing organizations push decisions to teams closest to the work,
enabling faster delivery and higher engagement.

audits.name: Team Composition Analysis
audits.description:
This audit examines the composition of engineering teams to assess whether
they have an appropriate balance of:
- Technical skill levels (junior, mid, senior, staff)
- Domain expertise coverage
- Experience diversity (tenure, backgrounds)
- Role distribution (engineers, tech leads, architects)

The audit evaluates whether teams are structured to deliver both short-term
velocity and long-term sustainability.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor team composition leads to:
- Knowledge silos when expertise is concentrated in few individuals
- Burnout when senior engineers carry disproportionate load
- Slow onboarding when there's insufficient mentorship capacity
- Technical debt accumulation when teams lack experienced guidance
- Delivery delays when critical skills are missing

Well-composed teams are more resilient, deliver more consistently, and
provide better career development opportunities for all members.

audits.name: Career Development Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the career development infrastructure for engineers including
documented career paths, leveling frameworks, growth opportunities,
promotion processes, and individual development planning. Evaluates
both the existence of these structures and their perceived fairness
and effectiveness.
audits.why_it_matters:
Clear career development paths are critical for engineer retention
and motivation. Without visible growth opportunities, talented
engineers leave for organizations that invest in their futures.
Well-designed career frameworks also ensure fair and consistent
promotion decisions, reducing bias and improving morale.

audits.name: Conference and Learning Budget Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the organization's investment in external learning opportunities
including conference attendance, training courses, certifications, books,
and other professional development. Evaluates both the budget allocation
and actual utilization of learning benefits.
audits.why_it_matters:
External learning opportunities expose engineers to new ideas, industry
trends, and best practices from outside the organization. Conference
attendance also provides networking opportunities and can improve
employer brand for recruiting. Underinvestment in external learning
leads to insularity and stagnation.

audits.name: Mentorship Program Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the mentorship infrastructure for engineers including formal
mentorship programs, mentor-mentee matching, expectations and structure,
and the broader culture of informal mentoring. Evaluates whether
mentorship effectively accelerates development and spreads knowledge.
audits.why_it_matters:
Mentorship accelerates engineer development, improves retention, and
spreads institutional knowledge. Junior engineers with mentors ramp
up faster and stay longer. Senior engineers who mentor report higher
job satisfaction. Without mentorship, knowledge silos form and new
hires struggle to become effective.

audits.name: Security Awareness Training Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the security awareness and secure coding training program
for engineering teams. Evaluates coverage of topics like secure
coding practices, threat modeling, vulnerability awareness, incident
response roles, and compliance requirements. Examines both initial
training and ongoing reinforcement.
audits.why_it_matters:
Security vulnerabilities often originate from developer mistakes that
could be prevented with proper training. Security awareness training
reduces the attack surface by ensuring engineers understand common
vulnerabilities, secure coding patterns, and their role in maintaining
security. Many compliance frameworks require documented security
training programs.

audits.name: Technical Training Program Assessment
audits.description:
Assesses the technical training program including onboarding training,
ongoing skill development, access to learning resources, time allocated
for learning, and the overall culture of continuous technical growth.
Evaluates both formal training programs and informal learning support.
audits.why_it_matters:
Technical skills require continuous investment as technology evolves
rapidly. Organizations that invest in training retain talent longer,
innovate faster, and maintain code quality as standards evolve. Without
structured training, skills stagnate, technical debt accumulates, and
engineers leave for employers who invest in their growth.

audits.name: AI Safety Guardrails
audits.description:
Evaluates AI safety guardrails including content filtering, output validation,
behavior constraints, anomaly detection, and fail-safe mechanisms. Assesses
protection against prompt injection, jailbreaking, harmful content generation,
hallucination, and other AI-specific risks. Reviews continuous monitoring
and incident response capabilities.
audits.why_it_matters:
AI systems can cause harm through malicious misuse, unintended behaviors,
or failure modes. Generative AI introduces risks of harmful content,
misinformation, and manipulation. Robust guardrails are essential for safe
deployment. EU AI Act requires risk management systems and safety measures.
Guardrail failures can cause reputational damage, legal liability, and harm.

audits.name: AI Transparency
audits.description:
Evaluates AI system transparency including disclosure of AI use to affected
parties, documentation of system capabilities and limitations, communication
of decision logic, and organizational accountability structures. Covers both
technical transparency (how systems work) and procedural transparency (how
organizations govern AI).
audits.why_it_matters:
Transparency is foundational to AI accountability and trust. Users have the
right to know when AI affects them and how decisions are made. Regulators
increasingly require AI transparency (EU AI Act Article 52, CCPA automated
decision rights). Lack of transparency erodes public trust and exposes
organizations to regulatory penalties and litigation.

audits.name: Algorithmic Bias Detection
audits.description:
Examines AI/ML systems for algorithmic bias across protected demographic
categories including race, gender, age, disability, and socioeconomic status.
Analyzes training data composition, model outputs, and decision patterns
to identify systematic discriminatory outcomes or disparate impact.
audits.why_it_matters:
Algorithmic bias can cause significant harm to individuals and communities,
leading to discriminatory lending, hiring, healthcare, and criminal justice
decisions. Beyond ethical concerns, biased systems expose organizations to
regulatory penalties under EU AI Act, civil rights litigation, and severe
reputational damage. Fair AI is both a moral imperative and legal requirement.

audits.name: Automated Decision Impact
audits.description:
Assesses automated decision-making (ADM) systems for their impact on
individuals' rights, opportunities, and wellbeing. Evaluates decision
significance, affected populations, potential harms, and safeguards
including human review and appeal processes. Conducts algorithmic impact
assessments for high-stakes decisions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Automated decisions can significantly impact individuals' access to credit,
employment, housing, healthcare, and justice. GDPR Article 22 restricts
solely automated decisions with significant effects. EU AI Act classifies
certain ADM systems as high-risk requiring extensive safeguards. Impact
assessment ensures proportionate protection and enables informed governance.

audits.name: Explainability
audits.description:
Assesses AI/ML system explainability including global model interpretability
(understanding overall model behavior), local explanations (explaining
individual predictions), and explanation quality (accuracy, completeness,
understandability). Evaluates both technical explainability methods and
stakeholder-appropriate explanation delivery.
audits.why_it_matters:
Explainability enables meaningful human oversight, informed consent, and
effective recourse for affected individuals. GDPR Article 22 provides right
to explanation for automated decisions. EU AI Act requires high-risk AI to
be interpretable. Beyond compliance, explainability builds trust, enables
debugging, and reveals potential biases or errors in model reasoning.

audits.name: Human Oversight
audits.description:
Assesses human oversight mechanisms for AI systems including human-in-the-loop
(human makes decisions), human-on-the-loop (human monitors and can intervene),
and human-in-command (human has full override authority). Evaluates whether
oversight is meaningful (not mere rubber-stamping) and whether humans have
the tools, training, and authority to intervene effectively.
audits.why_it_matters:
Meaningful human oversight is essential for AI accountability and safety.
EU AI Act requires human oversight measures for high-risk AI systems.
Oversight must be more than nominal - humans must have real capability
to understand, monitor, and override AI decisions. Automation bias can
undermine oversight if not actively addressed through system design.

audits.name: Model Fairness
audits.description:
Assesses ML model fairness using multiple mathematical definitions including
individual fairness (similar individuals treated similarly), group fairness
(equal treatment across demographic groups), and counterfactual fairness
(decisions unchanged by protected attribute changes). Evaluates trade-offs
between different fairness criteria and model performance.
audits.why_it_matters:
Different fairness definitions may conflict - achieving perfect demographic
parity can compromise individual fairness, and vice versa. Organizations must
make explicit choices about which fairness criteria to prioritize based on
context. Understanding these trade-offs is essential for defensible AI
governance and meeting regulatory requirements.

audits.name: Addiction by Design
audits.description:
Evaluates product design for patterns that exploit psychological
vulnerabilities to encourage compulsive usage. Examines variable reward
mechanisms, infinite scroll, social comparison features, FOMO-inducing
notifications, streaks and loss aversion, and other techniques derived
from behavioral psychology and gambling design. Assesses whether design
prioritizes engagement metrics over user wellbeing.
audits.why_it_matters:
Digital addiction harms mental health, relationships, and productivity.
Children and adolescents are especially vulnerable. Regulatory attention
is increasing - EU DSA addresses addictive design for minors, and children's
protection laws globally restrict manipulative features. Beyond regulation,
designing for addiction erodes trust and creates backlash. Ethical companies
differentiate through humane design.

audits.name: Dark Pattern Detection
audits.description:
Identifies and evaluates dark patterns - user interface designs that
manipulate, deceive, or coerce users into actions against their interests.
Covers categories including confirmshaming, hidden costs, trick questions,
forced continuity, roach motel, privacy zuckering, misdirection, bait and
switch, disguised ads, and friend spam. Assesses both intentional
manipulation and unintentional harmful patterns.
audits.why_it_matters:
Dark patterns undermine user trust, autonomy, and informed decision-making.
Regulators increasingly target dark patterns - FTC enforces against deceptive
practices, EU Digital Services Act prohibits manipulative design, and CCPA
specifically bans dark patterns in privacy choices. Beyond legal risk, dark
patterns damage brand reputation and customer relationships.

audits.name: Notification Ethics
audits.description:
Evaluates notification systems for ethical use of user attention.
Assesses notification frequency, timing, content, urgency signals,
and user control mechanisms. Examines whether notifications serve user
needs or primarily drive engagement metrics. Reviews opt-in/opt-out
mechanisms, bundling, and quiet hours respect.
audits.why_it_matters:
Notifications are powerful tools that can either help users or manipulate
them. Excessive or manipulative notifications fragment attention, increase
stress, and train users to ignore important communications. Poor notification
practices damage brand perception and lead to app deletion. Respectful
notification design builds trust and sustainable engagement.

audits.name: Screen Time Consideration
audits.description:
Evaluates whether product design respects user time as a finite resource.
Assesses features for time awareness including usage dashboards, session
limits, break reminders, and intentional friction. Reviews whether success
metrics prioritize time-on-site or value delivered. Examines efficiency
of user journeys and presence of unnecessary time sinks.
audits.why_it_matters:
User attention is finite and valuable. Products that maximize time spent
rather than value delivered exploit users. Excessive screen time is linked
to mental health issues, especially in youth. Regulators increasingly
require time awareness features, particularly for minors. Designing for
time respect builds sustainable user relationships and differentiates
ethical products.

audits.name: User Autonomy Respect
audits.description:
Evaluates respect for user autonomy including informed choice, meaningful
control, reversibility of actions, and freedom from manipulation. Assesses
whether users can understand, control, and exit their relationship with
the product. Reviews transparency of algorithmic influence, data usage,
and system behavior. Examines barriers to user agency.
audits.why_it_matters:
User autonomy is a fundamental ethical principle underlying privacy law,
consumer protection, and human rights frameworks. Products that undermine
autonomy through manipulation, lock-in, or opacity violate user trust and
face increasing regulatory scrutiny. Respecting autonomy creates sustainable
user relationships built on genuine value rather than exploitation.

audits.name: Digital Divide Consideration
audits.description:
Examines how well a technology product or service accommodates users
who face digital divide barriers including:
- Limited or no broadband access (dial-up, mobile-only, satellite)
- Older or lower-powered devices
- Low digital literacy or technology familiarity
- Intermittent connectivity or data caps
- Lack of access to technical support

Reviews application performance, offline capabilities, data efficiency,
progressive enhancement strategies, and accessibility for users with
varying technolog
audits.why_it_matters:
The digital divide affects billions globally and creates systemic exclusion
from digital services. Products designed only for high-bandwidth, modern
devices, and technically proficient users:
- Exclude rural, elderly, and economically disadvantaged populations
- Reinforce existing socioeconomic inequalities
- Miss significant market opportunities in developing regions
- May violate accessibility mandates in public sector contracts
- Create barriers to essential services increasingly delivered di

audits.name: Economic Accessibility
audits.description:
Assesses how well a product or service accommodates users with
varying economic means, examining:
- Pricing structures and tier accessibility
- Free tier functionality and limitations
- Payment method inclusivity
- Cost transparency and predictability
- Affordability relative to target markets
- Financial barriers to essential features

Reviews pricing models, payment systems, and feature gating to
ensure economic circumstances don't create undue barriers to access.
audits.why_it_matters:
Economic barriers to technology access perpetuate inequality and
exclude large populations from digital participation:
- Premium-only features may gatekeep essential functionality
- Complex pricing confuses users and leads to unexpected costs
- Limited payment options exclude unbanked/underbanked populations
- Regional pricing that ignores purchasing power parity excludes users
- Subscription fatigue disproportionately affects lower-income users

Organizations that prioritize economic accessibil

audits.name: Geographic Inclusion
audits.description:
Examines how well a technology product or service accommodates
users across different geographic regions, assessing:
- Service availability by country and region
- Infrastructure dependencies (CDN coverage, data centers)
- Latency and performance across regions
- Compliance with local regulations
- Localization beyond language (date formats, currencies, addresses)
- Feature parity across regions
- Rural vs. urban access considerations
audits.why_it_matters:
Geographic limitations in technology services create digital exclusion
and can reinforce global inequalities:
- Users in certain regions may be completely blocked from services
- Poor performance in some areas creates second-class user experiences
- Lack of localization signals that some markets are not valued
- Regulatory non-compliance can expose users to legal risks
- Urban-centric design neglects rural populations globally

Geographic inclusion enables global reach and demonstrates commitmen

audits.name: Language Inclusion
audits.description:
Examines the language accessibility of a product or service, assessing:
- Number and selection of supported languages
- Translation quality and cultural appropriateness
- Right-to-left (RTL) language support
- Support for non-Latin character sets
- Language detection and switching mechanisms
- Accessibility of language settings
- Consistency of translations across features
- Support for language variants and dialects
audits.why_it_matters:
Language barriers are among the most significant obstacles to digital
inclusion:
- 75% of internet users speak a language other than English as primary
- Poor translations or missing languages exclude entire populations
- RTL language issues make products unusable for Arabic, Hebrew speakers
- Machine translations without review can be offensive or confusing
- Language-only content excludes users with low literacy in any language

Comprehensive language support demonstrates commitment to global

audits.name: Representation Diversity
audits.description:
Examines how diverse populations are represented within a product
or service, assessing:
- Diversity in stock imagery and illustrations
- Inclusivity of example names, personas, and sample data
- Representation in marketing and promotional materials
- Diversity of voices in testimonials and case studies
- Avatar and profile customization options
- Default assumptions in forms and workflows
- Representation in documentation and tutorials
- Inclusive language and terminology throughout
audits.why_it_matters:
Representation matters for product adoption, user trust, and
social responsibility:
- Users who don't see themselves reflected may feel excluded
- Homogeneous representation reinforces societal biases
- Default assumptions can alienate users (e.g., gendered honorifics)
- Lack of diverse testing leads to blind spots in product design
- Representation affects brand perception and market reach
- Poor representation can cause reputational and legal risks

Inclusive representation signals that a prod

audits.name: Anonymization Effectiveness
audits.description:
Assesses effectiveness of anonymization and pseudonymization techniques
in preventing re-identification of individuals. Evaluates techniques
including k-anonymity, l-diversity, t-closeness, differential privacy,
and data masking against re-identification attacks including linkage
attacks, inference attacks, and auxiliary data correlation.
audits.why_it_matters:
Ineffective anonymization can expose personal data despite intended
protections. GDPR only exempts truly anonymous data - pseudonymized data
remains personal data. Re-identification can occur through linkage with
publicly available data. Organizations believing they hold anonymous data
may face unexpected compliance obligations when anonymization fails.

audits.name: Consent Management
audits.description:
Evaluates consent management practices including consent collection
mechanisms, granularity, record-keeping, withdrawal capabilities, and
enforcement. Assesses whether consent is freely given, specific, informed,
and unambiguous as required by GDPR. Reviews consent flows, dark patterns,
and the ease of consent withdrawal.
audits.why_it_matters:
Valid consent is a primary lawful basis for personal data processing under
GDPR. Invalid consent makes processing unlawful, exposing organizations to
enforcement action and fines. Users increasingly expect transparent consent
practices. Poor consent UX erodes trust and may constitute deceptive practice.
Dark patterns in consent interfaces face increasing regulatory scrutiny.

audits.name: Data Minimization
audits.description:
Evaluates adherence to the data minimization principle requiring that
personal data collected is adequate, relevant, and limited to what is
necessary for specified purposes. Reviews data collection points, storage
practices, retention periods, and processing operations against stated
purposes to identify excessive data collection or retention.
audits.why_it_matters:
Data minimization is a foundational GDPR principle (Article 5(1)(c)) and
privacy best practice. Collecting more data than needed increases breach
exposure, regulatory risk, and user privacy harm. Minimization reduces
attack surface, simplifies compliance, and builds user trust. Violations
can result in significant GDPR fines (up to 4% of global revenue).

audits.name: Data Subject Rights
audits.description:
Evaluates implementation of data subject rights under GDPR including the
right of access (Article 15), rectification (Article 16), erasure/right
to be forgotten (Article 17), restriction of processing (Article 18),
data portability (Article 20), and objection (Article 21). Assesses both
technical capability and operational readiness to fulfill requests.
audits.why_it_matters:
Data subject rights are fundamental to GDPR compliance. Failure to honor
rights requests within required timeframes (typically 30 days) constitutes
a violation subject to enforcement action. Beyond compliance, honoring
privacy rights builds trust and demonstrates respect for users. Organizations
must be technically capable of fulfilling all applicable rights.

audits.name: Privacy by Design
audits.description:
Assesses implementation of Privacy by Design (PbD) principles including
proactive privacy measures, privacy as default settings, privacy embedded
in design, full functionality (positive-sum), end-to-end security, visibility
and transparency, and respect for user privacy. Evaluates architectural
decisions, development processes, and technical implementations against
these principles.
audits.why_it_matters:
Privacy by Design is mandated by GDPR Article 25 and represents best practice
for building privacy-respecting systems. Retrofitting privacy is expensive
and often incomplete. PbD reduces compliance risk, builds user trust, and
creates competitive advantage. Organizations that embed privacy in design
avoid costly remediation and enforcement actions.

audits.name: Third-Party Data Sharing
audits.description:
Evaluates data sharing relationships with third parties including
processors, joint controllers, and data recipients. Assesses lawful
basis, contractual protections, data transfer mechanisms, user
transparency, and ongoing oversight of third-party data handling.
Covers both technical data flows and governance arrangements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Organizations remain accountable for data shared with third parties.
Inadequate third-party oversight has led to major breaches and regulatory
enforcement (e.g., Facebook-Cambridge Analytica). GDPR requires processor
contracts (Article 28) and transfer mechanisms for international transfers.
Poor third-party governance is one of the most common compliance failures.

audits.name: Child Safety
audits.description:
Examines protections for children and minors using digital services,
assessing:
- Age verification and age-gating mechanisms
- COPPA compliance for under-13 data collection
- Age-appropriate design principles (AADC compliance)
- Parental consent and control mechanisms
- Content moderation for child safety
- CSAM detection and reporting
- Grooming and predatory behavior prevention
- Minor-specific privacy protections
- Child-safe default settings
audits.why_it_matters:
Children face unique risks online and deserve special protections:
- COPPA violations carry significant FTC penalties
- UK AADC and state age-appropriate design laws are expanding
- CSAM is a strict liability offense requiring mandatory reporting
- Predatory targeting of minors causes severe harm
- Addictive design impacts developing minds differently
- Default privacy settings often expose children
- Parental controls are essential for younger users
- Regulatory and legal exposure is increasing

audits.name: Harassment Prevention
audits.description:
Examines systems and processes for preventing and addressing
online harassment, assessing:
- Anti-harassment policies and definitions
- User blocking and muting capabilities
- Harassment reporting mechanisms
- Report review and response processes
- Proactive harassment detection
- Escalation to law enforcement when appropriate
- Victim support and resources
- Repeat offender management
- Coordinated harassment prevention
audits.why_it_matters:
Online harassment causes significant harm and drives users away:
- Harassment disproportionately affects marginalized groups
- Victims experience psychological, professional, and physical harm
- Platforms that enable harassment face regulatory and legal action
- Users leave platforms where they don't feel safe
- Harassment reduces diversity and participation
- Coordinated harassment campaigns require specialized response
- Inadequate response normalizes abusive behavior

Effective harassment pre

audits.name: Misinformation Prevention
audits.description:
Examines systems and processes for addressing misinformation
and disinformation, assessing:
- Misinformation policy definitions and scope
- Fact-checking partnerships and processes
- Content labeling and warning systems
- Algorithmic amplification controls
- User reporting for misinformation
- Authoritative source surfacing
- Election and health misinformation handling
- Coordinated inauthentic behavior detection
- Transparency reporting on misinformation
audits.why_it_matters:
Misinformation causes significant societal harm and creates
platform liability:
- Health misinformation can lead to deaths (vaccine, COVID)
- Election misinformation threatens democratic processes
- Platforms face increasing regulatory pressure globally
- Algorithmic amplification accelerates misinformation spread
- Users lose trust when platforms spread false information
- DSA requires addressing systemic risks including misinformation
- Inaction creates legal and reputational exposure

audits.name: User Safety Priority
audits.description:
Examines how user safety is prioritized throughout the product
lifecycle, assessing:
- Safety-by-design principles in product development
- Risk assessment processes for new features
- User safety incident response capabilities
- Balance of growth metrics with safety considerations
- Safety features available to users (blocking, reporting)
- Proactive safety monitoring and intervention
- Crisis response and user communication
- Safety team resourcing and authority
audits.why_it_matters:
User safety failures have severe consequences for individuals
and organizations:
- Platforms have been implicated in real-world harm
- Safety incidents lead to regulatory action and legislation
- Users lose trust when safety is deprioritized for growth
- Lack of safety features enables abuse and harassment
- Reactive safety approaches fail to prevent harm
- Under-resourced safety teams cannot protect users effectively
- Legal liability for foreseeable harm is increasing

Prioritizing user safety

audits.name: Vulnerability Disclosure Ethics
audits.description:
Examines the ethics of vulnerability disclosure practices, assessing:
- Existence and accessibility of vulnerability reporting channels
- Safe harbor protections for security researchers
- Response timeliness and researcher communication
- Coordinated disclosure policy and practices
- Bug bounty program fairness and transparency
- Public disclosure timeline ethics
- Researcher acknowledgment and credit
- Legal treatment of good-faith researchers
audits.why_it_matters:
Ethical vulnerability disclosure practices protect both users and
the security research community:
- Without safe harbor, researchers fear legal action for helping
- Hostile policies drive vulnerabilities to black markets
- Slow or opaque responses leave users at risk longer
- Fair bug bounties attract skilled researchers
- Coordinated disclosure balances researcher freedom and user protection
- Poor practices damage reputation in security community
- Users depend on responsible disclosure to pr

audits.name: Community Impact
audits.description:
Examines the broader impact of technology products and operations
on communities, assessing:
- Local community effects (housing, traffic, infrastructure)
- Environmental impact on surrounding areas
- Community engagement and feedback mechanisms
- Philanthropic and community investment programs
- Displacement effects (gentrification, local business impact)
- Community safety and wellbeing considerations
- Social cohesion effects of platform features
- Disaster response and community support capab
audits.why_it_matters:
Technology companies have significant impacts on communities beyond
their direct users:
- Tech hubs drive gentrification and housing cost increases
- Data centers affect local water and energy resources
- Platforms can fragment or strengthen community bonds
- Corporate presence changes local business ecosystems
- Community support during crises builds goodwill and resilience
- Neglecting community impact creates opposition and regulatory risk
- ESG investors increasingly evaluate community relat

audits.name: Cultural Preservation
audits.description:
Examines how technology products affect cultural diversity,
heritage preservation, and traditional knowledge, assessing:

- Cultural content digitization and preservation
- Indigenous knowledge protection and respect
- Cultural appropriation in AI training data
- Platform effects on cultural homogenization
- Local cultural expression support
- Traditional knowledge IP protection
- Cultural heritage accessibility
audits.why_it_matters:
Technology can either preserve or erode cultural diversity:
- Dominant language bias marginalizes minority cultures
- AI trained on biased data perpetuates cultural stereotypes
- Platform algorithms favor mainstream over diverse content
- Traditional knowledge can be exploited without consent
- Digital preservation can save endangered cultural heritage
- Technology enables cultural exchange and education
- Cultural diversity drives innovation and resilience
- UNESCO and indigenous rights framewo

audits.name: Democratic Participation
audits.description:
Examines how technology products and platforms affect democratic
processes and civic participation, assessing:
- Election integrity measures and policies
- Political advertising transparency
- Voter information and civic education tools
- Protection against foreign influence operations
- Government request handling and transparency
- Political speech and content policies
- Civic data access and protection
- Support for democratic institutions
audits.why_it_matters:
Technology platforms have become critical infrastructure for
democratic participation:
- Social media is a primary source of political information
- Platforms can be weaponized for election interference
- Political ad targeting can manipulate or suppress voters
- Misinformation undermines informed democratic participation
- Government pressure on platforms can threaten free expression
- Civic data misuse can compromise democratic processes
- Algorithmic filter bubbles can polarize political disc

audits.name: Employment Impact
audits.description:
Examines the impact of technology and organizational practices on
employment and worker welfare, assessing:

- Gig economy and contractor labor practices
- Worker monitoring and algorithmic management
- Reskilling and transition support programs
- Supply chain labor conditions
- Content moderator welfare
- Remote work and work-life balance policies
- Employment diversity and equity
audits.why_it_matters:
Technology companies have significant influence on employment patterns

- Gig economy classification affects worker benefits and protections
- Algorithmic management can create oppressive working conditions
- Content moderation work causes psychological harm without support
- Supply chain labor abuses reflect on companies using those suppliers
- Employment practices set industry standards affecting millions

audits.name: Knowledge Access
audits.description:
Examines how technology products affect access to knowledge,
information, and educational resources, assessing:
- Educational content accessibility
- Academic and research resource availability
- Paywalls and knowledge gatekeeping
- Open access and open educational resources support
- Information accessibility for diverse learners
- Research data sharing and openness
- Digital library and archive features
- Scientific communication support
audits.why_it_matters:
Access to knowledge is foundational to human development and
opportunity:

- Paywalled research limits scientific progress
- Educational barriers affect economic mobility
- Open access accelerates innovation and discovery
- Accessible knowledge supports lifelong learning
- Information access is recognized as a human right
- Technology can democratize or restrict knowledge access
- SDG 4 (Quality Education) depends on accessible resources

audits.name: Open Source Contribution
audits.description:

- Responsible disclosure of dependencies

Open source is foundational to modern technology, and organizational

- Open source contributions attract and retain engineering talent

- Abandoned dependencies create security and sustainability risks
- Supporting maintainers ensures ecosystem health
- Open standards prevent vendor lock-in for users
- ESG and corporate responsibility frameworks include open s

audits.name: Carbon Footprint
audits.description:
Evaluates the carbon emissions impact of software systems including compute
resources, data storage, network transfers, and end-user device energy.
Quantifies emissions from infrastructure choices, usage patterns, and
growth projections. Assesses carbon measurement practices, reduction
strategies, and offsetting approaches.
audits.why_it_matters:
IT represents 2-4% of global carbon emissions and growing. Regulatory
pressure increases - EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD)
requires emissions disclosure. Investors and customers increasingly demand
carbon transparency. Digital services have real environmental impact that
responsible organizations must measure and reduce. Early carbon management
creates competitive advantage.

audits.name: E-Waste Consideration
audits.description:
Evaluates software design decisions that impact electronic waste including
device compatibility, performance requirements, update policies, and
backward compatibility. Assesses whether software contributes to premature
device obsolescence or supports device longevity. Reviews support for
older devices, lite versions, and progressive enhancement.
audits.why_it_matters:
E-waste is one of the fastest growing waste streams globally. Software
bloat and aggressive update requirements force hardware replacement
prematurely. Supporting older devices extends their useful life and
reduces e-waste. EU regulations increasingly mandate repairability and
longevity. Designing for device longevity also expands addressable market
to users with older devices.

audits.name: Energy Efficiency
audits.description:
Evaluates energy efficiency of software systems including compute
utilization, resource provisioning, code efficiency, caching strategies,
and idle resource management. Assesses both infrastructure efficiency
(PUE, right-sizing) and software efficiency (algorithmic optimization,
efficient data structures). Reviews energy-aware scheduling and
demand shaping.
audits.why_it_matters:
Energy efficiency directly impacts operating costs, carbon emissions,
and environmental sustainability. Inefficient systems waste energy on
idle resources, unnecessary computation, and poor utilization. With
rising energy costs and carbon regulations, efficiency is increasingly
strategic. Efficient software also performs better, creating win-win
for sustainability and user experience.

audits.name: Green Coding Practice
audits.description:
Evaluates software development practices for environmental efficiency
including algorithmic efficiency, dependency management, asset optimization,
data transfer minimization, and sustainable CI/CD practices. Assesses
adherence to green software principles and patterns that reduce the
energy footprint of software execution.
audits.why_it_matters:
Code efficiency directly impacts energy consumption. Inefficient algorithms,
bloated dependencies, and unoptimized assets waste compute cycles and
bandwidth. While individual optimizations seem small, at scale they
significantly impact carbon footprint. Green coding also improves
performance and reduces costs, creating multiple benefits.

audits.name: Renewable Energy Usage
audits.description:
Evaluates renewable energy usage across infrastructure including cloud
providers' renewable energy procurement, office energy sourcing, and
opportunities for carbon-aware computing. Assesses alignment with
science-based targets and renewable energy certificates (RECs).
audits.why_it_matters:
Renewable energy directly reduces Scope 2 emissions. Cloud providers
increasingly offer carbon-free energy options, and choosing appropriately
powered regions can significantly reduce carbon footprint. Stakeholders
expect transparency about energy sourcing. Science-based targets typically
require increasing renewable energy percentage over time.

audits.name: Sustainable Hosting
audits.description:
Evaluates hosting infrastructure for environmental sustainability
including cloud provider renewable energy commitments, region-specific
energy mix, data center efficiency (PUE), and provider sustainability
practices. Assesses hosting decisions against carbon intensity data
and available sustainable alternatives.
audits.why_it_matters:
Hosting provider and region selection significantly impact carbon footprint.
Major cloud providers have varying renewable energy commitments and regional
energy mixes differ substantially. Choosing sustainable hosting is one of
the most impactful decisions for digital sustainability. Provider transparency
and commitments also affect ability to report accurate Scope 3 emissions.

audits.name: Algorithm Disclosure
audits.description:
Examines transparency around algorithmic systems that affect
user experience, assessing:
- Disclosure of AI/ML system presence and purpose
- Explanation of recommendation/ranking algorithms
- Automated decision-making transparency
- Personalization and profiling disclosure
- Algorithm impact on content visibility
- User control over algorithmic preferences
- Explanation of algorithmic outcomes
- Right to human review disclosure
audits.why_it_matters:
Algorithmic transparency is increasingly a regulatory and ethical
imperative:
- GDPR Article 22 requires disclosure of automated decision-making
- EU AI Act mandates transparency for high-risk AI systems
- DSA requires disclosure of recommendation systems
- Users cannot contest unfair algorithmic decisions they don't understand
- Hidden algorithmic manipulation erodes trust
- Algorithmic bias cannot be addressed without transparency
- Platform accountability requires algorithmic visibility

audits.name: Content Moderation Transparency
audits.description:
Examines transparency in content moderation systems, assessing:
- Community guidelines/content policy clarity
- Enforcement action explanations
- Appeal process availability and fairness
- Transparency reporting (removal statistics)
- Automated moderation disclosure
- Consistency of enforcement
- Notice to affected users
- Government/legal request handling
audits.why_it_matters:
Content moderation affects free expression and user trust,
making transparency essential:

- Users cannot comply with unclear rules
- Unexplained removals feel arbitrary and unfair
- Appeal processes enable correction of errors
- Transparency reports enable accountability
- Automated moderation can have high error rates
- Trust requires understanding how rules are applied

Transparent content moderation balances safety with fairness
and demonstr

audits.name: Data Practice Transparency
audits.description:
Examines how clearly and completely data practices are communicated
to users, assessing:
- Privacy policy clarity and completeness
- Just-in-time data collection notices
- Third-party data sharing disclosures
- Data retention period communication
- User control and preference options
- Cookie and tracking disclosures
- Data breach notification practices
- Data subject rights communication
audits.why_it_matters:
Users have a right to understand how their data is used, and
regulations increasingly mandate transparent disclosure:
- GDPR requires clear, plain language privacy notices
- CCPA mandates disclosure of data sales and sharing
- Hidden data practices erode trust when discovered
- Data breaches are more damaging without prior transparency
- Users cannot exercise rights they don't know they have
- Regulatory fines for inadequate disclosure can be substantial

Transparent data practices build user tr

audits.name: Pricing Transparency
audits.description:
Examines the transparency and clarity of pricing communications,
assessing:
- Visibility of all costs before purchase
- Clarity of recurring billing terms
- Disclosure of fees and surcharges
- Free trial terms and conversion to paid
- Cancellation and refund policies
- Price increase notification practices
- Comparison to advertised prices
- Currency and regional pricing clarity
audits.why_it_matters:
Opaque pricing practices harm consumers and create legal/reputational
risks for businesses:
- Hidden fees are a leading cause of consumer complaints
- FTC and regulators actively target "drip pricing" and dark patterns
- Unexpected charges lead to chargebacks and customer loss
- Trust erosion spreads through reviews and social media
- Class action lawsuits target misleading price advertising
- Consumer protection laws require clear price disclosure

Transparent pricing builds customer trust, red

audits.name: Terms of Service Clarity
audits.description:
Assesses the clarity and accessibility of Terms of Service (ToS),
privacy policies, and related legal agreements, examining:
- Reading level and plain language usage
- Document length and structure
- Summary or highlight availability
- Key terms prominence (data use, liability, termination)
- Version history and change notification practices
- Accessibility of documents (format, findability)
- Translations available for supported languages
- Clarity of user rights and recourse options
audits.why_it_matters:
Complex, lengthy legal documents that users cannot understand
create significant ethical and practical problems:
- Users cannot give truly informed consent
- Hidden terms can lead to user harm and erode trust
- Regulators increasingly require plain language disclosures
- Class action lawsuits target unclear or misleading terms
- User trust decreases when agreements feel like traps
- GDPR and other regulations require accessible privacy notices

Clear, understandable terms build user trust and de

audits.name: Accessibility Statement Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates accessibility statements and conformance documentation
including:
- Statement completeness and accuracy
- Conformance level claims verification
- Known limitations disclosure
- Feedback mechanism availability
- Contact information for accessibility issues
- Alternative access information
- Remediation timeline commitments
- Compliance with statement requirements (EU, ADA, etc.)
audits.why_it_matters:
Accessibility statements serve multiple important purposes:
- Legal requirement in EU (Web Accessibility Directive)
- Demonstrates good faith effort under ADA
- Sets user expectations for accessibility support
- Provides accountability for accessibility commitments
- Reduces legal risk through transparency
- Enables users to request accommodations
- Documents compliance status for auditors
Inaccurate or missing statements increase legal exposure.

audits.name: ADA Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance with Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)
requirements for digital properties including:
- Title III public accommodation requirements
- Effective communication obligations
- Auxiliary aids and services
- WCAG conformance as ADA standard
- Mobile application accessibility
- Third-party content accessibility
- Alternative access methods
- Complaint and accommodation processes
audits.why_it_matters:
ADA compliance is a federal legal requirement in the United States.
Non-compliance results in:
- Federal civil rights lawsuits (over 4,500 filed annually)
- DOJ enforcement actions
- Demand letters (averaging $10,000-25,000 to settle)
- Class action lawsuits (multi-million dollar exposure)
- Injunctive relief requiring remediation
- Consent decrees with ongoing monitoring
- Reputational harm and negative publicity
- Exclusion of 61 million Americans with disabilities

audits.name: EN 301 549 Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance with EN 301 549, the European standard for
ICT accessibility, including:
- Web accessibility (WCAG 2.1 Level AA incorporated)
- Non-web software accessibility requirements
- Hardware with ICT capabilities
- Documentation and support services
- Two-way voice communication
- Video capabilities
- Authoring tools
- European Accessibility Act alignment
audits.why_it_matters:
EN 301 549 compliance is required for:
- EU public procurement of ICT products
- European Accessibility Act obligations (2025)
- CE marking for certain ICT products
Non-compliance results in:
- Exclusion from EU public sector market
- Regulatory penalties under European Accessibility Act
- Loss of CE marking eligibility
- Competitive disadvantage in European market
- Legal liability in EU member states
- Market access restrictions

audits.name: Section 508 Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance with Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act
including:
- Revised 508 Standards (WCAG 2.0 Level A and AA)
- Electronic document accessibility (PDF, Word, etc.)
- Software and operating system accessibility
- Hardware with embedded software
- Support documentation and services
- Functional performance criteria
- Voluntary Product Accessibility Template (VPAT) accuracy
- Accessibility Conformance Report (ACR) requirements
audits.why_it_matters:
Section 508 compliance is legally required for:
- Federal agencies and their contractors
- Organizations receiving federal funding
- Companies selling to federal government
Non-compliance results in:
- Loss of federal contracts (billions in market opportunity)
- Procurement rejection
- Federal agency complaints and investigations
- Requirement to remediate before contract award
- Competitive disadvantage in federal market
- Administrative complaints to agency CIOs

audits.name: WCAG Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance with Web Content Accessibility Guidelines
(WCAG) including:
- Perceivable content (text alternatives, captions, adaptable content)
- Operable interfaces (keyboard accessibility, timing, navigation)
- Understandable content (readable, predictable, input assistance)
- Robust implementation (compatibility with assistive technologies)
- WCAG 2.1 Level A, AA, and AAA success criteria
- Mobile accessibility considerations
- PDF and document accessibility
audits.why_it_matters:
WCAG compliance is both a legal requirement and ethical imperative.
Non-compliance results in:
- Legal liability under ADA, Section 508, and international laws
- Lawsuits and settlement costs (averaging $75K-150K)
- Exclusion of users with disabilities (15-20% of population)
- Lost market opportunity
- Reputational damage
- SEO penalties (accessibility affects search ranking)
- Government contract ineligibility

audits.name: Access Log Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates access logging coverage and quality for authentication events,
authorization decisions, and resource access. Reviews logging of successful
and failed access attempts, user identification, source attribution, and
access context. Assesses compliance with access logging requirements across
regulatory frameworks.
audits.why_it_matters:
Access logs are essential for detecting unauthorized access, investigating
security incidents, and demonstrating compliance. They enable identification
of compromised accounts, privilege abuse, and policy violations. Without
comprehensive access logging, organizations cannot detect or investigate
unauthorized access to systems and data.

audits.name: Audit Log Completeness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates audit logging coverage to ensure all security-relevant events
are captured. Reviews authentication events, authorization decisions,
data access, administrative actions, system events, and application-level
activity. Assesses log content completeness including timestamps, user
identity, source IP, and event details.
audits.why_it_matters:
Comprehensive audit logs are essential for security monitoring, incident
investigation, and compliance evidence. Incomplete logging creates blind
spots where malicious activity goes undetected. Regulatory frameworks
(SOC 2, PCI-DSS, HIPAA, GDPR) require comprehensive audit trails.
Insufficient logging makes incident investigation impossible and may
result in regulatory findings.

audits.name: Audit Log Integrity Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates audit log integrity protections including access controls on
log storage, tamper detection mechanisms, write-once storage, centralized
collection, and chain of custody. Reviews protection against modification,
deletion, and unauthorized access by administrators or attackers.
audits.why_it_matters:
Audit logs are only valuable if their integrity can be trusted. Attackers
routinely attempt to delete or modify logs to cover their tracks. Insider
threats may alter logs to hide unauthorized activity. Compliance frameworks
require log integrity protection. Tampered logs cannot support forensic
investigation or legal proceedings.

audits.name: Audit Log Monitoring Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates monitoring and analysis of audit logs for security events
including SIEM integration, alerting rules, anomaly detection, review
procedures, and incident correlation. Reviews coverage of security-relevant
events and timeliness of detection and response.
audits.why_it_matters:
Logs are only valuable if monitored. Unmonitored logs provide historical
record but no real-time protection. Compliance frameworks require log
review and monitoring. Security monitoring enables detection of threats
before they cause damage. Without monitoring, attacks succeed undetected.

audits.name: Audit Log Retention Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates audit log retention policies against regulatory requirements
and operational needs. Reviews retention periods for different log types,
automated archival processes, storage capacity planning, and retrieval
capabilities. Assesses compliance with PCI-DSS (1 year), SOC 2, HIPAA
(6 years), and other framework requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Regulatory frameworks mandate specific log retention periods: PCI-DSS
requires 1 year with 3 months immediately available, HIPAA requires
6 years, SOX requires 7 years. Insufficient retention prevents
investigation of past incidents and compliance evidence. Excessive
retention increases storage costs and breach exposure.

audits.name: Change Audit Trail Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates audit trail for system changes including configuration
modifications, code deployments, infrastructure changes, and data
modifications. Reviews change attribution, before/after state capture,
approval workflow logging, and rollback capability. Assesses compliance
with change management audit requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Change audit trails are essential for troubleshooting, security
investigation, and compliance. Unauthorized changes can introduce
vulnerabilities or cause outages. Without change logging, root cause
analysis is impossible. Compliance frameworks require documented change
management with audit trails.

audits.name: CCPA Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of CCPA/CPRA compliance including consumer rights
implementation (right to know, delete, opt-out, correct, limit), privacy
notice requirements, service provider agreements, "Do Not Sell/Share"
mechanisms, and data minimization requirements. Includes assessment of
sensitive personal information handling under CPRA.
audits.why_it_matters:
CCPA/CPRA applies to businesses meeting threshold criteria that collect
California residents' personal information. Non-compliance exposes organizations
to enforcement actions by the California Privacy Protection Agency (CPPA),
civil penalties up to $7,500 per intentional violation, and private right
of action for data breaches. California sets privacy standards often
adopted by other states.

audits.name: Cross-Border Data Transfer Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates international data transfers against legal requirements including
adequacy decisions, Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs), Binding Corporate
Rules (BCRs), and derogations. Assesses transfer impact assessments (TIAs),
supplementary measures, and ongoing compliance monitoring. Post-Schrems II
focus on government access risks and encryption requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Post-Schrems II, international data transfers face heightened scrutiny.
Transfers without valid legal basis are unlawful and may result in
enforcement action, processing bans, and fines. Organizations must assess
third-country government access risks and implement supplementary measures.
Invalid transfers undermine entire data protection compliance programs.

audits.name: Data Breach Notification Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates organizational capability to detect, assess, contain, and
report data breaches within regulatory timeframes. Reviews incident
response procedures, breach assessment criteria, notification templates,
communication channels, and documentation practices. Covers GDPR 72-hour,
CCPA, state breach notification laws, and sector-specific requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Data breach notification is a regulatory requirement under GDPR (72 hours),
CCPA, HIPAA (60 days), and numerous state laws. Failure to notify timely
results in significant penalties, regulatory scrutiny, and reputational
damage. Effective breach response minimizes harm to affected individuals
and demonstrates organizational accountability.

audits.name: Data Processing Agreement Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates data processing agreements (DPAs) with third-party processors
for compliance with GDPR Article 28 mandatory clauses, CCPA service provider
requirements, and industry best practices. Reviews subject matter, duration,
nature and purpose of processing, data types, controller instructions,
security measures, sub-processor management, and audit rights.
audits.why_it_matters:
Controllers remain responsible for processor compliance. Invalid or
incomplete DPAs expose organizations to liability for processor failures.
GDPR Article 28 mandates specific contractual elements; absence renders
processing unlawful. DPA deficiencies are common audit findings and
enforcement targets.

audits.name: Data Retention Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates data retention policies, schedules, and technical implementation
against regulatory requirements and data minimization principles. Reviews
retention period justifications, automated purging mechanisms, legal holds,
backup retention, and compliance with sector-specific retention requirements.
Assesses both over-retention (privacy risk) and under-retention (legal risk).
audits.why_it_matters:
GDPR storage limitation principle (Article 5(1)(e)) requires data kept no
longer than necessary. Over-retention increases breach impact and may violate
minimization requirements. Under-retention risks non-compliance with legal
holds, tax records, and sector-specific requirements. Proper retention
balances privacy protection with legal obligations.

audits.name: GDPR Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of GDPR compliance including lawful bases for
processing, data subject rights implementation, data protection impact
assessments, records of processing activities, international data transfers,
breach notification procedures, and organizational measures. Reviews both
technical implementations and governance frameworks.
audits.why_it_matters:
GDPR non-compliance exposes organizations to significant financial penalties
(up to 4% of global annual turnover or EUR 20 million), reputational damage,
and enforcement actions including processing bans. GDPR applies to any
organization processing EU residents' data, regardless of location. Compliance
demonstrates respect for fundamental privacy rights.

audits.name: Audit Readiness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates organizational readiness for external audits including:
- Documentation completeness and accessibility
- Evidence collection and retention processes
- Control testing status and remediation tracking
- Audit trail availability and integrity
- Key personnel availability and preparation
- Prior finding remediation status
- Walkthrough readiness
- Request list preparation capability
audits.why_it_matters:
Audit readiness directly impacts audit efficiency and outcomes.
Poor preparation results in:
- Extended audit timelines and increased fees
- Greater likelihood of findings and qualifications
- Management distraction during busy periods
- Potential scope expansion due to missing evidence
- Reputation impact with auditors and regulators
- Delayed financial reporting
- Increased risk of material weakness identification

audits.name: Financial Data Integrity Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates controls ensuring financial data integrity including:
- Input validation and data quality controls
- Processing integrity controls
- Output reconciliation procedures
- Data completeness verification
- Interface and integration controls
- Error handling and correction processes
- Data transformation accuracy
- Master data management controls
audits.why_it_matters:
Financial data integrity is fundamental to reliable financial
reporting. Data integrity failures can result in:
- Material misstatements in financial reports
- Regulatory enforcement and restatements
- Audit qualifications and increased scrutiny
- Investor lawsuits and loss of confidence
- Operational decisions based on incorrect data
- SOX material weaknesses
- Fraud facilitation through undetected manipulation

audits.name: Financial Reporting Accuracy Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates accuracy of financial reporting including:
- Calculation accuracy in financial systems
- Report generation and consolidation processes
- Disclosure completeness and accuracy
- Automated vs. manual report elements
- Period close and cutoff procedures
- Journal entry controls
- Financial statement presentation
- Footnote and disclosure generation
audits.why_it_matters:
Financial reporting accuracy is essential for investor decisions,
regulatory compliance, and organizational credibility. Inaccuracies
result in:
- Material misstatements requiring restatement
- SEC enforcement and penalties
- Audit qualifications and increased scrutiny
- Shareholder lawsuits
- Executive personal liability
- Loss of market confidence
- Damage to company reputation

audits.name: Segregation of Duties Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates segregation of duties (SoD) controls including:
- Incompatible duty identification and separation
- Role-based access control alignment with SoD
- Conflict detection in user access
- Emergency and privileged access controls
- Compensating controls for unavoidable conflicts
- SoD violation monitoring and reporting
- System-enforced vs. manually monitored controls
- Cross-functional process segregation
audits.why_it_matters:
Segregation of duties is a fundamental internal control that
prevents single individuals from controlling entire processes.
SoD failures enable:
- Fraud through undetected manipulation
- Errors propagating without review
- Asset misappropriation
- Financial statement manipulation
- SOX material weaknesses
- Audit findings and qualifications
- Regulatory sanctions

audits.name: SOX Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates Sarbanes-Oxley Act compliance for IT systems that support
financial reporting, including:
- Internal control over financial reporting (ICFR)
- Access controls for financial systems
- Audit trail completeness and integrity
- Change management for financial applications
- Data integrity controls
- Segregation of duties enforcement
- Management assessment and certification readiness
- External auditor requirements alignment
audits.why_it_matters:
SOX compliance is mandatory for publicly traded companies in the US.
Section 404 requires management to assess and report on internal
controls over financial reporting. Non-compliance can result in:
- Material weakness disclosures affecting stock price
- Personal liability for executives (CEO/CFO certification)
- SEC enforcement actions and penalties
- Loss of investor confidence
- Restatement of financial statements
- Criminal penalties for willful violations
IT controls are foundational to fin

audits.name: FedRAMP Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of FedRAMP compliance for cloud service providers
seeking authorization to serve federal agencies. Reviews compliance with
NIST SP 800-53 controls at Low, Moderate, or High impact levels. Assesses
System Security Plan (SSP), Security Assessment Plan (SAP), continuous
monitoring, and Plan of Action and Milestones (POA&M).
audits.why_it_matters:
FedRAMP authorization is required for cloud services used by federal
agencies. Authorization opens significant government market opportunity
estimated at $40+ billion annually. Without authorization, cloud providers
cannot sell to federal customers. FedRAMP demonstrates rigorous security
practices exceeding commercial standards.

audits.name: HIPAA Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of HIPAA compliance including Privacy Rule,
Security Rule, and Breach Notification Rule requirements. Reviews
administrative, physical, and technical safeguards for protected health
information (PHI). Assesses risk analysis, policies, training, business
associate agreements, and incident response procedures.
audits.why_it_matters:
HIPAA compliance is mandatory for covered entities and business associates
handling PHI. Violations result in substantial penalties (up to $1.9M per
violation category annually), criminal prosecution for knowing violations,
and OCR enforcement actions. Breaches require notification and trigger
investigations. PHI exposure causes significant patient harm and
organizational reputational damage.

audits.name: ISO 27001 Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of Information Security Management System (ISMS)
against ISO/IEC 27001:2022 requirements. Reviews ISMS documentation, risk
assessment methodology, Statement of Applicability, control implementation,
management review, internal audits, and continual improvement processes.
Assesses readiness for ISO 27001 certification audit.
audits.why_it_matters:
ISO 27001 is the international standard for information security management.
Certification demonstrates systematic approach to managing sensitive
information. Increasingly required by enterprise customers, government
contracts, and regulatory frameworks. Provides competitive advantage and
insurance premium reductions. Drives security culture and operational
maturity.

audits.name: NIST Framework Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of cybersecurity practices against the NIST
Cybersecurity Framework (CSF) 2.0 core functions: Govern, Identify,
Protect, Detect, Respond, and Recover. Assesses current profile,
target profile, and maturity across framework categories and
subcategories. Maps to NIST SP 800-53 controls where applicable.
audits.why_it_matters:
NIST CSF is the most widely adopted cybersecurity framework in the US,
used across critical infrastructure sectors and private industry.
Executive Order 13800 requires federal agencies to use CSF. Framework
provides common language for security discussions and enables risk-based
decision making. Adoption demonstrates security maturity to customers
and insurers.

audits.name: PCI-DSS Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of PCI-DSS v4.0 compliance for organizations
storing, processing, or transmitting cardholder data. Reviews all 12
requirements including network security, access control, vulnerability
management, encryption, monitoring, and security policies. Assesses
cardholder data environment (CDE) scope, data flows, and control
implementation.
audits.why_it_matters:
PCI-DSS compliance is mandatory for organizations handling payment card
data. Non-compliance results in fines from payment brands (up to $500,000
per incident), increased transaction fees, and potential loss of card
processing privileges. Data breaches involving card data trigger
mandatory forensic investigations and brand liability. Compliance
protects both organization and cardholders.

audits.name: SOC 2 Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates organizational controls against SOC 2 Trust Services Criteria (TSC)
including Security (common criteria), Availability, Processing Integrity,
Confidentiality, and Privacy principles. Reviews control design, implementation,
and operating effectiveness. Assesses readiness for SOC 2 Type I or Type II
examination by independent auditors.
audits.why_it_matters:
SOC 2 is the primary trust framework for service organizations, particularly
SaaS providers. Enterprise customers increasingly require SOC 2 reports as
prerequisite for vendor selection. SOC 2 demonstrates commitment to security
and operational excellence. Lack of SOC 2 may exclude organizations from
enterprise sales opportunities.

audits.name: Export Control Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance with export control regulations including US
Export Administration Regulations (EAR), International Traffic in
Arms Regulations (ITAR), sanctions (OFAC), and foreign national
access restrictions. Reviews product classification, license
requirements, and compliance processes.
audits.why_it_matters:
Export control violations carry severe penalties including criminal
prosecution, massive fines, debarment from government contracts, and
loss of export privileges. Applies to technology transfers including
software, encryption, and deemed exports to foreign nationals.
Increasing enforcement against both intentional and negligent violations.

audits.name: Intellectual Property Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates intellectual property management including ownership of
developed IP, employee/contractor IP assignments, third-party IP usage,
patent and trademark considerations, and infringement risk. Reviews
IP policies, agreements, and protection measures.
audits.why_it_matters:
Unclear IP ownership can jeopardize company valuation, investor
relationships, and M&A transactions. Using third-party IP without
proper rights exposes to infringement claims. Failure to protect
proprietary IP allows competitors to copy innovations. IP issues
are common blockers in due diligence.

audits.name: Legal Hold Capability Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates organizational capability to implement and manage legal holds
for litigation, regulatory investigation, or audit. Reviews preservation
processes, technical hold mechanisms, custodian management, documentation,
and ability to suspend routine deletion. Assesses compliance with
e-discovery obligations.
audits.why_it_matters:
Failure to preserve relevant data when litigation is reasonably anticipated
constitutes spoliation, resulting in severe sanctions including adverse
inference instructions, monetary penalties, and case dismissal. Courts
increasingly hold organizations to strict preservation standards.
Inadequate legal hold capability exposes organization to catastrophic
litigation consequences.

audits.name: Open Source License Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates open source license compliance across all dependencies and
incorporated code. Reviews license identification, compatibility analysis,
attribution requirements, copyleft obligations (GPL, LGPL, AGPL), and
license policy enforcement. Assesses SBOM generation and license tracking
processes.
audits.why_it_matters:
Open source license violations expose organizations to litigation,
injunctions, forced source disclosure, and reputational damage. GPL/AGPL
copyleft licenses can require releasing proprietary code. Attribution
failures violate even permissive licenses. Increasing enforcement by
license compliance organizations and courts.

audits.name: Software License Management Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates commercial software license management including license
inventory, entitlement tracking, compliance monitoring, renewal
management, and cost optimization. Reviews license procurement
processes, usage tracking, and audit readiness for major vendors
(Microsoft, Oracle, SAP, etc.).
audits.why_it_matters:
Software license non-compliance exposes organizations to vendor audits,
true-up costs, and legal action. Major vendors actively audit customers
with significant financial penalties for under-licensing. Over-licensing
wastes significant budget. Effective license management ensures
compliance while optimizing costs.

audits.name: Terms Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance with terms of service and acceptable use policies
for third-party services including cloud providers, SaaS platforms, APIs,
and data providers. Reviews usage against contractual limitations,
prohibited uses, and data handling requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Terms of service violations can result in service termination, legal
action, and data loss. Cloud providers and API services actively enforce
terms with account suspension. Non-compliance with data terms may
expose organization to third-party liability. Understanding and following
terms protects service continuity and legal standing.

audits.name: Governance Structure Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates governance structure including:
- Board and committee oversight
- Three lines of defense model
- Reporting structures and escalation
- Role clarity and accountability
- Decision-making authority
- Governance committee effectiveness
- Independence and conflicts of interest
- Integration with enterprise risk management
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective governance structure is foundational to compliance.
Weak governance results in:
- Lack of accountability for compliance
- Insufficient oversight of risk
- Regulatory findings about governance failures
- Ineffective escalation of issues
- Compliance function marginalization
- Board liability for oversight failures
- Culture of non-compliance
- Strategic misalignment of compliance program
Strong governance enables effective compliance.

audits.name: Policy Documentation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates policy documentation including:
- Policy completeness against regulatory requirements
- Policy clarity and readability
- Policy structure and organization
- Alignment between policies and procedures
- Policy accessibility and distribution
- Version control and approval documentation
- Policy hierarchy (policies, standards, procedures)
- Gap analysis against frameworks
audits.why_it_matters:
Policies are the foundation of governance and compliance.
Poor policy documentation results in:
- Regulatory findings for missing required policies
- Inconsistent behavior from unclear guidance
- Audit failures for inadequate documentation
- Legal exposure from missing policies
- Employee confusion about expectations
- Inability to enforce non-existent policies
- Compliance program foundation weakness
Clear, complete policies enable effective compliance.

audits.name: Policy Enforcement Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates policy enforcement including:
- Technical enforcement mechanisms
- Administrative enforcement procedures
- Violation detection capabilities
- Consequence management
- Enforcement consistency
- Policy compliance monitoring
- Awareness and acknowledgment tracking
- Exception handling vs. violations
audits.why_it_matters:
Policies without enforcement are merely suggestions.
Weak enforcement results in:
- Policy violations with no consequences
- Culture of non-compliance
- Regulatory findings for ineffective policies
- Inconsistent application creating legal exposure
- Erosion of governance credibility
- Competitive disadvantage to compliant competitors
- Inability to hold employees accountable
Effective enforcement makes policies meaningful.

audits.name: Policy Review Cycle Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates policy lifecycle management including:
- Review schedule and frequency
- Review process and participants
- Update triggers and change management
- Approval workflow for changes
- Communication of policy changes
- Policy retirement process
- Version control and history
- Integration with regulatory changes
audits.why_it_matters:
Policies require regular review to remain effective.
Poor lifecycle management leads to:
- Outdated policies providing wrong guidance
- Non-compliance with changed regulations
- Accumulated policy debt
- Conflicting or redundant policies
- Audit findings for stale policies
- Inability to respond to changing risks
- Erosion of policy program credibility
Active lifecycle management keeps policies relevant.

audits.name: Compliance Certification Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance certification processes including:
- Third-party certification status (ISO, SOC, etc.)
- Internal compliance attestation processes
- Management certification requirements
- Certification scope and coverage
- Audit and assessment schedules
- Finding remediation tracking
- Certification renewal planning
- Customer certification requirements
audits.why_it_matters:
Compliance certifications provide independent verification of
compliance status. Certification failures result in:
- Loss of customer confidence and contracts
- Inability to compete for certification-requiring contracts
- Regulatory concerns about compliance program
- Gap in third-party validation
- Market access restrictions
- Public disclosure of certification failures
- Increased audit and assessment scrutiny
Many customers and regulations require certifications.

audits.name: Compliance Documentation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance documentation including:
- Policy and procedure documentation completeness
- Regulatory requirement mapping
- Evidence collection and retention
- Document version control and currency
- Accessibility and organization of records
- Audit trail documentation
- Compliance attestation records
- Third-party compliance documentation
audits.why_it_matters:
Compliance documentation is essential for demonstrating regulatory
compliance. Documentation failures result in:
- Inability to demonstrate compliance during audits
- Regulatory findings and enforcement actions
- Failed certification and attestation processes
- Increased audit scope and costs
- Legal discovery disadvantages
- Knowledge loss during staff turnover
- Inconsistent compliance practices
"If it isn't documented, it didn't happen" applies to compliance.

audits.name: Compliance Training Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance training programs including:
- Training content coverage and currency
