- Training completion rates and tracking
- Training effectiveness assessment
- Role-based training requirements
- New hire and ongoing training programs
- Regulatory-specific training requirements
- Training documentation and records
- Remedial training processes
audits.why_it_matters:
Compliance training is essential for ensuring employees understand
and can fulfill their compliance obligations. Training failures lead to:
- Compliance violations due to ignorance
- Regulatory findings for inadequate training
- Inability to demonstrate compliance program effectiveness
- Increased risk of misconduct
- Legal exposure from untrained employees
- Regulatory mandate violations (many require specific training)
- Culture of non-compliance
Regulators increasingly scrutinize training pro

audits.name: Regulatory Change Tracking Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates regulatory change management including:
- Regulatory monitoring and horizon scanning
- Change identification and assessment processes
- Impact analysis methodology
- Implementation planning and tracking
- Stakeholder communication
- Compliance verification after implementation
- Documentation of regulatory changes
- Regulatory intelligence sources
audits.why_it_matters:
The regulatory landscape constantly evolves. Failure to track
and respond to changes results in:
- Non-compliance with new requirements
- Regulatory enforcement and penalties
- Competitive disadvantage vs. prepared competitors
- Rushed, error-prone implementations
- Missed implementation deadlines
- Reputational damage
- Business disruption from reactive responses
Proactive regulatory change management is essential.

audits.name: Regulatory Reporting Timeliness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates regulatory reporting timeliness including:
- Deadline tracking and management systems
- Historical on-time submission rates
- Buffer time and contingency planning
- Report preparation workflow efficiency
- Data availability for reporting
- Review and approval cycle times
- Submission confirmation processes
- Late filing tracking and root cause analysis
audits.why_it_matters:
Timely regulatory reporting is a fundamental compliance obligation.
Late filings result in:
- Regulatory fines and penalties
- Increased regulatory scrutiny
- Reputational damage with regulators
- Loss of business licenses or authorizations
- Public disclosure of late filings
- Management certification issues
- Stakeholder confidence erosion
Many regulators have zero tolerance for repeated late filings.

audits.name: Control Effectiveness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates control effectiveness including:
- Control design adequacy
- Operating effectiveness testing
- Control automation and reliability
- Key control identification
- Control documentation accuracy
- Compensating control adequacy
- Control gap identification
- Control ownership and accountability
audits.why_it_matters:
Controls are the foundation of compliance and risk management.
Ineffective controls result in:
- Compliance violations despite control existence
- Risk exposure from false sense of security
- Audit findings and material weaknesses
- Regulatory enforcement for control failures
- Operational losses from unmitigated risks
- Resource waste on controls that don't work
- Inability to rely on control assertions
Control effectiveness must be validated, not assumed.

audits.name: Control Monitoring Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates control monitoring including:
- Continuous monitoring capabilities
- Key performance indicators for controls
- Exception detection and alerting
- Dashboard and reporting effectiveness
- Monitoring coverage across control portfolio
- Automated vs. manual monitoring
- Threshold setting and calibration
- Escalation processes
audits.why_it_matters:
Point-in-time control testing is insufficient for ongoing
assurance. Inadequate monitoring results in:
- Control failures going undetected
- Delayed response to control degradation
- Compliance exposure between assessments
- Inability to demonstrate continuous compliance
- Reactive rather than proactive control management
- Audit findings for monitoring deficiencies
- Increased risk from undetected control drift
Continuous monitoring enables real-time assurance.

audits.name: Exception Management Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates exception management processes including:
- Exception request and approval workflow
- Risk acceptance criteria and documentation
- Exception tracking and expiration
- Compensating control requirements
- Exception review and renewal processes
- Trend analysis and root cause
- Escalation for high-risk exceptions
- Communication of exception status
audits.why_it_matters:
Exception management enables business flexibility while
maintaining risk awareness. Poor exception management leads to:
- Uncontrolled risk acceptance
- Exceptions that never expire (permanent gaps)
- Lack of visibility into compliance posture
- Audit findings for unmanaged exceptions
- Inconsistent risk decisions
- Shadow exceptions outside the process
- Regulatory concerns about control environment
Exceptions are acceptable; unmanaged exceptions are not.

audits.name: Remediation Tracking Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates remediation tracking processes including:
- Finding intake and prioritization
- Remediation plan development
- Owner assignment and accountability
- Progress tracking and reporting
- Deadline management and escalation
- Closure verification and evidence
- Trend analysis and root cause
- Integration with risk and audit processes
audits.why_it_matters:
Remediation tracking ensures identified issues are resolved.
Poor remediation management leads to:
- Persistent control deficiencies
- Recurring audit findings
- Regulatory criticism for open issues
- Increased risk from unaddressed vulnerabilities
- Audit findings about remediation itself
- Loss of credibility with auditors and regulators
- Compliance program ineffectiveness
Finding issues has no value without effective remediation.

audits.name: Risk Assessment Process Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates risk assessment processes including:
- Risk identification methodology
- Risk assessment and scoring criteria
- Risk appetite and tolerance alignment
- Assessment frequency and triggers
- Stakeholder involvement in assessments
- Risk documentation and communication
- Integration with control framework
- Emerging risk identification
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective risk assessment is foundational to risk management.
Poor risk assessment leads to:
- Unknown risks that materialize without mitigation
- Misallocated resources on low-priority risks
- Control gaps for unidentified risks
- Strategic decisions without risk context
- Regulatory findings for assessment deficiencies
- Compliance program ineffectiveness
- Audit focus on wrong areas
You cannot manage risks you haven't identified and assessed.

audits.name: Contract Security Clauses Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates security clauses in vendor contracts including:
- Data protection and confidentiality
- Security controls and standards
- Access management requirements
- Incident notification obligations
- Breach response responsibilities
- Audit and assessment rights
- Subcontractor security requirements
- Security certifications and attestations
- Personnel security requirements
- Security during and after termination
audits.why_it_matters:
Security clauses define vendor security obligations and recourse.
Inadequate security clauses result in:
- Unclear security expectations
- No contractual basis for security requirements
- Limited recourse for security failures
- Gaps in data protection coverage
- Delayed incident notification
- Uncontrolled subcontractor access
- Security gaps during vendor transitions
Strong security clauses protect organizational data and systems.

audits.name: Data Ownership Clauses Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates data ownership clauses in vendor contracts including:
- Data ownership definitions
- Organizational data rights
- Vendor data use restrictions
- Derivative data and insights
- Aggregated and anonymized data
- Data portability rights
- Data retention limits
- Data deletion obligations
- Cross-border data considerations
- Intellectual property in data
audits.why_it_matters:
Clear data ownership protects organizational data assets.
Unclear data ownership results in:
- Loss of control over organizational data
- Vendor claims to organizational data
- Unauthorized data monetization
- Inability to migrate data
- Compliance violations for data handling
- Intellectual property disputes
- Data held hostage during transitions
Clear data ownership clauses preserve data rights.

audits.name: Liability Provisions Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates liability provisions in vendor contracts including:
- Limitation of liability clauses
- Liability caps and carve-outs
- Indemnification obligations
- Insurance requirements
- Warranty provisions
- Consequential damages exclusions
- Mutual vs. one-sided provisions
- Survival of liability obligations
- Proportionality to contract value and risk
audits.why_it_matters:
Liability provisions define financial exposure and recourse.
Inadequate liability provisions result in:
- Unlimited organizational liability exposure
- Insufficient vendor accountability
- Unrecoverable losses from vendor failures
- Gaps in insurance coverage
- Disputes over liability allocation
- Unfavorable risk distribution
- Inadequate protection for critical risks
Appropriate liability provisions balance risk and accountability.

audits.name: SLA Definition Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates SLA definitions for completeness and enforceability:
- Service level metrics and measurements
- Performance thresholds and targets
- Measurement methodologies
- Reporting requirements
- Service credits and remedies
- Exclusions and exceptions
- Escalation procedures
- Review and adjustment mechanisms
- Alignment with business requirements
audits.why_it_matters:
Well-defined SLAs establish clear expectations and accountability.
Poor SLA definitions result in:
- Inability to measure vendor performance
- Disputes over service levels
- No recourse for poor performance
- Misalignment with business needs
- Unenforceable performance requirements
- Hidden service degradation
- Difficulty comparing vendor proposals
Clear SLAs enable effective vendor management.

audits.name: Termination Clauses Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates termination provisions in vendor contracts including:
- Termination for convenience rights
- Termination for cause provisions
- Notice periods and requirements
- Cure periods for breaches
- Transition assistance obligations
- Data return and destruction
- Post-termination access
- Survival of obligations
- Wind-down procedures
- Exit fees and penalties
audits.why_it_matters:
Termination provisions enable orderly vendor transitions.
Inadequate termination clauses result in:
- Vendor lock-in and dependency
- Costly and disruptive transitions
- Data held hostage by departing vendors
- Inability to terminate for poor performance
- Unexpected exit costs
- Service gaps during transitions
- Loss of intellectual property or data
Strong termination provisions protect business continuity.

audits.name: Vendor Contract Review Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor contracts for completeness and adequacy including:
- Contract structure and clarity
- Scope of services definition
- Pricing and payment terms
- Performance requirements
- Security and privacy obligations
- Intellectual property provisions
- Liability and indemnification
- Termination and transition provisions
- Dispute resolution mechanisms
- Compliance with organizational procurement policies
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendor contracts define the legal and operational framework for
third-party relationships. Inadequate contracts result in:
- Unclear responsibilities and expectations
- Exposure to operational and financial risk
- Limited recourse for vendor failures
- Compliance gaps in vendor relationships
- Difficulty enforcing performance requirements
- Unexpected costs and scope changes
- Challenges during vendor transitions
Thorough contract review protects organizational interests.

audits.name: Cascading Risk Assessment Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates cascading risk assessment including:
- Supply chain failure propagation
- Cascading impact analysis
- Critical path vulnerabilities
- Interdependency risk modeling
- Failure scenario planning
- Upstream risk transmission
- Downstream impact assessment
- Cross-vendor dependencies
- Systemic risk identification
- Mitigation strategy effectiveness
audits.why_it_matters:
Cascading risks amplify through supply chains exponentially.
Poor cascading risk management results in:
- Underestimated impact of vendor failures
- Surprise cascading outages
- Ineffective business continuity plans
- Unidentified critical vulnerabilities
- Systemic risk exposure
- Inadequate risk reserves
- Delayed incident response
- Cascading compliance failures
Understanding cascading risk enables proportionate controls.

audits.name: Concentration Risk Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor concentration risk including:
- Single vendor dependencies
- Shared technology providers
- Cloud platform concentration
- Geographic concentration
- Critical service single-sourcing
- Fourth-party concentration
- Industry-wide dependencies
- Financial concentration
- Exit strategy viability
- Alternative provider availability
audits.why_it_matters:
Concentration risk amplifies vendor failure impact.
Poor concentration management results in:
- Single points of failure
- Widespread outage impact
- Vendor lock-in
- Reduced negotiating leverage
- Industry-wide vulnerabilities
- Limited exit options
- Cascading failure potential
- Regulatory concentration concerns
Managed concentration limits systemic risk.

audits.name: Fourth-Party Mapping Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates fourth-party mapping including:
- Supply chain visibility depth
- Fourth-party identification methods
- Dependency mapping and documentation
- Service flow documentation
- Data flow through supply chain
- Critical path identification
- Geographic distribution
- Technology dependencies
- Shared service providers
- Supply chain visualization
audits.why_it_matters:
Fourth-party mapping provides supply chain visibility.
Without mapping, organizations face:
- Hidden dependencies creating risk
- Unknown parties with data access
- Blind spots in risk assessments
- Surprise supply chain disruptions
- Concentration risk not identified
- Compliance gaps in processing chain
- Difficulty in incident response
- Ineffective business continuity planning
Comprehensive mapping enables proactive risk management.

audits.name: Subcontractor Oversight Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates subcontractor oversight including:
- Subcontractor identification and disclosure
- Authorization and approval processes
- Contractual flow-down requirements
- Security requirements for subcontractors
- Performance monitoring of subcontractors
- Change notification processes
- Audit rights over subcontractors
- Incident reporting from subcontractors
- Geographic and jurisdictional considerations
- Subcontractor risk assessment
audits.why_it_matters:
Subcontractors extend the vendor risk chain to fourth parties.
Poor subcontractor oversight results in:
- Unknown parties accessing organizational data
- Security controls bypassed through subcontractors
- Compliance violations from unvetted parties
- No recourse for subcontractor failures
- Supply chain vulnerabilities
- Regulatory violations for unauthorized processing
- Hidden concentration risk
Effective oversight extends controls to the full supply chain.

audits.name: SLA Breach Handling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates SLA breach handling processes including:
- Breach detection mechanisms
- Escalation procedures
- Root cause analysis requirements
- Remediation tracking
- Service credit calculation
- Credit claim processes
- Vendor communication protocols
- Breach pattern analysis
- Contract enforcement actions
- Documentation requirements
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective breach handling ensures SLA accountability.
Poor breach handling results in:
- Unclaimed service credits
- Repeated breaches without improvement
- Vendor relationship deterioration
- Inadequate remediation
- Unresolved performance issues
- Loss of negotiating leverage
- Business impact without recourse
Structured breach handling protects organizational interests.

audits.name: SLA Performance Tracking Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates SLA performance tracking including:
- Performance measurement systems
- Data collection accuracy
- Metric calculation methodologies
- Reporting timeliness and accuracy
- Trend analysis capabilities
- Performance baseline management
- Alert and threshold monitoring
- Historical performance analysis
- Vendor performance comparison
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective SLA tracking enables vendor accountability.
Poor performance tracking results in:
- Undetected vendor underperformance
- Inability to enforce SLA remedies
- Disputed performance measurements
- Reactive rather than proactive management
- Inability to identify degradation trends
- Loss of service credits
- Uninformed contract decisions
Robust tracking enables evidence-based vendor management.

audits.name: SLA Reporting Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates SLA reporting processes including:
- Report content and completeness
- Reporting frequency and timeliness
- Report accuracy and validation
- Stakeholder distribution
- Executive summary effectiveness
- Trend visualization
- Anomaly highlighting
- Action item tracking
- Report automation
- Historical comparison
audits.why_it_matters:
SLA reporting drives vendor management decisions.
Poor SLA reporting results in:
- Uninformed management decisions
- Hidden performance issues
- Delayed corrective actions
- Stakeholder frustration
- Ineffective vendor reviews
- Lost organizational memory
- Compliance gaps in documentation
Effective reporting enables proactive vendor management.

audits.name: Vendor Response Time Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor response time tracking including:
- Support response time SLAs
- API/service latency requirements
- Incident response commitments
- Escalation response times
- Communication response requirements
- Time-to-resolution tracking
- Response time measurement accuracy
- Priority-based response requirements
- After-hours response commitments
audits.why_it_matters:
Response time impacts operational effectiveness and user experience.
Poor response time tracking results in:
- Undetected slow vendor responses
- Missed support SLAs
- Extended incident resolution
- Degraded user experience
- Business process delays
- Inability to enforce response commitments
- Uninformed vendor selection decisions
Accurate response tracking ensures vendor accountability.

audits.name: Vendor Uptime Monitoring Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor uptime monitoring including:
- Availability monitoring systems
- Endpoint health checks
- Service status page monitoring
- Incident detection timeliness
- Downtime tracking accuracy
- Availability calculation methods
- Historical uptime analysis
- Independent vs. vendor-reported metrics
- Multi-region monitoring coverage
audits.why_it_matters:
Uptime monitoring verifies vendor availability commitments.
Inadequate uptime monitoring results in:
- Undetected service degradation
- Disputed availability calculations
- Lost service credits
- Inability to correlate vendor outages with impact
- Reactive incident response
- Unreliable availability reporting
- Poor capacity planning decisions
Independent monitoring ensures vendor accountability.

audits.name: Dependency Vulnerability Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of dependency vulnerability management including
vulnerability scanning tools, scanning frequency, vulnerability tracking,
remediation processes, exception handling, and metrics. Reviews whether
vulnerable dependencies are identified, prioritized, and remediated
effectively.
audits.why_it_matters:
Dependencies represent a significant portion of modern software and are
frequent sources of vulnerabilities. High-profile incidents like Log4j,
Spring4Shell, and countless npm vulnerabilities demonstrate the critical
need for dependency vulnerability management. Unpatched dependencies are
a leading cause of security breaches.

audits.name: Hardware Supply Chain Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of hardware supply chain security including
vendor selection, procurement validation, chain of custody, firmware
integrity, hardware authentication, and secure decommissioning. Reviews
controls protecting against hardware tampering, counterfeiting, and
supply chain interdiction.
audits.why_it_matters:
Hardware supply chain attacks can implant persistent backdoors that
survive software reinstallation and are extremely difficult to detect.
Counterfeit components may contain vulnerabilities or fail at critical
moments. Proper hardware supply chain security ensures infrastructure
integrity from procurement through disposal.

audits.name: SBOM Management Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) practices
including generation processes, format compliance, completeness, accuracy,
distribution, and utilization for vulnerability management. Reviews whether
SBOMs effectively support software transparency and supply chain security.
audits.why_it_matters:
SBOMs provide transparency into software composition, enabling rapid
vulnerability response and supply chain risk assessment. Executive Order
14028 mandates SBOM for federal software. Without SBOMs, organizations
cannot quickly determine exposure to newly discovered vulnerabilities
like Log4j or identify all affected systems.

audits.name: Software Supply Chain Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of software supply chain security including
source code provenance, dependency management, build system integrity,
code signing, artifact verification, and distribution security. Reviews
the entire software delivery pipeline from development to deployment
for supply chain attack vectors.
audits.why_it_matters:
Software supply chain attacks have become increasingly sophisticated,
targeting dependencies, build systems, and distribution channels. High-profile
attacks like SolarWinds, Codecov, and Log4j demonstrate catastrophic impact.
Securing the software supply chain is essential to prevent compromise
propagation and maintain software integrity.

audits.name: Supplier Continuity Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of supplier continuity practices including
critical supplier identification, dependency analysis, contingency
planning, alternative supplier identification, and recovery procedures.
Reviews whether the organization can maintain operations despite
supplier disruptions or failures.
audits.why_it_matters:
Supplier disruptions can halt critical business operations, delay
projects, and cause financial losses. Single points of failure in
the supply chain create significant risk. Effective supplier continuity
planning ensures resilience against vendor outages, financial failures,
natural disasters, or geopolitical events affecting suppliers.

audits.name: Supply Chain Integrity Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of supply chain integrity controls including
artifact signing and verification, provenance attestation, integrity
checks, tamper detection, and chain of custody. Reviews whether
software and hardware integrity can be verified throughout the
supply chain.
audits.why_it_matters:
Supply chain integrity ensures that software and components have not
been tampered with between creation and deployment. Without integrity
verification, malicious modifications may go undetected. Integrity
controls are essential for preventing supply chain attacks and
maintaining trust in deployed systems.

audits.name: Third-Party Access Controls Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of third-party access controls including access
provisioning processes, least privilege implementation, access monitoring,
access certification, and timely deprovisioning. Reviews technical controls,
governance processes, and operational practices for managing vendor access
to systems and data.
audits.why_it_matters:
Third-party access represents significant attack surface expansion. Vendors
with excessive or poorly managed access can become breach vectors through
compromised credentials, insider threats, or inadequate security practices.
Strong access controls limit exposure and enable rapid response to vendor
security incidents.

audits.name: Third-Party Compliance Verification Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of third-party compliance verification processes
including certification validation, audit report review, compliance evidence
collection, ongoing monitoring, and exception management. Reviews whether
vendor compliance claims are adequately verified and maintained.
audits.why_it_matters:
Organizations often rely on vendor compliance certifications without
verification, creating false assurance. Unverified compliance claims may
be outdated, inapplicable, or fraudulent. Proper verification ensures
vendors actually meet security and regulatory requirements, supporting
organizational compliance obligations.

audits.name: Third-Party Data Handling Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of third-party data handling practices including
data classification awareness, storage locations, encryption practices,
retention compliance, data segregation, access restrictions, and secure
disposal. Reviews whether third parties adequately protect organizational
data throughout its lifecycle.
audits.why_it_matters:
Data shared with third parties remains the organization's responsibility.
Inadequate vendor data handling leads to breaches, compliance violations,
and regulatory penalties. Organizations must ensure vendors protect data
as rigorously as internal systems, particularly for sensitive or regulated
data categories.

audits.name: Third-Party Encryption Standards Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of third-party encryption standards including
encryption algorithms, key lengths, encryption at rest, encryption in
transit, key management practices, and certificate management. Reviews
whether vendors meet organizational encryption requirements for data
protection.
audits.why_it_matters:
Encryption is a critical control for protecting data shared with vendors.
Weak or absent encryption exposes data to interception and theft. Third
parties must implement encryption meeting organizational standards to
maintain security posture and comply with regulations requiring encryption
of sensitive data.

audits.name: Third-Party Incident Response Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of third-party incident response capabilities
including notification requirements, communication channels, coordination
procedures, escalation paths, and post-incident reviews. Reviews whether
vendor incidents are effectively communicated and collaboratively resolved.
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendor security incidents can directly impact organizational security and
operations. Without defined incident response coordination, organizations
may learn of vendor breaches too late to respond effectively. Clear
notification requirements and response procedures minimize incident impact
and ensure regulatory notification timelines are met.

audits.name: Third-Party Penetration Testing Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of third-party penetration testing requirements
and practices including vendor pen test requirements, evidence collection,
findings review, remediation tracking, and testing frequency. Reviews whether
vendors undergo adequate security testing and findings are appropriately
addressed.
audits.why_it_matters:
Penetration testing provides objective validation of vendor security controls
beyond self-assessments. Vendors without regular pen testing may have
undetected vulnerabilities that could expose your data or systems. Requiring
and reviewing vendor pen test results demonstrates due diligence and ensures
vendors maintain security hygiene.

audits.name: Vendor Background Check Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor background check processes including
ownership verification, business registration validation, key personnel
checks, sanctions screening, adverse media searches, and criminal history
reviews. Assesses whether due diligence adequately identifies potential
risks before vendor engagement.
audits.why_it_matters:
Engaging with vendors without proper background checks can expose
organizations to fraud, regulatory violations, reputational damage, and
security risks. Vendors may misrepresent capabilities, have undisclosed
ownership by sanctioned parties, or employ individuals with concerning
histories. Thorough background checks prevent costly mistakes.

audits.name: Vendor Capability Assessment Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor capability assessment processes
including technical capability validation, operational capacity review,
scalability assessment, expertise verification, and resource adequacy.
Reviews whether vendors can actually deliver contracted services at
required quality and scale.
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendors may overstate capabilities to win contracts, leading to
delivery failures, quality issues, and project delays. Proper
capability assessment ensures vendors can meet requirements before
engagement, preventing costly failures and relationship breakdowns.
Capability validation is especially critical for technical and
specialized services.

audits.name: Vendor Certification Verification Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor certification verification processes
including certification authenticity validation, scope verification,
expiration tracking, and ongoing monitoring. Reviews whether claimed
certifications (ISO 27001, SOC 2, PCI DSS, etc.) are valid, current,
and applicable to services provided.
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendors may claim certifications they do not possess, certifications
with expired validity, or certifications that do not cover the specific
services being provided. Relying on unverified certifications creates
false assurance about vendor security posture. Proper verification
ensures certifications provide intended assurance.

audits.name: Vendor Insurance Verification Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor insurance verification processes
including coverage requirements, certificate of insurance validation,
policy adequacy assessment, and ongoing monitoring. Reviews whether
vendor insurance appropriately transfers risk and provides adequate
protection.
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendor insurance provides financial protection against vendor-caused
incidents including data breaches, service failures, and negligence.
Without proper verification, insurance coverage may be inadequate,
expired, or fraudulent. Proper insurance verification ensures risk
transfer mechanisms are in place and functional.

audits.name: Vendor Legal Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor legal compliance including regulatory
compliance verification, contractual obligation adherence, litigation
history review, regulatory enforcement history, and compliance attestation
validation. Reviews whether vendors meet applicable legal and regulatory
requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendor legal violations can create organizational liability, regulatory
exposure, and reputational damage. Organizations may be held responsible
for vendor non-compliance with labor laws, data protection regulations,
or industry requirements. Proper legal compliance verification protects
against vicarious liability and regulatory penalties.

audits.name: Vendor Reference Check Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor reference checking processes including
reference collection, verification of reference authenticity, structured
inquiry methods, and reference analysis. Reviews whether reference checks
effectively validate vendor claims and identify potential concerns.
audits.why_it_matters:
References provide third-party validation of vendor capabilities,
reliability, and service quality. Without proper reference checks,
organizations rely solely on vendor self-representation. Structured
reference checking reveals real-world performance, potential issues,
and validates vendor claims.

audits.name: Vendor Categorization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor categorization including:
- Categorization criteria and methodology
- Risk-based tiering approach
- Criticality assessment factors
- Data access classification
- Service impact evaluation
- Financial significance thresholds
- Regulatory applicability
- Categorization consistency
- Re-categorization triggers
- Category-based requirements
audits.why_it_matters:
Categorization enables risk-based vendor management.
Poor categorization results in:
- Over-management of low-risk vendors
- Under-management of high-risk vendors
- Inconsistent vendor treatment
- Inefficient resource allocation
- Regulatory non-compliance
- Missed critical vendor risks
- Audit findings
- Inappropriate control requirements
Effective categorization focuses effort where risk is highest.

audits.name: Vendor Governance Structure Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor governance structure including:
- Governance committee and oversight
- Roles and responsibilities
- Three lines of defense model
- Reporting structures
- Decision-making authority
- Escalation procedures
- Cross-functional coordination
- Executive sponsorship
- Governance committee effectiveness
- Resource allocation
audits.why_it_matters:
Governance structure enables effective vendor management.
Weak governance structure results in:
- Unclear accountability
- Ineffective oversight
- Siloed vendor management
- Inconsistent practices
- Slow decision-making
- Unresolved escalations
- Resource constraints
- Audit findings
Strong governance ensures coordinated, effective management.

audits.name: Vendor Inventory Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor inventory including:
- Inventory completeness
- Vendor identification and classification
- Data captured for each vendor
- Risk categorization
- Contract linkage
- Owner assignment
- Service mapping
- Contact information
- Inventory maintenance processes
- System capabilities
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendor inventory is the foundation of vendor management.
Incomplete inventory results in:
- Unknown vendor relationships
- Unmanaged vendor risks
- Compliance gaps from missing vendors
- Ineffective vendor oversight
- Audit findings
- Shadow IT vendors
- Duplicate vendor relationships
- Inability to assess vendor landscape
Complete inventory enables effective vendor management.

audits.name: Vendor Management Policy Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor management policy including:
- Policy scope and applicability
- Roles and responsibilities
- Risk-based categorization requirements
- Due diligence requirements
- Contract standards
- Ongoing monitoring requirements
- Termination and exit requirements
- Compliance and reporting
- Exception processes
- Policy maintenance and review
audits.why_it_matters:
Policy establishes the foundation for vendor management.
Weak vendor management policy results in:
- Inconsistent vendor practices
- Unclear accountability
- Gaps in vendor oversight
- Compliance failures
- Unmanaged vendor risks
- Audit findings
- Regulatory enforcement
- Inefficient vendor processes
Strong policy enables consistent, effective vendor management.

audits.name: Vendor Offboarding Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor offboarding processes including:
- Access revocation procedures
- Data return and destruction
- Knowledge transfer requirements
- Transition assistance execution
- Contract close-out
- Financial settlement
- Equipment and asset return
- Documentation archival
- Security clearance termination
- Post-termination obligations
audits.why_it_matters:
Proper offboarding protects organizational assets at exit.
Poor offboarding processes result in:
- Residual access creating security risks
- Data retention by former vendors
- Knowledge loss without transfer
- Financial exposure from incomplete settlement
- Compliance violations from retained data
- Asset loss from unreturned equipment
- Difficulty with future audits
Comprehensive offboarding ensures clean relationship termination.

audits.name: Vendor Onboarding Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor onboarding processes including:
- Due diligence requirements
- Risk assessment procedures
- Security questionnaires
- Financial stability verification
- Reference checks
- Contract execution
- System access provisioning
- Integration procedures
- Training and orientation
- Documentation requirements
- Compliance verification
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective onboarding establishes vendor relationships properly.
Poor onboarding processes result in:
- Unvetted vendors accessing systems and data
- Security risks from inadequate due diligence
- Contract gaps discovered after engagement
- Integration failures and delays
- Compliance violations from missing documentation
- Relationship issues from unclear expectations
- Financial exposure from unstable vendors
Robust onboarding protects the organization from vendor risks.

audits.name: Vendor Performance Evaluation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor performance evaluation including:
- Evaluation criteria and metrics
- Balanced scorecard approach
- SLA performance weighting
- Quality assessment methods
- Cost performance analysis
- Innovation and value-add evaluation
- Risk performance assessment
- Stakeholder input gathering
- Evaluation consistency
- Performance improvement actions
audits.why_it_matters:
Performance evaluation drives vendor accountability and improvement.
Poor performance evaluation results in:
- Uninformed contract decisions
- Poor performers retained
- Top performers not recognized
- No basis for performance discussions
- Missed improvement opportunities
- Inconsistent vendor treatment
- Weak negotiating position
- Value leakage from vendor relationships
Effective evaluation enables performance-based management.

audits.name: Vendor Periodic Review Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor periodic review processes including:
- Review frequency and scheduling
- Performance assessment criteria
- Risk reassessment requirements
- Security review updates
- Financial health monitoring
- Contract compliance verification
- SLA performance analysis
- Relationship health assessment
- Issue and escalation tracking
- Documentation and follow-up
audits.why_it_matters:
Ongoing review ensures vendor relationships remain healthy.
Inadequate periodic review results in:
- Undetected performance degradation
- Changed vendor risk profiles missed
- Contract non-compliance unaddressed
- Relationship issues escalating
- Stale security assessments
- Financial instability surprises
- Missed improvement opportunities
Regular review maintains vendor accountability.

audits.name: Vendor Relationship Management Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates vendor relationship management including:
- Relationship ownership and governance
- Communication channels and frequency
- Issue escalation and resolution
- Strategic alignment assessment
- Partnership development
- Innovation collaboration
- Executive sponsorship
- Vendor satisfaction monitoring
- Continuous improvement programs
- Relationship health metrics
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective relationship management maximizes vendor value.
Poor relationship management results in:
- Transactional rather than strategic relationships
- Missed improvement opportunities
- Communication breakdowns
- Unresolved issues festering
- Vendor disengagement
- Limited innovation from vendors
- Competitive disadvantage
- Higher total cost of ownership
Strong relationships create mutual value.

audits.name: Vendor Financial Stability Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor financial stability assessment processes
including financial health indicators, credit ratings, market stability,
financial statement analysis, and ongoing monitoring. Reviews whether
financial risk is appropriately evaluated and monitored for critical vendors.
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendor financial instability can lead to service disruption, data loss,
or sudden termination of critical services. Financially distressed vendors
may cut security investments, lose key staff, or cease operations without
notice. Proactive financial monitoring enables contingency planning and
reduces dependency risks.

audits.name: Vendor Reputation Assessment Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor reputation assessment processes including
media monitoring, litigation history, regulatory actions, customer feedback,
industry standing, and reputational risk indicators. Reviews whether
reputational risks are appropriately evaluated before and during vendor
relationships.
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendor reputational issues can create significant organizational exposure
through association. Vendors involved in scandals, breaches, ethical
violations, or regulatory enforcement actions can damage customer trust
and brand value. Proactive reputation monitoring enables informed decisions
and early issue detection.

audits.name: Vendor Risk Classification Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor risk classification framework including
tiering methodology, risk criteria definitions, data sensitivity assessments,
business criticality ratings, and classification accuracy. Reviews whether
vendors are appropriately categorized based on access levels, data handling,
and operational dependencies.
audits.why_it_matters:
Accurate vendor risk classification drives proportionate security controls and
oversight levels. Misclassification can lead to over-investment in low-risk
vendors or dangerous under-protection of high-risk relationships. Proper
classification ensures resources focus where risk is greatest and satisfies
regulatory requirements for risk-based vendor management.

audits.name: Vendor Risk Register Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of the vendor risk register including completeness,
accuracy, risk categorization, risk treatment tracking, ownership assignment,
and integration with enterprise risk management. Reviews whether vendor risks
are systematically identified, documented, and managed.
audits.why_it_matters:
The vendor risk register is the central repository for tracking vendor-related
risks. An incomplete or inaccurate register means risks are unmanaged and
potentially forgotten. Proper register maintenance enables risk prioritization,
resource allocation, and executive visibility into third-party risk exposure.

audits.name: Vendor Risk Scoring Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor risk scoring methodology including
scoring models, risk factor weighting, inherent vs. residual risk
calculations, score aggregation methods, and score accuracy validation.
Reviews whether risk scores accurately reflect vendor risk profiles and
inform appropriate management decisions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendor risk scores drive critical decisions about vendor approval, control
requirements, monitoring intensity, and risk acceptance. Inaccurate scores
lead to misallocated resources, overlooked high-risk vendors, or excessive
burden on low-risk relationships. Robust scoring enables risk-informed
vendor management at scale.

audits.name: Vendor Security Questionnaire Audit
audits.description:
Comprehensive evaluation of vendor security questionnaire processes including
questionnaire design, distribution methods, response collection, answer
validation, evidence requirements, and findings analysis. Assesses whether
questionnaires effectively capture vendor security posture and inform risk
decisions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Security questionnaires are primary tools for assessing vendor security
controls before and during engagements. Poorly designed questionnaires or
inadequate response analysis can miss critical security gaps, creating false
confidence in vendor security posture. Effective questionnaires drive vendor
improvements and support informed risk acceptance.

audits.name: Engagement Metric Ethics Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether engagement metrics and success criteria incentivize
manipulation or respect user wellbeing. Assesses whether metrics like
DAU, time-on-site, sessions, and engagement drive design decisions
that prioritize business goals over user benefit.

Examines how metrics shape product decisions and whether wellbeing
metrics balance engagement metrics.
audits.why_it_matters:
Metrics shape behavior - what gets measured gets optimized:

- Pure engagement metrics incentivize addictive design
- Lack of wellbeing metrics means wellbeing ignored
- Metrics determine what teams are rewarded for
- Engagement without value is extraction, not service
- Regulators and investors increasingly scrutinize metrics
- Metric misalignment creates systemic harm

audits.name: FOMO Exploitation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product exploits Fear of Missing Out (FOMO) to
drive engagement. Assesses time-limited content, disappearing features,
scarcity messaging, social comparison, and other tactics that create
anxiety about missing something.

Examines whether FOMO is used as a deliberate engagement strategy
rather than reflecting genuine scarcity or time-sensitivity.
audits.why_it_matters:
FOMO exploitation harms user wellbeing:

- Creates anxiety and compulsive checking
- Exploits psychological vulnerability
- Particularly harmful for younger users
- Often based on artificial rather than real scarcity
- Undermines user autonomy
- Increasingly scrutinized by regulators

audits.name: Infinite Scroll Impact Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the use of infinite scroll and its impact on user wellbeing.
Assesses whether endless content feeds eliminate natural stopping points,
whether users can track time and progress, and whether the pattern
is designed to maximize engagement regardless of user benefit.

Examines content feed design, stopping cues, time awareness features,
and user control over consumption.
audits.why_it_matters:
Infinite scroll is linked to problematic technology use:

- Eliminates natural stopping points users would otherwise have
- Exploits variable reward psychology
- Contributes to excessive screen time and wellbeing issues
- EU Digital Services Act targets addictive design features
- Parents, educators, and regulators increasingly concerned
- Brand risk from association with addictive design

audits.name: Notification Manipulation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether push notifications, emails, and alerts are designed
to manipulate users into app engagement rather than serve genuine user
needs. Assesses notification relevance, frequency, timing, psychological
triggers, and user control over notification settings.

Examines whether notifications create FOMO, artificial urgency, or
interrupt users unnecessarily.
audits.why_it_matters:
Manipulative notifications harm user wellbeing:

- Constant interruptions affect focus and mental health
- FOMO-inducing notifications exploit psychological vulnerabilities
- Notification fatigue damages user relationship
- Regulators increasingly scrutinize notification practices
- Users resent manipulative notification patterns

audits.name: Social Pressure Mechanism Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product uses social pressure mechanisms to drive
engagement through guilt, obligation, or fear of social consequences.
Assesses read receipts, streaks, public activity indicators, and
features that create social obligation or public accountability.

Examines whether users are pressured to engage through social
dynamics rather than genuine value.
audits.why_it_matters:
Social pressure mechanisms can harm wellbeing:

- Create anxiety about social obligations
- Manipulate users through fear of judgment
- Particularly harmful for younger users
- Can contribute to problematic technology use
- Undermine authentic social connections
- Subject to increasing regulatory scrutiny

audits.name: Variable Reward Pattern Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product uses variable reward schedules - the
psychological mechanism that makes gambling addictive - to drive user
engagement. Assesses pull-to-refresh uncertainty, feed unpredictability,
notification randomness, and other patterns that exploit variable
reinforcement.

Examines whether design deliberately creates unpredictability to
maximize checking behavior and engagement.
audits.why_it_matters:
Variable reward schedules are powerful manipulation mechanisms:

- Core mechanism behind gambling addiction
- Creates compulsive checking behavior
- Exploits fundamental psychology for engagement
- Particularly harmful for children and vulnerable users
- Increasingly subject to regulatory scrutiny
- Ethically problematic when used knowingly

audits.name: Bias Detection Audit
audits.description:
Assesses algorithmic systems for potential bias against protected groups
and marginalized populations. Evaluates whether AI/ML models, recommendation
systems, scoring algorithms, and automated decision-making processes
produce discriminatory outcomes based on race, gender, age, disability,
religion, national origin, or other protected characteristics.

Examines training data composition, feature selection, model outputs,
and downstream impacts across demographic groups.
audits.why_it_matters:
Algorithmic bias can cause significant harm to individuals and communities:
- Discriminatory hiring decisions affecting employment opportunities
- Biased loan/credit decisions perpetuating economic inequality
- Healthcare algorithms that underserve minority populations
- Criminal justice systems with disparate racial impacts
- Housing algorithms that enforce digital redlining

Beyond ethical concerns, algorithmic bias exposes organizations to:
- Legal liability under civil rights laws
- Regulato

audits.name: Disparate Impact Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates algorithmic systems for disparate impact using the EEOC four-fifths
rule and statistical significance testing. Examines whether facially neutral
algorithms produce outcomes that disproportionately affect protected groups
in employment, lending, housing, or other regulated domains.

Applies the adverse impact ratio calculation: selection rate of protected
group divided by selection rate of reference group. Ratios below 0.8 (80%)
indicate potential disparate impact requiring further inve
audits.why_it_matters:
Disparate impact liability under Title VII, ECOA, and Fair Housing Act
applies even when algorithms appear neutral. Organizations face:

- Legal liability for discriminatory outcomes regardless of intent
- EEOC enforcement actions and investigations
- Private litigation and class action lawsuits
- State law violations (many states have disparate impact provisions)
- Reputational damage affecting customer and employee relationships

Even with recent federal enforcement shifts (2025 Executive Orde

audits.name: Fairness Metric Selection Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the appropriateness of fairness metrics chosen for algorithmic
systems. Assesses whether selected metrics align with the ethical context,
legal requirements, and stakeholder values for the specific use case.

Different fairness metrics (demographic parity, equalized odds, calibration,
individual fairness) encode different ethical assumptions and cannot all
be satisfied simultaneously (impossibility theorems). This audit ensures
the chosen metrics match the normative requirements of the
audits.why_it_matters:
Fairness metric selection is a normative choice with significant implications:

- Choosing demographic parity may sacrifice accuracy for some groups
- Equalized odds may permit different selection rates
- Calibration may conflict with demographic parity
- Wrong metric choice can mask discrimination or create new unfairness

Organizations often default to a single metric without understanding
tradeoffs, leading to:
- False confidence in "fair" systems that discriminate
- Regulatory non-compliance

audits.name: Historical Bias in Training Data Audit
audits.description:
Assesses training data for historical biases that may be learned and
perpetuated by machine learning models. Examines whether training labels,
data collection processes, or historical patterns encode past discrimination
that could be amplified by algorithmic systems.

Examples include hiring models trained on historically biased hiring decisions,
criminal justice algorithms trained on racially disparate arrest data, and
lending models trained on redlining-era decisions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Machine learning models learn from data - if that data reflects historical
discrimination, models will perpetuate and potentially amplify it:

- Models trained on biased hiring data will continue discriminating
- Criminal justice algorithms trained on biased arrests predict biased outcomes
- Loan models trained on redlining data encode geographic discrimination
- Healthcare algorithms trained during access disparities underserve minorities

Unlike explicit discrimination, historical bias creates

audits.name: Protected Class Treatment Audit
audits.description:
Assesses how algorithmic systems handle protected class characteristics
under civil rights law. Evaluates whether systems inappropriately use,
collect, store, or infer protected characteristics including race, color,
religion, sex (including pregnancy, gender identity, sexual orientation),
national origin, age (40+), disability, and genetic information.

Examines data collection practices, feature engineering, model inputs,
and whether systems attempt to infer protected characteristics from
othe
audits.why_it_matters:
Protected class treatment violations carry severe legal consequences:

- Title VII prohibits discrimination in employment based on protected class
- Fair Housing Act prohibits discrimination in housing
- Equal Credit Opportunity Act prohibits discrimination in lending
- ADA prohibits discrimination based on disability
- ADEA prohibits age discrimination

Beyond direct use, inferring protected characteristics or using highly
correlated proxies can constitute illegal discrimination. Organizations

audits.name: Proxy Variable Audit
audits.description:
Identifies and assesses proxy variables in algorithmic systems - features
that correlate strongly with protected characteristics and can enable
indirect discrimination. Evaluates whether algorithms use zip codes, names,
schools, purchase patterns, or other variables that serve as proxies for
race, gender, age, or other protected attributes.

Examines both direct feature correlations and more subtle pathways where
combinations of features reconstruct protected characteristics.
audits.why_it_matters:
Proxy discrimination is legally equivalent to direct discrimination:

- Courts recognize proxy variables as discriminatory when they correlate
  with protected characteristics and lack business justification
- Zip code discrimination can constitute racial discrimination (redlining)
- Name-based discrimination can proxy for gender or ethnicity
- School/college proxies can encode socioeconomic and racial bias

Organizations often believe removing explicit protected characteristics
is sufficient, b

audits.name: Algorithm Explainability Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether algorithmic decisions affecting users can be
meaningfully explained. Assesses whether users can understand why
an algorithm made a particular decision about them, what factors
influenced it, and how they might get a different outcome.

Examines explanation mechanisms, meaningful information requirements,
and the gap between technical explainability and user understanding.
audits.why_it_matters:
Algorithm explainability is increasingly required and ethically important:

- GDPR Article 22 requires meaningful information about automated decisions
- EU AI Act requires transparency for high-risk AI systems
- ECOA requires reasons for credit denials
- Users have ethical right to understand decisions affecting them
- Explainability enables contestability and fairness verification

audits.name: Cookie Consent Implementation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates cookie consent banner implementation for GDPR and ePrivacy
compliance. Assesses whether consent is freely given, specific,
informed, and unambiguous. Examines whether rejection is as easy
as acceptance and whether cookies are blocked before consent.

Reviews consent management platform configuration, cookie behavior
before consent, and dark patterns in consent interfaces.
audits.why_it_matters:
Cookie consent is heavily regulated and enforced:

- GDPR and ePrivacy require prior consent for non-essential cookies
- DPAs actively fine organizations for non-compliant consent
- CNIL, ICO, and other authorities have issued specific guidance
- Cookie walls and dark patterns face increased scrutiny
- EU DSA explicitly prohibits dark patterns in consent

audits.name: Data Usage Transparency Audit
audits.description:
Assesses whether users have clear, accessible information about how
their data is collected, used, shared, and retained. Evaluates transparency
of data practices including what data is collected, for what purposes,
with whom it's shared, and for how long it's kept.

Examines privacy policies, in-product disclosures, data dashboards,
and user-facing explanations of data practices.
audits.why_it_matters:
Transparency is a cornerstone of privacy regulation and ethics:

- GDPR requires transparent processing and disclosure
- CCPA requires disclosure of data practices
- Users cannot exercise rights they don't know about
- Lack of transparency damages trust
- Regulatory enforcement targets opacity

audits.name: Informed Consent Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether user consent is truly informed - that users understand
what they're agreeing to when they accept terms, permissions, or data
processing. Assesses whether consent is specific, freely given, unambiguous,
and based on clear information about consequences.

Examines consent flows, disclosure adequacy, comprehension testing, and
whether users can make genuinely informed decisions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Informed consent is foundational to ethical and legal data practices:

- GDPR requires consent to be informed, specific, and freely given
- Lack of informed consent invalidates consent under privacy law
- Users who don't understand what they agreed to feel deceived
- Informed consent is ethical foundation for data processing
- Regulatory enforcement increasingly scrutinizes consent quality

audits.name: Opt-In vs Opt-Out Default Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether default settings appropriately use opt-in vs opt-out
for data collection, communications, and other user choices. Assesses
whether defaults favor user privacy and autonomy or maximize data
collection through user inaction.

Examines email marketing, data sharing, tracking, personalization,
and other settings where defaults matter.
audits.why_it_matters:
Defaults have enormous impact on user behavior:

- GDPR requires opt-in for marketing communications
- Privacy by default requires most protective settings
- Opt-out defaults exploit user inertia
- Default bias means most users stay with default
- Ethical design respects user autonomy through appropriate defaults

audits.name: Price Transparency Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether pricing is transparently communicated to users.
Assesses whether total costs are clear upfront, how fees are disclosed,
whether personalized pricing is disclosed, and if subscription terms
are clear.

Examines pricing pages, checkout flows, and disclosure of all costs
including taxes, fees, and recurring charges.
audits.why_it_matters:
Price transparency is legally required and ethically important:

- FTC prohibits deceptive pricing practices
- EU Consumer Rights Directive requires total price disclosure
- Drip pricing is under regulatory scrutiny
- Personalized pricing requires disclosure in many jurisdictions
- Price transparency enables informed purchase decisions

audits.name: Terms of Service Readability Audit
audits.description:
Assesses whether Terms of Service, privacy policies, and other legal
documents are readable and comprehensible to average users. Evaluates
reading level, length, structure, use of plain language, and whether
key terms are highlighted or summarized.

Applies readability metrics (Flesch-Kincaid, SMOG) and qualitative
assessment of comprehensibility.
audits.why_it_matters:
Unreadable legal documents undermine consent:

- GDPR requires clear, plain language
- Consumer protection laws require understandable terms
- Users cannot meaningfully agree to incomprehensible terms
- Overly complex terms may be unenforceable
- Poor readability signals lack of user respect

audits.name: Harmful Content Moderation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the effectiveness and fairness of content moderation systems
for harmful content including hate speech, violence, harassment,
self-harm promotion, and illegal content. Assesses detection accuracy,
enforcement consistency, appeal processes, and moderator wellbeing.
audits.why_it_matters:
Content moderation is critical for platform safety:

- Inadequate moderation enables harm to users and communities
- Over-moderation can silence legitimate speech
- Inconsistent enforcement undermines trust
- EU DSA requires effective content moderation
- Moderator welfare is ethical obligation
- Legal liability for certain content types

audits.name: Misinformation Amplification Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether platform systems amplify misinformation through
recommendation algorithms, engagement optimization, or content
distribution. Assesses whether viral dynamics favor false content,
whether fact-checking reduces amplification, and whether systems
have misinformation safeguards.
audits.why_it_matters:
Misinformation amplification causes significant harm:

- Health misinformation can cause death and disease
- Election misinformation undermines democracy
- Financial misinformation causes economic harm
- EU DSA requires systemic risk assessment for misinformation
- Platform liability increasing for amplification
- Reputational damage from being misinformation vector

audits.name: Radicalization Vector Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether platform systems act as vectors for radicalization by
progressively recommending increasingly extreme content. Assesses whether
recommendation algorithms create "rabbit holes" that lead users from
mainstream to extreme content, and whether safeguards prevent this pathway.

Examines algorithmic pathways, content adjacency, extremism detection,
and circuit breakers that interrupt radicalization progressions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Platforms can inadvertently accelerate radicalization:

- Recommendation systems optimizing for engagement may favor extreme content
- Progressive exposure to extreme content normalizes it
- Algorithmic radicalization has been linked to real-world violence
- EU DSA requires systemic risk assessment for radicalization
- Platforms face increasing scrutiny and liability
- Social harm from radicalization is severe and lasting

audits.name: Bait and Switch Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product employs bait-and-switch tactics -
advertising or presenting one thing to attract users, then substituting
something different once they're engaged. This includes feature changes
after signup, pricing changes after commitment, or actions that produce
unexpected results.

Examines marketing promises versus delivered experience, UI actions
that do something different than expected, and post-signup changes.
audits.why_it_matters:
Bait and switch is a recognized deceptive practice:

- FTC Act Section 5 prohibits deceptive practices
- Bait advertising is specifically regulated
- Can constitute fraud in severe cases
- Damages trust and increases churn
- Creates negative word-of-mouth and reviews

Digital products have new bait-and-switch vectors including
click hijacking, where clicks do something different than indicated.

audits.name: Confirmshaming Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product uses confirmshaming - language that
guilts or shames users into choosing the business-preferred option.
This includes opt-out text like "No, I don't want to save money" or
"No thanks, I'll pay full price" designed to emotionally manipulate
users.

Examines popup dismissals, newsletter opt-outs, upgrade declines,
cancellation flows, and any choice language for manipulative framing.
audits.why_it_matters:
Confirmshaming is emotionally manipulative:

- Exploits social psychology to override user preferences
- Creates negative emotional experience
- Undermines autonomous decision-making
- Increasing regulatory attention as manipulative design
- Damages brand perception when users notice manipulation

While it may boost short-term conversions, it erodes trust and
creates resentment that affects long-term customer relationships.

audits.name: Forced Continuity Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product uses forced continuity dark patterns -
automatically enrolling users in paid subscriptions after free trials
without clear disclosure, making it difficult to cancel, or silently
renewing subscriptions without adequate notice.

Examines free trial to paid conversion flows, subscription renewal
processes, cancellation pathways, and billing transparency.
audits.why_it_matters:
Forced continuity is one of the most costly dark patterns for consumers:

- FTC enforcement actions have resulted in significant penalties
- ROSCA (Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act) specifically addresses this
- EU Digital Services Act prohibits manipulative subscription practices
- California and other states have auto-renewal disclosure laws
- Class action lawsuits over forced continuity are common

Beyond legal risk, forced continuity damages customer trust and creates
negative brand p

audits.name: Hidden Cost Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product reveals all costs upfront or employs
hidden cost dark patterns - fees, charges, or costs that appear only
late in the purchase flow after users have invested time and effort.

Examines pricing displays, checkout flows, fee disclosures, and
identifies "drip pricing" where costs are gradually revealed.
audits.why_it_matters:
Hidden costs are a pervasive and harmful dark pattern:

- FTC targets drip pricing as unfair/deceptive practice
- DOT requires all-in pricing for airline tickets
- Hotel resort fees face increasing regulation
- Consumer frustration and cart abandonment
- Brand damage when customers feel deceived

Research shows hidden costs lead to poor consumer decisions and
disproportionately affect lower-income consumers who can least
afford unexpected charges.

audits.name: Misdirection Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product uses misdirection dark patterns -
design techniques that focus user attention on one thing to distract
from another, typically to encourage upgrades, prevent cancellation,
or obscure important information.

Examines visual hierarchy, attention manipulation, decoy options,
and asymmetric emphasis between user-beneficial and business-beneficial
choices.
audits.why_it_matters:
Misdirection manipulates user attention to achieve business goals at
user expense:

- EU DSA prohibits design that subverts user decision-making
- Creates user frustration when manipulation is noticed
- Undermines trust and informed consent
- Can constitute unfair practice under consumer protection laws
- Often combined with other dark patterns for compounding effect

audits.name: Privacy Zuckering Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product manipulates users into sharing more
personal data than intended through confusing interfaces, defaults
that maximize data collection, or unclear privacy settings. Named
after Facebook's historical privacy practices, this pattern tricks
users into revealing information they would prefer to keep private.

Examines privacy settings complexity, default configurations,
consent flows, and data sharing disclosures.
audits.why_it_matters:
Privacy zuckering has severe regulatory and trust implications:

- GDPR requires privacy by design and by default
- Data minimization principle requires limiting collection
- Consent must be informed, specific, and freely given
- FTC has taken action against deceptive privacy practices
- EU DSA prohibits dark patterns in consent interfaces

Beyond regulation, users who discover their data was collected
through manipulation lose trust and may become vocal critics.

audits.name: Roach Motel (Hard to Cancel) Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether it is as easy to cancel, unsubscribe, or delete
an account as it was to sign up - the "roach motel" pattern makes
it easy to get in but hard to get out. Examines cancellation flows,
account deletion processes, unsubscribe mechanisms, and data deletion
requests.

Tests the FTC's "click-to-cancel" principle: if you can sign up
online, you should be able to cancel online just as easily.
audits.why_it_matters:
Hard-to-cancel practices face increasing legal scrutiny:

- FTC's click-to-cancel rule requires simple cancellation
- California auto-renewal law requires easy cancellation
- GDPR requires straightforward data deletion
- Class actions over cancellation difficulty are common
- FTC enforcement actions have resulted in significant penalties

Beyond legal risk, making cancellation difficult creates angry
customers who vocally complain and damage brand reputation.

audits.name: Sneak into Basket Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether items, services, or charges are added to user
carts or orders without explicit consent - the "sneak into basket"
dark pattern. This includes pre-selected add-ons, automatically
bundled items, donations added by default, or insurance/protection
plans pre-checked.

Examines checkout flows, add-on presentations, and default
selections for unwanted items.
audits.why_it_matters:
Sneaking items into baskets is consumer deception:

- EU Directive explicitly prohibits pre-ticked boxes for additional payments
- FTC considers this unfair/deceptive practice
- Creates customer disputes and chargebacks
- Damages trust and brand reputation
- High complaint rates and negative reviews

Users who notice unexpected items lose trust; those who don't
notice pay for things they didn't want.

audits.name: Trick Question Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the product uses confusing or misleading questions
to trick users into unintended choices. This includes double negatives,
ambiguous opt-out/opt-in language, questions where 'yes' means different
things in different contexts, or convoluted phrasing that makes the
desired action unclear.

Examines consent forms, settings interfaces, email preferences, and
any user-facing questions that could be misinterpreted.
audits.why_it_matters:
Trick questions undermine informed consent:

- Users make choices opposite to their intent
- GDPR requires clear, plain language for consent
- Creates user frustration when error is discovered
- May constitute deceptive practice under consumer protection law
- Damages trust when users realize manipulation

Questions designed to confuse are particularly harmful as users
believe they're making informed choices.

audits.name: Accessibility Pricing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether essential services or products have pricing models
that enable access across economic levels. Assesses whether pricing
creates barriers to essential services, whether accessibility options
exist (tiered pricing, discounts, subsidized access), and whether
pricing decisions consider economic equity.

Examines pricing barriers, accessibility programs, and the balance
between business sustainability and inclusive access.
audits.why_it_matters:
Pricing affects who can access products and services:

- Essential services should be accessible across income levels
- Pricing can perpetuate or reduce economic inequality
- Accessibility pricing can expand market and mission impact
- Some services have public interest obligations
- Ethical business considers access alongside profit
- Inaccessible pricing for essentials causes societal harm

audits.name: Dynamic Pricing Transparency Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the fairness and transparency of dynamic pricing systems that
adjust prices based on demand, user characteristics, or other factors.
Assesses whether dynamic pricing is disclosed, whether personalized
pricing discriminates unfairly, and whether consumers can understand
and anticipate price changes.

Examines pricing algorithms, disclosure practices, discrimination patterns,
and consumer information about how prices are determined.
audits.why_it_matters:
Dynamic pricing raises ethical concerns:

- Personalized pricing can discriminate against protected classes
- Hidden dynamic pricing erodes consumer trust
- Price discrimination based on user data raises privacy concerns
- EU and FTC increasingly scrutinizing personalized pricing
- Surge pricing during emergencies can constitute gouging
- Consumers expect price transparency and fairness

audits.name: Predatory Pricing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates pricing practices for predatory or exploitative patterns that
harm consumers or competitors. Assesses whether pricing takes advantage
of vulnerable populations, uses below-cost pricing to eliminate competition,
employs price gouging during emergencies, or exploits information asymmetry
to extract excessive value.

Examines pricing logic, vulnerability targeting, competitive impact, and
ethical pricing guardrails.
audits.why_it_matters:
Predatory pricing causes significant economic harm:

- Targeting vulnerable populations is both unethical and often illegal
- Below-cost predatory pricing damages market competition
- Price gouging during emergencies harms those in crisis
- FTC and state laws prohibit various predatory pricing practices
- Reputational damage from predatory pricing exposure
- Long-term harm to consumer trust and market health

audits.name: Vendor Lock-In Ethics Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether products or services create artificial barriers to
switching that trap users or businesses. Assesses whether lock-in is
achieved through proprietary formats, data non-portability, artificial
technical barriers, or contractual restrictions rather than genuine
product value.

Examines data portability, export capabilities, interoperability,
contract terms, and switching costs relative to legitimate product value.
audits.why_it_matters:
Artificial lock-in raises ethical and legal concerns:

- Trapping customers is fundamentally adversarial
- GDPR requires data portability
- Artificial barriers harm consumer choice
- Lock-in can enable exploitative pricing once trapped
- Interoperability regulations increasing (EU DMA)
- Ethical products compete on value, not barriers

audits.name: Compute Optimization (Environmental) Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compute resource optimization from an environmental perspective.
Assesses whether workloads are right-sized, auto-scaling is efficient,
spot/preemptible instances are utilized, and compute waste is minimized.
Focuses on the environmental benefit of efficiency, not just cost.
audits.why_it_matters:
Compute efficiency directly reduces carbon footprint:

- Over-provisioned resources waste energy
- Efficient scaling matches resources to demand
- Spot/preemptible instances use otherwise wasted capacity
- Optimization reduces both cost and environmental impact
- Every wasted CPU cycle has a carbon cost

audits.name: Data Center Efficiency Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the energy efficiency of data center infrastructure used by
the software system. For cloud deployments, assesses cloud provider
efficiency metrics, PUE (Power Usage Effectiveness), and renewable
energy usage. For on-premises, evaluates direct facility efficiency.
audits.why_it_matters:
Data center efficiency directly impacts environmental footprint:

- PUE differences can double or halve energy usage
- Cloud provider choice affects sustainability
- Efficient infrastructure reduces both cost and carbon
- Growing regulatory focus on data center energy
- ESG expectations include infrastructure efficiency

audits.name: Data Retention (Environmental) Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates data retention practices from an environmental perspective.
Assesses whether data is retained longer than necessary, whether
storage tiers are optimized, and whether deletion policies reduce
storage carbon footprint.

Focuses on the environmental benefit of data minimization and efficient
storage, complementing privacy-focused retention audits.
audits.why_it_matters:
Data storage has significant environmental impact:

- Storage infrastructure consumes substantial energy
- Retaining unnecessary data wastes resources
- Cold storage tiers reduce active storage energy
- Data growth is exponential - unchecked growth unsustainable
- Storage optimization reduces both cost and carbon

audits.name: Energy-Efficient Algorithm Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates algorithm and code efficiency from an environmental perspective.
Assesses whether algorithms are optimized for energy consumption, whether
expensive computation is justified, and whether ML models consider
inference cost relative to benefit.

Examines algorithm complexity, model efficiency, and the energy/value
tradeoff of computational approaches.
audits.why_it_matters:
Algorithm efficiency directly impacts energy consumption:

- Large ML models have significant training and inference costs
- Inefficient algorithms multiply energy use at scale
- Optimization can dramatically reduce environmental impact
- AI energy consumption growing rapidly
- Every computation has an energy and carbon cost

audits.name: Green Hosting Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether hosting infrastructure uses renewable energy and
environmentally responsible practices. Assesses cloud provider
renewable energy commitments, carbon offset programs, and actual
vs. claimed sustainability practices.

Examines provider sustainability claims, verification, and the
actual environmental impact of hosting choices.
audits.why_it_matters:
Hosting provider choice significantly impacts environmental footprint:

- Major cloud providers have different renewable energy levels
- Green energy usage can dramatically reduce carbon footprint
- Greenwashing vs. genuine sustainability varies widely
- Customer pressure drives provider sustainability improvements
- ESG and sustainability reporting requires understanding hosting impact

audits.name: Achievement Completability Audit
audits.description:
Assesses whether achievements are actually completable, including
time-limited achievements, missable content, and whether all
players have fair access to achievement completion.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incompletable achievements:
- Frustrate completionists
- Create FOMO from missed opportunities
- Punish players who weren't present at specific times
- Devalue the achievement system

Fair completability:
