wasting the effort of creating it. Good discoverability enables self-
service information access and reduces repetitive questions.

audits.name: Tribal Knowledge Capture Audit
audits.description:
This audit identifies critical knowledge that exists only in individuals'
heads and evaluates processes for capturing and documenting this tribal
knowledge. The audit examines knowledge concentration risks, documentation
gaps, and knowledge transfer practices.
audits.why_it_matters:
Tribal knowledge represents significant organizational risk. When key
people leave, take vacation, or are unavailable, undocumented knowledge
becomes inaccessible. Systematic capture of tribal knowledge reduces
bus factor risk and enables organizational scalability.

audits.name: Wiki Organization Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the organization and structure of internal wikis
and documentation platforms. The audit examines information architecture,
navigation, categorization, and overall usability for finding and
contributing information.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poorly organized wikis become documentation graveyards where information
goes to die. When content is hard to find, people don't use the wiki,
leading to knowledge silos and repeated questions. Good organization
enables self-service information discovery and knowledge sharing.

audits.name: Learning Paths Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates documentation of learning paths and skill
development resources for team members. The audit examines structured
learning recommendations, skill development resources, and progression
guidance for different roles and levels.
audits.why_it_matters:
Learning paths guide professional development and help team members
grow systematically. Without documented paths, learning is ad-hoc,
skill development is inconsistent, and career progression is unclear.
Good learning paths enable self-directed development.

audits.name: Mentorship Resources Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates documentation supporting mentorship and buddy
programs for new hires. The audit examines resources for both mentors
and mentees, program guidelines, and supporting documentation for
effective mentorship.
audits.why_it_matters:
Mentorship accelerates onboarding by providing personalized guidance
and support. Documentation enables consistent mentorship quality,
helps mentors be effective, and ensures mentees get the support they
need. Without resources, mentorship quality varies widely.

audits.name: Onboarding Completeness Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the completeness of onboarding documentation for
new team members. The audit examines coverage of essential topics,
clarity of instructions, and effectiveness in enabling new hires to
become productive.
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective onboarding documentation accelerates time-to-productivity
for new team members. Poor onboarding leads to extended ramp-up times,
frustration, repeated questions, and early attrition. Comprehensive
onboarding documentation is a force multiplier for growing teams.

audits.name: Process Documentation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates documentation of team and engineering processes
that new hires need to understand. This includes development workflows,
code review processes, deployment procedures, and team ceremonies.
audits.why_it_matters:
Process knowledge enables effective participation in team activities.
Without documented processes, new hires don't know how work gets done,
leading to mistakes, delays, and reliance on others for basic guidance.
Clear process documentation enables autonomous contribution.

audits.name: Team-Specific Onboarding Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates team-specific onboarding documentation that
supplements general onboarding. The audit examines whether individual
teams have documented their specific context, systems, processes, and
expectations for new team members.
audits.why_it_matters:
General onboarding covers company-wide basics, but each team has
unique systems, processes, and context. Team-specific onboarding
accelerates integration into the specific team and its work.
Without it, new hires struggle to understand team-specific nuances.

audits.name: Tool Access Documentation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates documentation of tool access requirements and
procedures for new team members. The audit examines whether all
required tools are documented, access procedures are clear, and
new hires can get productive without extensive help.
audits.why_it_matters:
Tool access issues are a common onboarding blocker. Without clear
documentation, new hires spend days requesting access, waiting for
approvals, and troubleshooting access problems. Good access documentation
enables self-service onboarding for tools.

audits.name: Deployment Guides Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates deployment documentation including deployment
procedures, environment configurations, deployment prerequisites,
rollback procedures, and post-deployment verification steps. The audit
examines whether deployment guides enable safe, consistent deployments
across different environments and team members.
audits.why_it_matters:
Deployment documentation directly impacts release reliability and velocity.
Poor deployment guides lead to failed deployments, production incidents,
inconsistent environments, and deployment fear that slows delivery. Good
deployment documentation enables safe, frequent releases with confidence,
supporting continuous delivery practices.

audits.name: Disaster Recovery Documentation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates disaster recovery (DR) documentation including
recovery procedures, RTO/RPO targets, failover processes, data restoration
guides, and business continuity plans. The audit examines whether DR
documentation enables effective recovery from major outages and data loss
scenarios.
audits.why_it_matters:
When disasters strike, organizations must recover quickly with minimal
data loss. Without comprehensive, tested DR documentation, recovery
becomes chaotic and error-prone, extending downtime and potentially
causing permanent data loss. DR documentation is also required for
compliance with many regulatory frameworks.

audits.name: Incident Playbooks Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates incident response playbooks that guide teams through
handling specific types of incidents. Unlike general runbooks, incident
playbooks are optimized for high-stress situations with clear decision
trees, escalation paths, and communication templates. The audit examines
coverage of common incident types, playbook clarity, and integration with
incident management tooling.
audits.why_it_matters:
During incidents, responders experience cognitive load and stress that
impairs decision-making. Well-designed incident playbooks reduce mean
time to resolution (MTTR) by providing clear, tested procedures that
don't require creative problem-solving in crisis moments. Organizations
without playbooks see longer incidents, more customer impact, and
higher responder burnout.

audits.name: Monitoring Documentation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates documentation of monitoring systems, including
dashboard guides, metric explanations, alert documentation, and
observability architecture. The audit examines whether teams can
effectively use monitoring tools to understand system health and
diagnose issues.
audits.why_it_matters:
Monitoring systems are only valuable when operators understand how to
use them. Without documentation, dashboards become confusing, metrics
lack context, and alerts fire without clear meaning. Well-documented
monitoring enables faster incident detection and resolution while
reducing cognitive load on operators.

audits.name: Operational Procedures Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates documentation of standard operating procedures (SOPs)
for day-to-day system operations. This includes routine maintenance tasks,
scheduled jobs, access management procedures, capacity management, and
regular operational activities. The audit examines procedure completeness,
accuracy, and alignment with actual operational practices.
audits.why_it_matters:
Standard operating procedures ensure consistent, repeatable operations
across team members and time. Without documented SOPs, operations become
person-dependent, leading to variations in execution, missed steps, and
difficulty training new team members. Well-documented procedures also
support compliance requirements and audit readiness.

audits.name: Runbook Documentation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the completeness, accuracy, and usability of operational
runbooks. Runbooks are documented procedures for operating systems in production,
including routine tasks, maintenance procedures, and operational responses.
The audit examines whether runbooks exist for all critical operations, are
kept current with system changes, and follow consistent formatting standards.
audits.why_it_matters:
Well-documented runbooks enable consistent and reliable system operations
across team members and shifts. Without runbooks, operations depend on
tribal knowledge, leading to inconsistent execution, longer resolution
times during incidents, and increased risk during staff transitions.
Runbooks are essential for operational excellence and compliance with
standards like SOC 2 and ISO 27001.

audits.name: Troubleshooting Guides Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates troubleshooting documentation that helps engineers
diagnose and resolve system issues. This includes diagnostic procedures,
symptom-to-cause mappings, debugging guides, and common issue resolutions.
The audit examines whether troubleshooting guides enable efficient problem
resolution across skill levels.
audits.why_it_matters:
Troubleshooting documentation captures institutional knowledge about
system behavior and common problems. Without it, engineers repeatedly
rediscover solutions, extending resolution times and frustrating both
operators and customers. Good troubleshooting guides accelerate diagnosis,
enable junior engineers to resolve issues independently, and preserve
knowledge across team transitions.

audits.name: Escalation Documentation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates documentation of escalation procedures for support,
incidents, and other situations requiring involvement of additional
stakeholders. The audit examines escalation paths, criteria, contacts,
and procedures.
audits.why_it_matters:
Clear escalation documentation ensures issues reach the right people at
the right time. Without documented escalation procedures, critical issues
may be delayed, wrong people may be contacted, or issues may fall through
the cracks. Proper escalation documentation is essential for incident
response and support operations.

audits.name: FAQ Completeness Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the completeness and quality of FAQ (Frequently
Asked Questions) documentation. The audit examines whether FAQs
address actual frequent questions, are well-organized, and provide
helpful answers.
audits.why_it_matters:
FAQs are often the first place users look for answers. Well-curated
FAQs deflect support tickets, enable self-service, and demonstrate
customer understanding. Poor FAQs waste user time and increase
support burden.

audits.name: Help Center Quality Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the overall quality of the help center or support
documentation portal. The audit examines content organization, search
effectiveness, navigation, content freshness, and user experience across
the entire help center.
audits.why_it_matters:
A well-designed help center enables customer self-service, reduces
support costs, and improves customer satisfaction. Poor help center
experiences frustrate users and drive unnecessary support contacts.
Help center quality directly impacts support efficiency.

audits.name: Known Issues Documentation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates documentation of known issues, limitations, and
workarounds. The audit examines how known problems are documented,
communicated to users and support teams, and tracked for resolution.
audits.why_it_matters:
Known issues documentation reduces support burden by preemptively
informing users of problems and workarounds. Without this documentation,
support handles the same known issues repeatedly, users are frustrated
by undocumented limitations, and engineering lacks visibility into
user-impacting issues.

audits.name: Support Playbooks Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates internal support playbooks that guide support
agents in handling customer issues. The audit examines playbook coverage
for common scenarios, troubleshooting steps, escalation criteria, and
resolution procedures.
audits.why_it_matters:
Support playbooks enable consistent, high-quality customer support.
Without playbooks, support quality varies by agent, resolution times
are longer, and incorrect solutions may be provided. Good playbooks
scale support capability and ensure consistent customer experience.

audits.name: User Documentation Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates end-user documentation that helps customers or
users understand and use the product. The audit examines user guides,
feature documentation, tutorials, and help content for completeness,
accuracy, and usability.
audits.why_it_matters:
User documentation directly impacts product adoption and customer
success. Poor user documentation leads to support burden, user
frustration, and churn. Good documentation enables self-service
success and reduces support costs.

audits.name: Acceptance Criteria Definition Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the definition and quality of acceptance criteria
for requirements and user stories. It evaluates:
- Presence of acceptance criteria for all stories/requirements
- Clarity and specificity of criteria
- Use of Given-When-Then or equivalent format
- Measurability of criteria
- Stakeholder-understandable language
audits.why_it_matters:
Acceptance criteria define done and enable verification:
- Provide shared understanding of requirement completion
- Enable acceptance testing
- Reduce ambiguity in requirements
- Support sprint completion decisions
- Facilitate stakeholder sign-off
- Enable automated acceptance tests

audits.name: Acceptance Criteria Testability Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines whether acceptance criteria can be effectively tested.
It evaluates:
- Criteria translate to test cases
- Pass/fail conditions are unambiguous
- Test automation potential
- BDD scenario executable coverage
- Test case existence for criteria
audits.why_it_matters:
Testable acceptance criteria enable verification:
- Untestable criteria cannot be verified
- BDD requires executable specifications
- Automation requires testable criteria
- Clear pass/fail enables objective assessment
- Reduces disputes about completion

audits.name: Business Rules Validation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines how business rules are validated through
acceptance criteria and testing. It evaluates:
- Business rules documented with test criteria
- Rule validation in acceptance criteria
- Business rule test coverage
- Edge case handling for rules
- Rule consistency across the system
audits.why_it_matters:
Business rules enforce domain constraints:
- Rules are often undocumented or implicit
- Incorrect rule implementation causes business errors
- Rules need explicit validation criteria
- Rule violations can have financial/legal impact
- Comprehensive rule testing prevents defects

audits.name: Definition of Done Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the Definition of Done (DoD) used by teams to
determine when work items are complete. It evaluates:
- DoD existence and documentation
- DoD comprehensiveness
- Quality criteria inclusion
- Team adherence to DoD
- DoD evolution and improvement
audits.why_it_matters:
Definition of Done ensures consistent quality:
- Scrum Guide requires clear DoD
- Prevents incomplete work from being marked done
- Ensures quality standards are met
- Reduces technical debt accumulation
- Provides shared completion criteria
- Enables accurate velocity measurement

audits.name: Edge Case Coverage Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines whether acceptance criteria cover edge cases
and boundary conditions. It evaluates:
- Boundary value identification
- Empty/null handling specified
- Maximum/minimum cases covered
- Concurrent/race condition scenarios
- Unusual but valid input handling
audits.why_it_matters:
Edge cases often cause production defects:
- Happy path testing misses edge cases
- Boundary conditions are common failure points
- Null/empty handling causes many defects
- Edge cases reveal incomplete requirements
- Proactive edge case identification prevents defects

audits.name: Negative Scenarios Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines coverage of negative scenarios and error cases
in acceptance criteria. It evaluates:
- Invalid input handling
- Error message specifications
- Failure scenario coverage
- Recovery behavior requirements
- Security violation scenarios
audits.why_it_matters:
Negative scenarios ensure robustness:
- Users make mistakes; systems must handle them
- Security depends on rejecting invalid input
- Error handling affects user experience
- Negative testing finds vulnerabilities
- Missing error handling causes support issues

audits.name: Baseline Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines how requirements baselines are established and
maintained. It evaluates:
- Baseline establishment process
- Baseline identification and labeling
- Baseline content documentation
- Changes from baseline tracking
- Baseline comparison capability
- Re-baselining process
audits.why_it_matters:
Baselines provide reference points for change management:
- Establish agreed scope at point in time
- Enable comparison of current to baseline
- Support scope management
- Required for contract management
- CMMI CM requires baseline establishment
- Enable progress measurement

audits.name: Change Approval Workflow Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the workflow for approving requirements changes.
It evaluates:
- Approval workflow definition
- Approval authority levels
- CCB (Change Control Board) if applicable
- Approval criteria
- Approval documentation
- Escalation procedures
audits.why_it_matters:
Approval workflow ensures appropriate authorization:
- Prevents unauthorized scope changes
- Ensures appropriate review level
- Documents decision authority
- Supports audit compliance
- Enables accountability
- CCB provides governance for significant changes

audits.name: Change Communication Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines how requirements changes are communicated to
stakeholders. It evaluates:
- Communication process for changes
- Stakeholder notification
- Change impact communication
- Communication timeliness
- Communication channels
- Feedback collection
audits.why_it_matters:
Change communication ensures alignment:
- Stakeholders need to know about changes
- Teams need to adjust plans
- Impacts need to be understood
- Poor communication causes surprises
- Timely communication enables response
- Two-way communication surfaces issues

audits.name: Change Request Process Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the process for requesting and managing requirements
changes. It evaluates:
- Change request process definition
- Request documentation requirements
- Submission and tracking mechanisms
- Request categorization and prioritization
- Process compliance
- Request lifecycle management
audits.why_it_matters:
Change request process ensures controlled evolution:
- Prevents ad-hoc scope changes
- Enables impact assessment
- Supports decision-making
- Maintains audit trail
- Required by CMMI REQM
- Supports contract management

audits.name: Impact Assessment Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the process for assessing impact of requirements
changes before approval. It evaluates:
- Impact assessment process
- Scope of assessment (schedule, cost, other requirements)
- Assessment quality and completeness
- Stakeholder involvement
- Documentation of impacts
- Use in decision-making
audits.why_it_matters:
Impact assessment enables informed decisions:
- Changes have ripple effects
- Cost/schedule impacts must be known before approval
- Other requirements may be affected
- Risk implications must be understood
- Stakeholders need impact information
- CMMI REQM requires impact understanding

audits.name: Requirements Freeze Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the use of requirements freeze periods before releases.
It evaluates:
- Freeze policy definition
- Freeze timing appropriateness
- Freeze enforcement
- Exception handling
- Communication of freeze status
- Freeze effectiveness
audits.why_it_matters:
Requirements freeze enables stable delivery:
- Provides stability for final development and testing
- Prevents last-minute scope disruption
- Enables predictable delivery
- Allows testing to complete against stable target
- Exception process handles genuine emergencies
- Communicates commitment to delivery

audits.name: Scope Creep Control Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines measures to prevent and control scope creep.
It evaluates:
- Scope definition clarity
- Change process enforcement
- Scope monitoring mechanisms
- Scope creep detection
- Corrective actions
- Stakeholder communication about scope
audits.why_it_matters:

- OWASP emphasizes risk-based prioritization
- Effective prioritization maximizes security ROI

audits.name: Configuration Access Control Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines access controls applied to configuration items
to ensure appropriate authorization. It evaluates:
- Read access restrictions for sensitive configurations
- Write access restrictions for configuration modification
- Role-based access control (RBAC) for configurations
- Service account access management
- Access audit logging
- Principle of least privilege application
- Access review processes
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration access control protects system integrity:
- CMMI CM requires controlling access to configuration items
- SOC 2 CC6.1 requires logical access controls
- Unauthorized configuration access enables attacks
- Write access to configs enables privilege escalation
- Overly permissive access increases blast radius
- Least privilege limits damage from compromised accounts
- Access logging enables forensic investigation

audits.name: Configuration Approval Workflow Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the approval workflows implemented for configuration
changes. It evaluates:
- Multi-level approval requirements based on change risk
- Approval routing and escalation paths
- Approval automation and integration with CI/CD
- Time-bound approvals and expiration
- Delegation and out-of-office handling
- Approval audit trails and documentation
- Emergency approval procedures
audits.why_it_matters:
Approval workflows ensure appropriate oversight for changes:
- ITIL requires appropriate authorization for changes based on risk
- SOC 2 requires documented approval for changes
- Proper approval prevents unauthorized or erroneous changes
- Multi-level approval scales oversight to change impact
- Automated approval routing reduces delays
- Audit trails demonstrate compliance to regulators
- Clear escalation paths prevent process bottlenecks

audits.name: Configuration Change Control Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the formal change control processes applied to
configuration modifications. It evaluates:
- Change request and approval workflows
- Change authorization and audit trails
- Pre-change impact assessment
- Change implementation procedures
- Post-change verification
- Emergency change procedures
- Change rollback capabilities
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration change control is fundamental to operational stability:
- CMMI CM SP 2.1 requires tracking and controlling changes to CIs
- ITIL Change Management ensures changes are authorized and controlled
- 85% of production incidents are attributed to changes (Gartner)
- Uncontrolled changes lead to configuration drift and incidents
- Compliance frameworks require demonstrable change control
- Audit trails are essential for forensics and compliance
- Proper change control reduces mean time to

audits.name: Configuration Review Process Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the review processes applied to configuration changes
before deployment. It evaluates:
- Technical review requirements and coverage
- Security review for sensitive configurations
- Peer review practices and guidelines
- Review checklists and criteria
- Review tooling and automation
- Review turnaround time
- Review quality metrics
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration review catches errors before they cause incidents:
- 85% of production incidents are attributed to changes (Gartner)
- Peer review is proven to detect errors that automated testing misses
- Security review prevents misconfigurations that create vulnerabilities
- CMMI requires formal review of configuration items
- SOC 2 requires review of changes before production
- Review quality directly impacts system reliability
- Clear review criteria enable consistent quality

audits.name: Configuration Rollback Procedures Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines rollback capabilities and procedures for configuration
changes. It evaluates:
- Rollback automation and tooling
- Rollback procedure documentation
- Rollback testing and validation
- Rollback triggers and decision criteria
- Partial vs full rollback capabilities
- Rollback timing and SLAs
- Post-rollback verification
audits.why_it_matters:
Rollback capability is essential for operational resilience:
- ITIL recommends remediation plans for all changes
- Fast rollback reduces incident duration and impact
- Untested rollback procedures often fail when needed
- Clear rollback criteria prevent delayed responses
- Automated rollback enables rapid recovery
- Partial rollback minimizes disruption
- 12-factor app disposability principle supports quick rollback

audits.name: Configuration Version Control Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines version control practices for configuration items
across the software stack. It evaluates:
- All configurations stored in version control
- Meaningful commit messages for config changes
- Branch strategies for configuration changes
- Tag usage for configuration versions
- Configuration history accessibility
- Diff and comparison capabilities
- Integration with CI/CD for config deployment
audits.why_it_matters:
Version control is foundational to configuration management:
- 12-factor app Factor III requires config stored outside code, but
  Factor I requires version control for all assets
- Version control provides audit trail required by SOC 2, ISO 27001
- History enables understanding when, why, and who changed configs
- Diff capability enables change review and impact assessment
- Tags enable reproducible deployments and rollbacks
- Branch strategies enable parallel development and testing

audits.name: Configuration Baseline Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the establishment and maintenance of configuration
baselines representing known-good system states. It evaluates:
- Baseline definition and documentation
- Baseline versioning and history
- Baseline approval processes
- Environment-specific baselines
- Baseline comparison capabilities
- Restoration procedures from baseline
- Baseline testing and validation
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration baselines are essential for reliable system management:
- CMMI CM SP 1.3 requires establishing and maintaining baselines of
  configuration items
- ITIL defines baselines as the recorded state of a CI at a specific
  point in time for comparison and rollback
- Without baselines, there is no reference point for drift detection
- Incident recovery requires known-good configuration states
- Compliance audits need documented baseline configurations

audits.name: Configuration Classification Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the classification of configuration items according
to their type, sensitivity, and criticality. It evaluates:
- Configuration type taxonomy (application, infrastructure, security)
- Sensitivity classification (public, internal, confidential, secret)
- Criticality levels for change impact assessment
- Handling requirements based on classification
- Classification metadata and tagging
- Classification-based access controls
- Classification review and updates
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration classification enables appropriate handling and controls:
- CMMI requires identifying and classifying configuration items
- Security configurations require stricter change controls than
  non-sensitive settings
- Classification drives approval workflows and access permissions
- Sensitive configurations (secrets, credentials) need special handling
- Criticality classification enables proper change impact assessment
- Compliance frameworks require demonstrating configuration controls

audits.name: Configuration Dependencies Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the mapping and tracking of dependencies between
configuration items across the system. It evaluates:
- Inter-configuration dependencies (config A requires config B)
- Service-to-configuration dependencies
- Configuration ordering requirements
- Circular dependency detection
- External service configuration dependencies
- Environment variable dependency chains
- Infrastructure configuration dependencies
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration dependency mapping is critical for safe operations:
- ITIL CMDB requires relationship mapping between CIs for impact analysis
- Untracked dependencies cause cascading failures during changes
- Change impact assessment depends on complete dependency graphs
- Circular dependencies create initialization deadlocks
- Dependency awareness enables proper change sequencing
- Incident response requires understanding configuration relationships
- Compliance requires demonstrating configurati

audits.name: Configuration Discovery Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the systematic identification and cataloging of all
configuration items (CIs) across the software stack. It evaluates:
- Completeness of configuration item inventory
- Discovery mechanisms for identifying new configurations
- Classification of configuration types (application, infrastructure, data)
- Relationships between configuration items
- Configuration item attributes and metadata
- Automated vs manual discovery processes
- Coverage across all environments and systems
audits.why_it_matters:
Comprehensive configuration discovery is foundational to configuration management:
- CMMI Configuration Management (CM) requires identification of configuration
  items to be placed under configuration management
- ITIL Configuration Management Database (CMDB) requires complete CI inventory
- 12-factor app Factor III mandates storing config in the environment, making
  discovery essential for understanding system state
- Without complete discovery, configuration drift goes undetected
- Incident

audits.name: Configuration Documentation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the documentation completeness and quality for
configuration items across the system. It evaluates:
- Configuration parameter descriptions and purpose
- Valid value ranges and defaults
- Dependencies between configurations
- Usage examples and common patterns
- Environment-specific documentation
- Schema documentation for complex configurations
- Changelog and version history documentation
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration documentation is essential for safe operation:
- 12-factor app principles require clear configuration boundaries,
  which documentation supports
- Undocumented configurations lead to misconfiguration incidents
- New team members cannot safely modify unknown configurations
- Incident response requires understanding configuration impact
- Compliance audits need documented configuration purposes
- Self-documenting configurations reduce operational burden
- Documentation enables automa

audits.name: Configuration Naming Conventions Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines naming conventions applied to configuration items
across the software stack. It evaluates:
- Consistency of configuration file naming patterns
- Environment variable naming standards (SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE)
- Configuration key naming conventions
- Namespace and prefix usage for grouping
- Naming clarity and self-documentation
- Avoidance of ambiguous or conflicting names
- Alignment with industry conventions
audits.why_it_matters:
Consistent configuration naming is essential for maintainability:
- 12-factor app Factor III recommends strict separation of config,
  which requires clear naming to identify configuration sources
- Inconsistent naming increases cognitive load and error risk
- Ambiguous names lead to misconfiguration incidents
- Automated discovery and validation depend on predictable naming
- Clear naming enables self-documenting configuration
- Teams can onboard faster with consistent conventions
- Duplicate o

audits.name: Configuration Ownership Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the assignment and tracking of configuration item
ownership across the organization. It evaluates:
- Ownership assignment for all configuration items
- Clear ownership metadata and documentation
- Ownership transfer procedures
- Team vs individual ownership models
- Owner responsibilities and accountability
- Ownership for third-party and external configurations
- Escalation paths for ownership disputes
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration ownership is essential for accountability:
- ITIL requires every CI to have a clearly identified owner
- Ownership determines who approves changes to configurations
- Unowned configurations lack accountability for quality and security
- Incident response requires knowing who to contact for config issues
- Compliance audits need documented ownership chains
- Change impact assessment requires owner consultation
- Configuration deprecation needs owner decision authority

audits.name: Configuration Audit Trail Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the audit trail for configuration changes ensuring
compliance and accountability. It evaluates:
- Audit log completeness for all change types
- Audit record immutability and integrity
- Audit data retention compliance
- Audit log accessibility and searchability
- Tamper detection for audit records
- Integration with SIEM and monitoring
- Compliance with regulatory requirements
audits.why_it_matters:
Audit trails are essential for compliance and security:
- SOC 2 CC7.2 requires logging of configuration changes
- HIPAA, PCI-DSS, GDPR require audit trail maintenance
- Forensic investigation depends on complete audit records
- Accountability requires attributable change records
- Compliance audits need accessible audit data
- Tamper-evident logs prevent evidence destruction

audits.name: Configuration Change Tracking Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the tracking and recording of configuration changes
across the system. It evaluates:
- Change event capture completeness
- Change attribution (who, what, when)
- Before/after state recording
- Change reason documentation
- Change history retention
- Change search and query capabilities
- Integration with incident management
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration change tracking is essential for operational visibility:
- CMMI CM SP 3.1 requires recording status of configuration items
- ITIL Configuration Status Accounting tracks CI states over time
- Change correlation with incidents enables root cause analysis
- Audit compliance requires complete change history
- Change tracking enables trend analysis and improvement
- Forensic investigation depends on accurate change records
- Troubleshooting requires understanding recent changes

audits.name: CMDB Integration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines integration of configuration data with Configuration
Management Database systems. It evaluates:
- CMDB data population and accuracy
- Automated discovery and synchronization
- CI relationship mapping in CMDB
- Data quality and completeness
- CMDB integration with change management
- Federation with external configuration sources
- CMDB accessibility and usability
audits.why_it_matters:
CMDB integration provides unified configuration visibility:
- ITIL requires CMDB as authoritative source for CI information
- Integrated CMDB enables impact analysis for changes
- Siloed configuration data prevents unified management
- Automated population ensures data accuracy
- Relationship mapping supports dependency analysis
- CMDB supports incident and problem management

audits.name: Configuration Metrics Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the metrics and KPIs used to measure configuration
management effectiveness. It evaluates:
- Change volume and frequency metrics
- Change success and failure rates
- Configuration drift metrics
- Time to implement changes
- Approval cycle time metrics
- Compliance and policy adherence rates
- Configuration-related incident correlation
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration metrics enable data-driven improvement:
- CMMI requires measurement for process improvement
- ITIL recommends CSFs and KPIs for configuration management
- Metrics identify bottlenecks and improvement opportunities
- Trend analysis enables proactive management
- Incident correlation reveals configuration-related issues
- Benchmarking enables comparison and goal setting
- Reporting to management requires quantifiable data

audits.name: Configuration Reporting Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the reporting capabilities for configuration status
across the organization. It evaluates:
- Configuration inventory reports
- Change activity reports
- Compliance status reporting
- Drift and variance reporting
- Report automation and scheduling
- Stakeholder report distribution
- Report accuracy and timeliness
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration reporting enables informed decision-making:
- ITIL Configuration Status Accounting includes reporting requirements
- Management needs visibility into configuration state
- Compliance audits require configuration reports
- Trend reporting enables proactive improvements
- Stakeholders need accessible configuration information
- Report automation reduces manual effort
- Accurate reporting supports governance

audits.name: Configuration Status Accounting Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the configuration status accounting function that
records and reports on CI states throughout their lifecycle. It evaluates:
- CI status definitions and state model
- Status transition tracking
- Current status accuracy
- Historical status records
- Status reporting capabilities
- Status-based metrics and KPIs
- Integration with CMDB
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration Status Accounting is a core ITIL practice:
- CMMI CM SP 3.1 and 3.2 require recording and reporting CI status
- ITIL CSA provides information on current and historical states
- Status awareness enables change impact assessment
- Accurate status supports capacity planning
- Status history aids troubleshooting and audit
- Metrics from status data drive improvements

audits.name: Configuration Compliance Checking Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines compliance checking mechanisms for configuration
items against policies and standards. It evaluates:
- Policy-as-code implementation
- Compliance rule coverage
- CIS benchmark conformance
- Security best practice checking
- Regulatory compliance verification
- Compliance reporting and dashboards
- Remediation guidance and automation
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration compliance is essential for security and governance:
- Non-compliant configurations create security vulnerabilities
- Regulatory frameworks require demonstrable compliance
- CIS benchmarks provide industry-standard baselines
- Policy-as-code enables consistent enforcement
- Compliance checking prevents misconfigurations reaching production
- Audit readiness requires continuous compliance monitoring

audits.name: Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the formal configuration audit process verifying
CI integrity and baseline conformance. It evaluates:
- Functional Configuration Audit (FCA) processes
- Physical Configuration Audit (PCA) processes
- Baseline comparison procedures
- Audit scheduling and frequency
- Audit findings tracking and resolution
- Audit documentation and reporting
- Audit independence and objectivity
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration audits verify system integrity:
- CMMI CM SP 3.2 requires performing configuration audits
- FCA verifies configurations meet functional requirements
- PCA verifies configurations match documentation
- Audits detect unauthorized changes and drift
- Regular audits ensure ongoing compliance
- Audit findings drive improvement actions
- Independence ensures objective assessment

audits.name: Configuration Validation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the validation mechanisms for configuration files
and values. It evaluates:
- Schema validation for configuration files
- Value range and constraint validation
- Type checking for configuration values
- Required field validation
- Cross-reference validation
- CI/CD integration of validation
- Pre-deployment validation gates
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration validation prevents deployment failures:
- Invalid configurations cause runtime errors and outages
- Early validation catches errors before deployment
- Schema validation ensures structural correctness
- Constraint validation prevents out-of-range values
- 12-factor app requires explicit and validated config
- Validation reduces configuration-related incidents
- Automated validation scales with development velocity

audits.name: Configuration Drift Detection Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the capabilities for detecting configuration drift
from desired state. It evaluates:
- Drift detection mechanisms and tools
- Baseline comparison capabilities
- Real-time vs scheduled drift detection
- Drift alerting and notification
- Drift categorization and prioritization
- Drift remediation automation
- Drift trend analysis
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration drift undermines system reliability and security:
- CMMI CM SP 3.2 requires verifying CI integrity
- Drift represents unauthorized or untracked changes
- Security misconfigurations often result from drift
- Compliance violations may go undetected without drift detection
- GitOps principles require reconciliation with desired state
- Drift accumulation increases incident risk
- 12-factor app immutability prevents drift by design

audits.name: Configuration Integrity Verification Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines integrity verification mechanisms for configuration
items. It evaluates:
- Checksum verification for configurations
- Digital signatures for configuration packages
- Tamper detection mechanisms
- Integrity monitoring tools
- Supply chain integrity for configurations
- File integrity monitoring (FIM)
- Verification automation and alerting
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration integrity is essential for security:
- Tampering with configurations enables attacks
- Supply chain attacks target configuration packages
- Integrity verification detects unauthorized modifications
- Compliance frameworks require integrity controls
- FIM is a key security control for sensitive configs
- Signatures ensure authenticity of config sources
- Early tamper detection limits damage

audits.name: Configuration Testing and Verification Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the testing and verification of configuration
changes before production deployment. It evaluates:
- Configuration testing environments
- Automated configuration testing
- Smoke testing after config deployment
- Integration testing with config changes
- Configuration rollout testing
- Test coverage for configuration scenarios
- Pre-production validation gates
audits.why_it_matters:
Configuration testing prevents production incidents:
- Untested configs are a leading cause of outages
- Testing catches errors before they impact users
- 12-factor app requires dev/prod parity for config testing
- Automated testing enables rapid config deployment
- Test environments validate config behavior
- Pre-production gates prevent bad configs reaching prod
- Testing builds confidence in configuration changes

audits.name: Configuration Templating Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines configuration templating practices for generating
environment-specific configurations from shared templates. It evaluates
template usage, parameterization, and template management.
audits.why_it_matters:
Templates enable DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) configuration management.
Without templates, configurations are duplicated and diverge. Parameterized
templates ensure consistency while supporting environment differences.

audits.name: Environment Isolation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines isolation between environments to prevent cross-
environment impact. It evaluates network isolation, data separation,
credential isolation, and resource boundaries.
audits.why_it_matters:
Environment isolation prevents cascading failures and data breaches.
Development accessing production data violates privacy. Shared resources
create dependencies that cause cross-environment failures.

audits.name: Environment Lifecycle Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines management of environment lifecycle from creation
through decommissioning. It evaluates creation procedures, maintenance,
temporary environment cleanup, and secure decommissioning.
audits.why_it_matters:
Unmanaged environment lifecycle creates waste and security risk.
Orphaned environments consume resources and may be forgotten attack
surfaces. Proper decommissioning ensures data is securely removed.

audits.name: Environment Parity Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines consistency between development, staging, and
production environments. It evaluates:
- Configuration structure parity across environments
- Infrastructure configuration alignment
- Service version consistency
- Database schema synchronization
- Third-party service parity
- Environment-specific vs shared configurations
- Parity verification automation
audits.why_it_matters:
Environment parity is essential for reliable deployments:
- 12-factor app Factor X requires keeping dev, staging, and prod similar
- Environment drift causes "works on my machine" problems
- Differences create surprises in production deployment
- Parity enables accurate testing in non-production
- Compliance may require consistent controls across environments
- Parity reduces deployment risk and incident likelihood

audits.name: Environment Promotion Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the controlled promotion of configurations through
environment tiers. It evaluates promotion pipelines, approval gates,
promotion validation, and rollback capabilities.
audits.why_it_matters:
Controlled promotion ensures configurations are validated before reaching
production. Direct-to-production changes bypass validation. ITIL recommends
staged change promotion through controlled environments.

audits.name: Environment Provisioning Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines environment provisioning practices through
infrastructure as code. It evaluates IaC coverage, provisioning
automation, environment templates, and reproducibility.
audits.why_it_matters:
IaC enables reproducible and consistent environment provisioning.
Manual provisioning creates drift and inconsistency. Automated
provisioning supports rapid scaling and disaster recovery.

audits.name: Environment Variable Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines environment variable management practices per
12-factor app principles. It evaluates env var usage, documentation,
validation, default handling, and security of sensitive variables.
audits.why_it_matters:
12-factor app Factor III mandates storing config in environment variables.
Poor env var management causes deployment failures and security issues.
Undocumented env vars create operational knowledge gaps.

audits.name: Feature Flag Governance Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines governance policies and controls for feature
flag management. It evaluates approval processes, access controls,
audit logging, and change management for flags.
audits.why_it_matters:
Feature flags can enable/disable production functionality. Uncontrolled
flag changes are effectively uncontrolled deployments. Governance ensures
flags are managed with appropriate oversight.

audits.name: Feature Flag Lifecycle Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines feature flag lifecycle management from creation
through retirement. It evaluates flag documentation, ownership,
expiration policies, and cleanup processes.
audits.why_it_matters:
Unmanaged feature flags accumulate technical debt. Old flags create
confusion and code complexity. Proper lifecycle management keeps flags
purposeful and temporary, not permanent code clutter.

audits.name: Feature Flag Monitoring Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines monitoring and observability for feature flags.
It evaluates flag evaluation metrics, impact monitoring, error tracking,
and performance monitoring for flagged features.
audits.why_it_matters:
Monitoring enables understanding flag impact. Without monitoring,
flag-related issues go undetected. Metrics help decide when to
fully roll out or roll back flagged features.

audits.name: Feature Flag Testing Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines testing practices for feature flagged code.
It evaluates whether both flag states are tested, flag mocking
approaches, and integration testing with flags.
audits.why_it_matters:
Feature flags create multiple code paths that must all be tested.
Untested flag states cause production bugs. Testing both states
ensures functionality regardless of flag configuration.

audits.name: Stale Feature Flags Audit
audits.description:
This audit identifies stale feature flags that are no longer needed.
It evaluates flags past their expiration, flags always on/off,
and orphaned flags with no references.
audits.why_it_matters:
Stale flags create code complexity and maintenance burden. Flags that
are always on/off serve no purpose. Orphaned flags cause confusion.
Cleaning up stale flags improves code quality and reduces risk.

audits.name: Feature Flag Targeting Rules Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines feature flag targeting rules used for controlled
rollouts. It evaluates user targeting, percentage rollouts, segment
targeting, and rule complexity.
audits.why_it_matters:
Targeting rules control who sees features. Complex or incorrect rules
cause unexpected behavior. Proper targeting enables safe rollouts.
Audit ensures rules work as intended.

audits.name: Blue-Green Deployment Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines blue-green deployment configurations. It evaluates
environment parity between blue and green, traffic switching mechanisms,
validation procedures, and resource management for parallel environments.
audits.why_it_matters:
Blue-green deployments provide zero-downtime releases and instant rollback.
Misconfiguration can cause traffic routing issues, resource waste, or
failed cutover. Proper configuration ensures reliable deployment switching.

audits.name: Canary Deployment Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines canary deployment configurations used for gradual
rollouts. It evaluates traffic splitting configurations, promotion
criteria, rollback triggers, and monitoring integration for canary
releases.
audits.why_it_matters:
Canary deployments reduce release risk by exposing changes to a subset
of users first. Misconfigured canaries can either fail to catch issues
or accidentally expose too many users to problematic releases.
Proper configuration ensures effective risk mitigation.

audits.name: Deployment Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines deployment configuration parameters including
resource requests/limits, health checks, replica counts, and
deployment strategies. It ensures deployments are configured for
reliability and appropriate resource utilization.
audits.why_it_matters:
Deployment configuration directly impacts application reliability
and resource costs. Misconfigured health checks cause bad rollouts,
incorrect resource limits cause OOM kills or waste, and wrong
replica counts affect availability.

audits.name: Progressive Delivery Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines progressive delivery configurations that combine
feature flags, canary deployments, and metrics analysis for controlled
releases. It evaluates the integration of deployment strategies with
observability and automated decision-making.
audits.why_it_matters:
Progressive delivery represents the state of the art in safe releases,
combining multiple techniques for risk reduction. Poor configuration
can negate these benefits or create complex failure modes. Proper
setup ensures each layer provides its intended protection.

audits.name: Release Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines how release configurations are managed across the
deployment pipeline. It evaluates release versioning, environment-specific
configuration handling, release metadata, and configuration promotion
practices through deployment stages.
audits.why_it_matters:
Release configuration errors are a leading cause of deployment failures.
Misconfigured releases can cause outages, data corruption, or security
vulnerabilities. Proper release configuration management ensures
consistent, repeatable, and safe deployments.

audits.name: Rollback Configuration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines rollback configuration and capabilities for
deployments. It evaluates rollback procedures, artifact retention,
database migration rollback, and automated rollback triggers.
audits.why_it_matters:
Every deployment needs a rollback plan. When releases fail, quick
rollback minimizes user impact. Without proper rollback configuration,
teams scramble during incidents, extending outages and increasing risk.

audits.name: Secret Access Control Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines access controls for secrets ensuring appropriate
authorization and least privilege. It evaluates RBAC policies, service
account access, human access controls, and access audit logging.
audits.why_it_matters:
Secret access must follow least privilege. Overly broad access exposes
secrets to unnecessary risk. Proper access controls limit blast radius
of compromised accounts and ensure compliance.

audits.name: Secret Detection Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines secret detection mechanisms to prevent accidental
exposure of credentials in code. It evaluates pre-commit hooks,
CI scanning, secret detection tools, and historical secret scanning.
audits.why_it_matters:
Secrets committed to code are exposed in git history forever. Detection
at commit time prevents exposure. Historical scanning finds past exposure.
Automated detection catches secrets that humans miss.

audits.name: Secret Encryption Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines encryption of secrets at rest and in transit.
It evaluates encryption algorithms, key management, TLS configuration,
and encrypted secret storage.
audits.why_it_matters:
Unencrypted secrets are exposed if storage is compromised. Encryption
at rest protects stored secrets. Encryption in transit prevents
interception. Strong key management is essential for encryption value.

audits.name: Secret Injection Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines how secrets are injected into applications at
runtime. It evaluates injection patterns, sidecar injectors,
init containers, environment variable injection, and file mounts.
audits.why_it_matters:
Proper secret injection keeps secrets out of configs and images.
Secrets should be retrieved at runtime, not baked in. Injection
patterns affect security, portability, and operational complexity.

audits.name: Secret Rotation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines secret rotation practices to limit credential
exposure window. It evaluates rotation policies, automation,
zero-downtime rotation, and rotation monitoring.
audits.why_it_matters:
Secret rotation limits the damage from compromised credentials.
PCI-DSS requires password rotation. Long-lived secrets have extended
exposure windows. Automated rotation ensures consistent compliance.

audits.name: Vault Integration Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines integration with secret management systems for
secure storage and retrieval of secrets. It evaluates vault deployment,
authentication methods, access policies, audit logging, and secret
injection patterns.
audits.why_it_matters:
Centralized secret management is essential for security. Secrets in code
or config files are exposed. Vault provides secure storage, access control,
audit logging, and rotation capabilities that protect sensitive data.

audits.name: Account Structure Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines cloud account/subscription/project structure
and its effectiveness for cost management. It evaluates hierarchy
design, account strategy, billing consolidation, and alignment
with organizational and cost allocation needs.
audits.why_it_matters:
Account structure is foundational to cost management. A well-designed
structure enables clear cost attribution, appropriate governance,
and efficient billing. Poor structure creates confusion, hinders
visibility, and complicates chargeback.

audits.name: Cloud Budget Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines cloud budget management practices including
budget definition, threshold alerting, automated actions, and
alignment between budgets and actual organizational structure.
It evaluates the effectiveness of budget controls.
audits.why_it_matters:
Budgets are the primary mechanism for controlling cloud costs.
Without effective budget management, organizations frequently
experience cost overruns, surprise bills, and loss of financial
predictability. Proper budgeting enables accountability and
informed decision-making.

audits.name: Cloud Cost Tooling Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the cloud cost management tooling ecosystem
including evaluation of tool capabilities, coverage, integration,
and effectiveness. It identifies gaps and optimization opportunities
in the tooling landscape.
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective tooling is essential for scalable cost management. The
right tools automate tedious tasks, provide actionable insights,
and enable proactive optimization. Poor tooling choices waste
both tool spend and staff time.

audits.name: Cost Governance Policies Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines cloud cost governance policies including
spending limits, approval workflows, resource creation policies,
and preventive controls. It evaluates the effectiveness of
governance in controlling costs while enabling innovation.
audits.why_it_matters:
Cost governance provides guardrails that prevent runaway spending
while enabling teams to move quickly. Without effective governance,
organizations either over-control (slowing innovation) or under-
control (enabling waste). Balanced governance optimizes both.

audits.name: FinOps Maturity Audit
audits.description:
This audit assesses the organization's FinOps maturity against
the FinOps Foundation framework. It evaluates capabilities across
the Inform, Optimize, and Operate phases, as well as cultural
and organizational dimensions.
audits.why_it_matters:
FinOps maturity directly correlates with cloud cost efficiency.
Organizations at higher maturity levels demonstrate 20-40% better
cost efficiency than those at lower levels. Understanding current
maturity guides investment in capability improvement.

audits.name: Multi-Cloud Cost Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines cost management practices in multi-cloud
environments. It evaluates unified cost visibility, normalized
reporting, cross-cloud governance, and provider-specific
optimization across AWS, Azure, GCP, and other cloud providers.
audits.why_it_matters:
Multi-cloud environments create cost management complexity.
Without unified visibility, organizations cannot compare costs,
make informed placement decisions, or implement consistent
governance. Provider-specific optimization opportunities may
be missed.

audits.name: Chargeback Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines chargeback processes where IT and cloud
costs are directly charged to consuming business units,
affecting their P&L. It evaluates allocation methodology,
accuracy, fairness, and organizational acceptance.
audits.why_it_matters:
Chargeback creates true financial accountability by making
cost consumers directly responsible. When done well, it drives
cost-conscious behavior and efficient resource use. When done
poorly, it creates friction, disputes, and suboptimal behavior.

audits.name: Cost Centers Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines cost center structure and its alignment
with IT and cloud cost allocation. It evaluates whether cost
centers accurately represent the organizational hierarchy,
enable appropriate cost tracking, and support financial
reporting requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Cost centers are the organizational units to which costs are
allocated. If cost centers do not align with how the organization
operates and makes decisions, cost allocation is ineffective.
Proper cost center structure enables meaningful accountability
and reporting.

audits.name: Environment Cost Tracking Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the ability to track costs by environment
type (production, staging, development, test, etc.). It
evaluates tagging, attribution, and analysis capabilities
for environment-based cost optimization.
audits.why_it_matters:
Environment-level cost tracking reveals optimization opportunities.
Non-production environments often consume 40-60% of cloud spend
but are frequently over-provisioned. Understanding environment
costs enables right-sizing and scheduled shutdown strategies.

audits.name: Project Cost Tracking Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the ability to track costs by project,
initiative, or product. It evaluates tagging practices,
tracking mechanisms, and the quality of project-level cost
data for investment decisions and accountability.
audits.why_it_matters:
Project-level cost tracking enables understanding of true
investment costs, ROI analysis, and go/no-go decisions.
Without project tracking, organizations cannot determine
which initiatives are consuming resources or delivering
value.

audits.name: Shared Cost Allocation Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines how shared costs (platforms, infrastructure,
support functions) are allocated across consumers. It evaluates
allocation methodology fairness, accuracy, and transparency for
costs that cannot be directly attributed.
audits.why_it_matters:
Shared costs often represent 20-40% of IT spend and are the most
contentious aspect of cost allocation. Unfair or opaque shared
cost allocation creates disputes, gaming behavior, and undermines
trust in chargeback. Fair allocation requires thoughtful methodology.

audits.name: Showback Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines showback processes where IT and cloud
costs are displayed to business units for awareness without
directly impacting their financial statements. It evaluates
visibility, accessibility, and behavioral impact.
audits.why_it_matters:
Showback creates cost awareness as a precursor to or alternative
to chargeback. It helps teams understand the costs they generate
without the complexity of financial charges. When effective,
showback drives cost-conscious behavior through transparency
rather than financial impact.

audits.name: Network Cost Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines network-related costs including data transfer,
NAT Gateway fees, VPN/Direct Connect charges, and cross-region
traffic. It identifies architectural patterns that create excessive
network costs and recommends optimizations.
audits.why_it_matters:
Network costs are often overlooked but can represent a significant
portion of cloud spend. Data egress charges, NAT Gateway processing
fees, and cross-region transfer costs can surprise organizations.
Architectural decisions dramatically impact network costs.

audits.name: Reserved Instances Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the organization's use of Reserved Instances,
Savings Plans, and other commitment-based discounts. It evaluates
coverage levels, utilization rates, expiration schedules, and
identifies opportunities for additional commitments or adjustments.
audits.why_it_matters:
Commitment-based discounts (RIs, Savings Plans) offer 30-75% savings
compared to on-demand pricing. However, poorly managed commitments
can result in wasted spend (unused reservations) or missed savings
(low coverage). Optimal commitment management is a core FinOps
capability with significant financial impact.

audits.name: Rightsizing Audit
audits.description:
This audit identifies compute and storage resources that are
over-provisioned relative to their actual utilization. It analyzes
CPU, memory, storage, and network utilization patterns to recommend
appropriate sizing that maintains performance while reducing costs.
audits.why_it_matters:
Over-provisioned resources are one of the largest sources of cloud
waste. The FinOps Foundation estimates that 30-40% of cloud resources
are oversized. Rightsizing can achieve 20-30% cost reduction without
impacting application performance when done correctly.

audits.name: Savings Plans Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the organization's use of AWS Savings Plans
(or equivalent Azure/GCP offerings) including Compute Savings Plans,
EC2 Instance Savings Plans, and SageMaker Savings Plans. It analyzes
coverage levels, utilization rates, and optimal plan configuration.
audits.why_it_matters:
Savings Plans offer up to 72% discount with greater flexibility than
Reserved Instances. Compute Savings Plans automatically apply across
instance families, regions, and compute services. Proper Savings Plan
management can save millions annually while maintaining architectural
flexibility.

audits.name: Spot Instances Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the organization's use of Spot Instances
(AWS), Spot VMs (Azure), or Preemptible VMs (GCP) for workloads
that can tolerate interruption. It evaluates Spot adoption,
interruption handling, diversification strategy, and savings realized.
audits.why_it_matters:
Spot Instances offer up to 90% discount compared to on-demand pricing.
Many workloads (batch processing, CI/CD, stateless services, dev/test)
can run on Spot with proper interruption handling. Organizations not
leveraging Spot are leaving significant savings on the table.

audits.name: Storage Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines storage costs across object storage, block
storage, file systems, and databases. It evaluates storage tier
selection, lifecycle policies, data retention practices, and
identifies opportunities to reduce costs through tiering,
compression, and cleanup.
audits.why_it_matters:
Storage costs often grow unchecked as data accumulates. The cost
difference between storage tiers can be 10-20x (e.g., S3 Standard
vs Glacier). Proper lifecycle management and tier selection can
significantly reduce storage costs while maintaining data accessibility.

audits.name: Billing Data Quality Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the quality and reliability of billing data
used for cost management. It evaluates data completeness, accuracy,
timeliness, and consistency across sources. The audit also assesses
data pipelines that transform and aggregate billing information.
audits.why_it_matters:
All FinOps decisions depend on accurate billing data. Poor data
quality leads to incorrect reports, flawed optimization decisions,
and disputed chargebacks. Data quality issues compound over time,
making historical analysis unreliable and forecasting inaccurate.

audits.name: Cost Anomaly Detection Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the organization's capability to automatically
detect and respond to cost anomalies. It evaluates alerting thresholds,
detection algorithms, notification routing, and the effectiveness of
the anomaly response process.
audits.why_it_matters:
Cloud costs can spike unexpectedly due to misconfigurations, runaway
processes, security incidents, or legitimate traffic increases.
Without effective anomaly detection, these spikes may go unnoticed
until the monthly bill arrives, by which time significant waste may
have occurred. Early detection enables rapid response and cost savings.

audits.name: Cost Attribution Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines how effectively costs are attributed to their
consumers across multiple dimensions: applications, teams, business
units, environments, and projects. It evaluates attribution accuracy,
identifies unattributed costs, and assesses the methodology used for
shared cost distribution.
audits.why_it_matters:
Accurate cost attribution enables informed decision-making at all
organizational levels. When costs cannot be traced to their source,
teams lack accountability and cannot optimize their spending. Poor
attribution leads to budget disputes, over-provisioning, and inability
to measure true ROI of technology investments.

audits.name: Cost Transparency Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines how effectively cost information is communicated
and made accessible throughout the organization. It evaluates cost
reporting clarity, stakeholder access to relevant data, and the
ability of teams to understand and act on their cost information.
audits.why_it_matters:
Cost transparency is essential for creating a cost-aware culture.
When teams cannot easily access and understand their costs, they
cannot make informed trade-offs or optimize their spending. The
FinOps Foundation emphasizes that transparency is a prerequisite
for accountability and continuous improvement.

audits.name: Resource Tagging Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the completeness and consistency of resource tagging
across cloud infrastructure. It evaluates mandatory tag compliance,
tag naming conventions, tag value standardization, and identifies
untagged or improperly tagged resources that hinder cost attribution.
audits.why_it_matters:
Resource tagging is the foundation of cloud cost visibility. Without
consistent tagging, organizations cannot accurately attribute costs
to business units, applications, environments, or projects. Poor tagging
leads to orphaned costs, disputed chargebacks, and inability to make
informed optimization decisions. The FinOps Foundation identifies tagging
as a critical capability for achieving cost transparency.

audits.name: Unit Cost Tracking Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the organization's capability to calculate,
track, and report unit economics for cloud infrastructure. It
evaluates metrics like cost per transaction, cost per customer,
cost per API call, and cost per deployment, enabling the connection
of infrastructure spending to business value.
audits.why_it_matters:
Unit costs provide the bridge between infrastructure spending and
business outcomes. Without unit cost metrics, organizations cannot
determine if their cloud spend is efficient relative to the value
it produces. Unit costs enable meaningful trend analysis, capacity
planning, and optimization prioritization based on ROI.

audits.name: Approval Workflows Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines approval workflows for cloud and IT
spending including spending thresholds, approval authority
levels, escalation paths, and the balance between control
and agility.
audits.why_it_matters:
Approval workflows provide financial control while enabling
business operations. Overly restrictive workflows slow
innovation; too-permissive workflows create risk. Well-designed
workflows balance control with agility and provide appropriate
oversight for spending decisions.

audits.name: Budget Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines IT and cloud budget management processes
including budget planning methodology, tracking mechanisms,
variance analysis, and integration with corporate financial
planning. It evaluates the maturity and effectiveness of
budget governance.
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective budget management ensures financial predictability
and accountability. Poor budget practices lead to overruns,
surprise costs, and inability to demonstrate IT value. Good
budgeting enables informed investment decisions and builds
trust with finance leadership.

audits.name: Financial Reporting Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines IT and cloud cost financial reporting
including report content, quality, timeliness, distribution,
and alignment with corporate financial standards. It evaluates
reports for different audiences from executives to engineers.
audits.why_it_matters:
Financial reporting enables informed decision-making at all
levels. Poor reporting hides problems, prevents optimization,
and reduces trust. Good reporting provides actionable insights,
builds credibility, and enables accountability.

audits.name: Forecasting Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines cloud and IT cost forecasting capabilities
including forecasting methodology, accuracy tracking, inputs
and assumptions, and integration with business planning. It
evaluates both short-term operational and long-term strategic
forecasting.
audits.why_it_matters:
Accurate forecasting enables proactive financial management,
better commitment decisions (RIs, Savings Plans), and alignment
with business planning. Poor forecasting leads to budget
surprises, missed optimization opportunities, and reduced
credibility with finance.

audits.name: Spending Controls Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines spending controls including preventive
controls (limits, restrictions) and detective controls
(monitoring, alerting). It evaluates the effectiveness of
controls in preventing unplanned or unauthorized spending.
audits.why_it_matters:
Spending controls prevent runaway costs and unauthorized
spending. Without controls, cloud costs can spiral quickly
due to misconfigurations, crypto mining attacks, or simple
mistakes. Effective controls catch issues before they become
expensive problems.

audits.name: Vendor Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines technology vendor management practices
including contract management, renewal processes, negotiation
effectiveness, and relationship management. It evaluates the
organization's ability to optimize vendor relationships.
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective vendor management can yield 10-30% cost savings
through better negotiations, consolidated purchases, and
proactive renewals. Poor vendor management leads to unfavorable
terms, missed opportunities, and fragmented spending.

audits.name: Cloud License Mobility Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines the ability to use existing on-premises
software licenses in cloud environments. It evaluates BYOL
(Bring Your Own License) rights, license mobility through
Software Assurance, and compliance with cloud-specific
licensing requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Proper use of license mobility can save 40-70% on cloud
software costs compared to cloud-included licensing. However,
improper BYOL creates compliance risk. Understanding mobility
rights enables cost optimization while maintaining compliance.

audits.name: License Compliance Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines software license compliance across the
organization. It compares software deployments against owned
licenses, identifies compliance gaps, and ensures license terms
are being met including cloud mobility rights and virtual
environments.
audits.why_it_matters:
License non-compliance creates significant financial and legal
risk. Vendor audits can result in substantial penalties, back-
payments, and legal action. Over-licensing wastes money. Proper
license management balances compliance risk with cost efficiency.

audits.name: License Optimization Audit
audits.description:
This audit identifies opportunities to reduce software licensing
costs through optimization strategies including right-sizing,
alternative license types, vendor consolidation, and renegotiation.
It balances cost reduction with operational needs.
audits.why_it_matters:
Software licensing is often 15-30% of IT budgets. Many organizations
over-license by 20-40%. License optimization can yield significant
savings without impacting operations. Understanding license economics
enables better negotiation and procurement decisions.

audits.name: SaaS Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines SaaS subscription management including
discovery of all SaaS applications, utilization tracking,
duplicate application identification, and optimization of
subscription tiers and counts.
audits.why_it_matters:
SaaS sprawl is a significant cost driver. Studies show 30-40%
of SaaS licenses are unused or underutilized. Without visibility,
organizations pay for shadow IT, duplicate applications, and
abandoned subscriptions. SaaS management recovers significant waste.

audits.name: Software Asset Management Audit
audits.description:
This audit evaluates the organization's software asset management
program including discovery, inventory, compliance, and lifecycle
management capabilities. It assesses maturity against ISO 19770
standards and industry best practices.
audits.why_it_matters:
A mature SAM program reduces software costs by 20-30%, minimizes
compliance risk, and provides accurate data for IT decisions.
Without SAM, organizations cannot effectively manage their software
estate, leading to waste and exposure.

audits.name: Vendor Audit Readiness Audit
audits.description:
This audit assesses the organization's preparedness for software
vendor audits. It evaluates documentation quality, evidence
gathering capabilities, compliance position, and the ability
to respond effectively to audit requests.
audits.why_it_matters:
Vendor audits can result in significant unplanned expenses.
Being unprepared increases costs through penalties, rushed
purchases, and poor negotiating position. Audit readiness
minimizes financial exposure and stress.

audits.name: Container Efficiency Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines container resource efficiency in Kubernetes
and other container orchestration platforms. It evaluates CPU
and memory requests/limits, actual vs allocated resources, pod
density, and cluster-level resource efficiency.
audits.why_it_matters:
Container environments often have significant inefficiency due to
over-provisioned requests, poorly configured limits, and low pod
density. Studies show average container utilization is only 30-40%
of requested resources. Improving container efficiency can reduce
costs by 30-50% while maintaining application performance.

audits.name: Database Efficiency Audit
audits.description:
This audit examines database resource efficiency across managed
database services like RDS, Aurora, DynamoDB, and equivalent
