that business rules correctly handle time zones, daylight saving transitions,
and temporal boundaries.
audits.why_it_matters:
Time-related bugs are notoriously difficult to detect and can cause significant
business impact. Incorrect temporal rules lead to premature or missed
expirations, wrong calculations for billing periods, and compliance violations
for time-sensitive regulations. Temporal correctness is essential for accurate
business operations.

audits.name: Algorithm Correctness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the correctness of business algorithms including scoring, rating,
ranking, optimization, and statistical calculations. This audit examines
algorithm implementations against their specifications, verifies mathematical
correctness, and ensures edge cases are handled properly.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incorrect algorithms produce wrong business outcomes. Credit scoring errors
deny loans to qualified applicants, pricing algorithms can cause losses,
and recommendation algorithms can miss revenue opportunities. Algorithm
correctness directly impacts business results.

audits.name: Currency Handling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates multi-currency handling including currency storage, conversion,
exchange rate application, mixed-currency operations, and presentation.
This audit examines whether currencies are properly tracked with amounts,
conversions are applied correctly, and currency-related edge cases are
handled.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incorrect currency handling leads to significant financial losses,
especially in international operations. Adding amounts in different
currencies, applying wrong exchange rates, or displaying incorrect
currency symbols causes customer confusion and financial errors.

audits.name: Discount Promotion Logic Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates discount and promotion calculation logic including percentage
discounts, fixed discounts, tiered pricing, buy-one-get-one offers, and
promotional campaigns. This audit examines discount stacking rules,
application order, eligibility validation, and abuse prevention.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incorrect discount logic directly impacts revenue and margin. Stacking
discounts incorrectly can lead to excessive discounts or products being
sold at a loss. Conversely, failing to apply valid discounts frustrates
customers. Promotion logic must be both accurate and abuse-resistant.

audits.name: Financial Accuracy Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the accuracy of financial calculations including pricing, billing,
taxes, interest, and monetary computations. This audit examines calculation
algorithms, decimal handling, rounding modes, precision maintenance, and
verification against known-correct results. It ensures financial calculations
produce accurate results that match business specifications.
audits.why_it_matters:
Financial calculation errors directly impact revenue, customer trust, and
regulatory compliance. Even small calculation errors compound over volume
to create significant discrepancies. Accurate financial calculations are
non-negotiable for fintech, e-commerce, and any system handling money.

audits.name: Pro-Rata Calculation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates pro-rata calculation logic for billing, allocations, and apportionments.
This audit examines how amounts are divided proportionally over time periods,
how partial periods are handled, how days are counted, and how remainders are
distributed. It ensures pro-rata calculations are fair, consistent, and match
business expectations.
audits.why_it_matters:
Pro-rata calculations affect customer billing, revenue recognition, and cost
allocation. Incorrect pro-rata logic causes billing disputes, revenue errors,
and fairness issues. Customers are particularly sensitive to proration
accuracy in subscription and billing contexts.

audits.name: Rounding Precision Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates rounding strategies and precision handling in business calculations.
This audit examines rounding modes (half-up, banker's rounding, truncation),
precision levels, when rounding is applied, and consistency of rounding across
the system. It ensures rounding behavior is intentional, consistent, and
compliant with business requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incorrect or inconsistent rounding causes discrepancies that compound over
volume. When line items don't sum to totals, or prices differ between displays,
user trust erodes. Rounding strategies must be explicit and consistent for
financial accuracy and regulatory compliance.

audits.name: Tax Calculation Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates tax calculation logic for compliance with applicable tax regulations.
This audit examines sales tax, VAT, GST, withholding tax, and other tax
calculations for correctness, jurisdiction handling, rate application, and
exemption handling. It ensures tax calculations comply with regulatory
requirements and produce accurate tax amounts.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incorrect tax calculations create legal liability, regulatory penalties, and
audit findings. Both under-collection and over-collection cause problems.
Tax compliance is non-negotiable for businesses operating in jurisdictions
with tax obligations.

audits.name: Aggregate Boundary Analysis Audit
audits.description:
Examines the definition and enforcement of aggregate boundaries in domain-driven
design implementations. This audit verifies that aggregates are properly sized,
maintain transactional consistency, and enforce invariants correctly. It analyzes
whether aggregate roots properly control access to child entities and whether
aggregate boundaries align with business transaction requirements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poorly defined aggregate boundaries lead to data inconsistency, performance
problems, and complex transaction management. Oversized aggregates cause
contention and scalability issues, while undersized aggregates fail to
maintain business invariants. Correct aggregate design is fundamental to
building maintainable and scalable domain models.

audits.name: Bounded Context Clarity Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the clarity and correctness of bounded context definitions within
a domain-driven design implementation. This audit examines whether bounded
contexts are properly identified, their boundaries are well-defined, and
the ubiquitous language is consistent within each context. It also reviews
context mapping relationships and integration patterns between contexts.
audits.why_it_matters:
Unclear bounded context boundaries lead to model contamination, conflicting
definitions, and tight coupling between teams. When contexts bleed into each
other, changes in one area have unexpected impacts elsewhere. Clear bounded
contexts enable team autonomy, independent deployability, and maintainable
systems.

audits.name: Domain Service Responsibility Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the appropriate use of domain services in the domain model. This
audit examines whether domain services encapsulate operations that naturally
do not belong to any entity or value object, are stateless, express domain
concepts in the ubiquitous language, and maintain proper separation from
application and infrastructure services.
audits.why_it_matters:
Misuse of domain services leads to anemic domain models where entities become
mere data containers. Overuse creates procedural code disguised as OOP, while
underuse forces unnatural behavior onto entities. Proper domain service design
keeps the domain model clean and expressive.

audits.name: Entity Relationship Validation Audit
audits.description:
Validates the correctness and completeness of entity relationships within the
domain model. This audit examines cardinality constraints, referential integrity,
bidirectional relationship consistency, and whether relationships accurately
reflect business requirements. It ensures that entity associations support
required business operations without introducing unnecessary coupling.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incorrect entity relationships lead to data integrity issues, broken business
processes, and maintenance nightmares. Missing relationships force workarounds,
while incorrect cardinality causes data loss or orphaned records. Proper
relationship modeling is essential for a functioning domain model.

audits.name: Repository Pattern Adherence Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the implementation and usage of the repository pattern in the domain
model. This audit examines whether repositories properly abstract persistence
concerns, expose collection-like interfaces for aggregates only, and maintain
the illusion of in-memory collections. It verifies that repositories do not
leak persistence implementation details into the domain layer.
audits.why_it_matters:
Properly implemented repositories keep the domain model persistence-agnostic
and testable. When repositories leak implementation details or expose non-
aggregate entities, the domain becomes coupled to infrastructure and harder
to maintain. Clean repository design enables technology migration and
simplifies testing.

audits.name: Ubiquitous Language Consistency Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the consistency of ubiquitous language usage throughout the codebase
and documentation. This audit examines whether domain terminology is consistently
applied across code, tests, documentation, and team communication. It identifies
terminology drift, synonyms that cause confusion, and misalignments between
code and business language.
audits.why_it_matters:
Inconsistent terminology creates communication barriers between developers and
domain experts, leads to misunderstandings, and makes the codebase harder to
navigate. When code uses different terms than the business, knowledge transfer
becomes difficult and bugs from misunderstanding requirements become common.

audits.name: Value Object Design Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the design and implementation of value objects in the domain model.
This audit examines whether value objects are properly immutable, implement
value equality correctly, encapsulate related attributes appropriately, and
contain domain-specific validation and behavior. It identifies primitive
obsession and opportunities to introduce meaningful value objects.
audits.why_it_matters:
Well-designed value objects encapsulate domain concepts, making code more
expressive and self-documenting. They prevent invalid states through
construction validation and reduce bugs through immutability. Missing value
objects lead to primitive obsession, duplicated validation, and scattered
business logic.

audits.name: Business Event Completeness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether all significant business events are captured and published.
This audit compares business processes with emitted events, identifies missing
events, and ensures consumers have the events they need. It ensures the event
stream fully represents business activity.
audits.why_it_matters:
Missing business events prevent downstream systems from reacting to important
changes. This causes integration gaps, stale caches, missing notifications,
and broken analytics. Complete event coverage is essential for event-driven
architectures to work properly.

audits.name: Domain Event Design Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the design of domain events in event-driven systems. This audit
examines event naming, payload design, versioning, immutability, and whether
events properly represent business facts. It ensures domain events are
well-designed for current and future consumption needs.
audits.why_it_matters:
Domain events are the contract between producers and consumers in event-driven
systems. Poorly designed events lead to tight coupling, versioning nightmares,
and integration failures. Good event design enables system evolution while
maintaining backward compatibility.

audits.name: Event Handler Reliability Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the reliability of event handlers including error handling,
retry mechanisms, idempotency, dead letter handling, and handler ordering.
This audit ensures event handlers process events reliably without data
loss or corruption, even in failure scenarios.
audits.why_it_matters:
Event handlers are critical integration points. Unreliable handlers cause
lost events, inconsistent state, and business process failures. In event-
driven systems, handler reliability directly determines system reliability.

audits.name: Event Ordering Consistency Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates event ordering guarantees and consistency in event-driven systems.
This audit examines partition strategies, ordering requirements, timestamp
handling, and causality preservation. It ensures events are processed in
the correct order when business logic depends on sequence.
audits.why_it_matters:
Many business processes depend on event ordering. Processing events out of
order can cause incorrect state, violated invariants, and business logic
failures. Understanding and enforcing ordering requirements is critical for
event-driven system correctness.

audits.name: Event Schema Evolution Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates strategies for evolving event schemas over time. This audit
examines schema versioning, backward/forward compatibility, schema
registry usage, and migration strategies. It ensures event schemas can
evolve without breaking existing producers or consumers.
audits.why_it_matters:
Event schemas must evolve as business needs change. Without proper evolution
strategies, schema changes break integration, cause data loss, and require
coordinated deployments. Good schema evolution enables independent team
velocity while maintaining compatibility.

audits.name: Event Sourcing Implementation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates event sourcing implementations including event store design,
aggregate reconstruction, snapshot strategies, event versioning, and
projection maintenance. This audit ensures event sourcing is implemented
correctly for reliable state reconstruction and temporal queries.
audits.why_it_matters:
Event sourcing provides powerful audit capabilities and temporal flexibility
but is complex to implement correctly. Incorrect implementations lead to
data loss, inconsistent state, performance problems, and inability to
reproduce historical states. Proper implementation is essential.

audits.name: Contract Testing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the implementation of contract testing for API integrations. This
audit examines consumer-driven contracts, provider verification, contract
versioning, and integration with CI/CD. It ensures API contracts are tested
to prevent integration failures.
audits.why_it_matters:
Integration failures are often discovered in production because API contracts
aren't properly tested. Contract testing catches breaking changes before
deployment, preventing outages and enabling independent deployability.
Good contract testing is essential for microservices and B2B integrations.

audits.name: Data Exchange Format Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates data exchange formats used in business integrations. This audit
examines message formats (JSON, XML, CSV), schema definitions, encoding
handling, null/empty value handling, and date/time formats. It ensures
data is exchanged correctly and consistently with partners.
audits.why_it_matters:
Data format mismatches cause integration failures, data corruption, and
processing errors. When partners interpret data differently, it leads to
reconciliation issues and business disputes. Consistent, well-defined
data formats are essential for reliable integrations.

audits.name: Idempotency Handling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates idempotency handling in API integrations. This audit examines
idempotency key usage, duplicate request handling, retry safety, and
exactly-once semantics. It ensures operations can be safely retried without
causing duplicate effects.
audits.why_it_matters:
Network failures and timeouts are inevitable. Without proper idempotency,
retries cause duplicate transactions, double charges, and data corruption.
Idempotent operations are essential for reliable integrations and financial
correctness.

audits.name: Partner API Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance with partner API specifications and contracts. This
audit examines whether integrations correctly implement partner API
requirements, handle responses properly, respect rate limits, and follow
partner guidelines for data handling and usage.
audits.why_it_matters:
Partner API violations can result in service disruption, termination of
partnership, and legal liability. Incorrect implementations cause integration
failures that impact business operations. Compliance with partner contracts
is essential for maintaining B2B relationships.

audits.name: SLA Compliance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates compliance with Service Level Agreements for business integrations.
This audit examines response time requirements, availability targets, throughput
commitments, and error rate thresholds. It ensures the system meets contractual
SLA obligations to partners and customers.
audits.why_it_matters:
SLA violations result in financial penalties, damaged relationships, and
lost business. Understanding SLA requirements and measuring compliance is
essential for maintaining partner trust and avoiding contractual penalties.

audits.name: Webhook Reliability Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates webhook reliability for both sending and receiving. This audit
examines retry mechanisms, signature verification, delivery guarantees,
timeout handling, and failure monitoring. It ensures webhooks are delivered
reliably and processed securely.
audits.why_it_matters:
Webhooks are critical for real-time integrations. Unreliable webhooks cause
missed events, delayed processing, and inconsistent state. Proper webhook
implementation ensures partners receive timely notifications and events
are not lost.

audits.name: Async Validation Handling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates asynchronous validation patterns including server-side uniqueness
checks, external service validations, debouncing strategies, and handling
of validation timing issues. This audit examines how async validations
are triggered, how their results are integrated with synchronous validation,
and how race conditions are prevented.
audits.why_it_matters:
Async validation provides better UX by checking constraints before submission
but introduces complexity. Poor async validation leads to race conditions,
inconsistent state, and confusing user experiences. Proper handling ensures
reliable real-time validation feedback.

audits.name: Business Constraint Enforcement Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the enforcement of business constraints that go beyond basic input
validation. This audit examines business rules like uniqueness constraints,
cross-field validations, entity state constraints, and complex business
invariants. It ensures that domain-specific constraints are properly enforced
at both application and database levels.
audits.why_it_matters:
Business constraints protect data integrity and ensure correct business
operations. Without proper enforcement, the system can enter invalid states
that violate business rules, causing incorrect calculations, compliance
issues, and operational problems.

audits.name: Cross-Field Validation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates validation rules that depend on relationships between multiple
fields. This audit examines date range validations, conditional required
fields, mutually exclusive options, sum validations, and other inter-field
dependencies. It ensures all cross-field business rules are properly
validated.
audits.why_it_matters:
Cross-field validation errors are a common source of data quality issues.
When individual fields validate but their combination is invalid, business
logic fails. These validations are often overlooked because they are more
complex to implement than single-field validation.

audits.name: Data Format Validation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates validation of data formats including email addresses, phone numbers,
postal codes, URLs, IDs, and other formatted fields. This audit examines
whether format validation is appropriate for the business context, consistent
across the application, and handles international formats correctly.
audits.why_it_matters:
Improper format validation leads to poor data quality and user frustration.
Overly strict validation rejects valid inputs, while too lenient validation
accepts garbage data. Format validation must balance strictness with
usability and international compatibility.

audits.name: Input Validation Completeness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the completeness of input validation across all entry points.
This audit examines validation rules for user inputs, API parameters,
file uploads, and external data. It ensures all inputs are validated
for type, format, range, and business constraints before processing.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incomplete input validation leads to data corruption, security vulnerabilities,
and system failures. Invalid data that enters the system causes downstream
errors that are difficult to trace. Comprehensive validation is the first
line of defense for data integrity.

audits.name: Validation Error Handling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how validation errors are collected, formatted, and presented to
users. This audit examines error message quality, field-level error mapping,
error aggregation, internationalization of messages, and accessibility of
error presentation.
audits.why_it_matters:
Good validation error handling is essential for user experience and data
quality. When users cannot understand what is wrong or how to fix it, they
abandon forms or enter incorrect data. Clear, actionable error messages
help users succeed.

audits.name: Approval Workflow Security Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the security of approval workflows including authorization checks,
segregation of duties, approval chains, delegation rules, and audit trails.
This audit ensures that approval processes cannot be bypassed, self-approvals
are prevented where required, and approval authority is properly validated.
audits.why_it_matters:
Approval workflows are critical controls for preventing fraud and ensuring
compliance. Weak approval workflows allow unauthorized transactions, bypass
of financial controls, and compliance violations. Secure approval workflows
are essential for SOX compliance and fraud prevention.

audits.name: Long-Running Process Handling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how the system handles long-running business processes that span
hours, days, or longer. This audit examines process state persistence, resume
capabilities, timeout handling, progress tracking, and user notification
mechanisms. It ensures that long-running processes survive system restarts
and provide appropriate visibility.
audits.why_it_matters:
Many business processes like loan approvals, background checks, or batch
processing can take extended periods. Poor handling of long-running processes
leads to lost work, duplicate processing, timeout failures, and user
frustration. Robust handling ensures business continuity and reliability.

audits.name: Parallel Execution Correctness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the correctness of parallel execution patterns in business workflows.
This audit examines fork/join constructs, parallel branch handling, race
condition prevention, synchronization points, and partial failure handling.
It ensures that parallel workflow execution maintains data consistency and
handles all branch completion scenarios correctly.
audits.why_it_matters:
Parallel execution improves workflow performance but introduces complexity.
Incorrect parallel handling leads to data races, lost updates, incomplete
aggregations, and inconsistent results. Proper parallel execution is critical
for workflows that must be both fast and reliable.

audits.name: Process Boundary Definition Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how business processes are bounded and separated. This audit examines
process start and end triggers, input/output contracts, cross-process
interactions, and process isolation. It ensures that processes have clear
boundaries, well-defined responsibilities, and minimal coupling with other
processes.
audits.why_it_matters:
Unclear process boundaries lead to tangled workflows that are difficult to
understand, modify, and test. When processes overlap or have unclear handoffs,
responsibilities become ambiguous, causing bugs and maintenance issues.
Clear boundaries enable independent process evolution and testing.

audits.name: Process Orchestration Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates business process orchestration including saga patterns, process
managers, and workflow engines. This audit examines how multi-step business
processes coordinate across services, handle failures, manage compensating
transactions, and maintain process state. It ensures orchestration patterns
are correctly implemented for reliability and consistency.
audits.why_it_matters:
Business processes spanning multiple services require careful orchestration
to maintain consistency. Poorly orchestrated processes lead to partial
completions, orphaned data, and failed business transactions. Proper
orchestration ensures business processes complete reliably even when
individual steps fail.

audits.name: State Machine Integrity Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the design and implementation of state machines in business workflows.
This audit examines state definitions, transition rules, guard conditions, and
invariants. It ensures that state machines are complete (all valid transitions
defined), deterministic (no ambiguous transitions), and prevent invalid state
transitions.
audits.why_it_matters:
State machines are critical for managing complex business processes like order
fulfillment, loan processing, and approval workflows. Invalid state transitions
cause business process failures, data corruption, and compliance violations.
Robust state machine design ensures predictable workflow behavior.

audits.name: Workflow Versioning Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how workflow definitions are versioned and how version changes are
handled for in-flight processes. This audit examines version control of
workflow definitions, migration strategies for running processes, backward
compatibility, and version tracking. It ensures workflow changes can be
deployed safely without disrupting ongoing business processes.
audits.why_it_matters:
Business workflows evolve with changing requirements. Without proper versioning,
workflow updates can break in-flight processes, causing business disruption
and data integrity issues. Good versioning enables continuous improvement
while maintaining operational stability.

audits.name: Build Configuration Complexity Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the complexity and maintainability of build configurations
including webpack, TypeScript, Babel, and other build tool configs.
Assesses whether configurations are understandable, documented, and
follow best practices. Identifies unnecessary complexity and
maintenance burden.
audits.why_it_matters:
Complex build configurations become maintenance nightmares that
few developers understand or dare to modify. This creates bottlenecks,
prevents upgrades, and slows feature development. Simpler configurations
are easier to debug, modify, and keep up to date.

audits.name: Build Error Messages Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the quality and actionability of build error messages,
warnings, and diagnostics. Assesses whether error messages clearly
indicate what went wrong, where it occurred, and how to fix it.
Reviews error presentation in terminals, IDEs, and CI logs.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor error messages waste developer time interpreting cryptic output
and searching for solutions. Good error messages accelerate debugging
by pointing directly to the problem and suggesting fixes. Error message
quality significantly impacts developer experience and productivity.

audits.name: Build Time Analysis Audit
audits.description:
Measures and analyzes build times across different build scenarios
including full builds, incremental builds, and CI builds. Identifies
slow build phases, inefficient configurations, and optimization
opportunities to reduce developer wait time.
audits.why_it_matters:
Build time directly impacts developer productivity and iteration speed.
DORA research shows that build time is a key factor in lead time for
changes. Slow builds cause context switching, reduce experimentation,
and can bottleneck CI pipelines. Every minute saved on builds multiplies
across all developers and builds.

audits.name: Cache Effectiveness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the effectiveness of build caching mechanisms including
local caches, remote caches, and CI caches. Measures cache hit rates,
cache invalidation accuracy, and storage utilization. Identifies
opportunities to improve caching for faster builds.
audits.why_it_matters:
Build caching can dramatically reduce build times by reusing previous
work. Effective caching transforms 10-minute builds into 1-minute builds.
However, misconfigured caches can waste storage, serve stale results,
or miss opportunities for reuse.

audits.name: Dependency Management Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the developer experience of managing project dependencies
including installation speed, version resolution, lockfile management,
update workflows, and conflict resolution. Assesses whether dependency
operations are fast, predictable, and well-documented.
audits.why_it_matters:
Poor dependency management creates daily friction for developers.
Slow installs, confusing conflicts, or inconsistent versions waste
time and cause hard-to-debug issues. Good dependency management
enables predictable builds and smooth collaboration.

audits.name: Incremental Build Support Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the build system's ability to perform incremental builds,
recompiling only what changed rather than rebuilding everything.
Assesses dependency tracking accuracy, rebuild triggers, and the
effectiveness of incremental compilation across different file types.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incremental builds are essential for fast iteration. Without them,
developers wait for full rebuilds after every change, even trivial
ones. Effective incremental builds can reduce iteration time from
minutes to seconds, dramatically improving development velocity.

audits.name: Monorepo Tooling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the tooling and workflows for managing monorepo development
including build orchestration, dependency management between packages,
affected change detection, and task running. Assesses whether monorepo
tools enable efficient development across multiple packages.
audits.why_it_matters:
Monorepos offer benefits like atomic changes and code sharing, but
require specialized tooling to remain efficient. Without proper tools,
monorepos become slow, confusing, and frustrating. Good monorepo tooling
enables selective builds, clear dependencies, and efficient CI.

audits.name: Code Documentation Display Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how code documentation (JSDoc, docstrings, comments) is
displayed in the IDE during development. Assesses hover information
quality, parameter hints, quick documentation popups, and integration
between documentation and navigation features.
audits.why_it_matters:
Inline documentation access reduces context switching between code
and external documentation. When developers can see API documentation
on hover, they work faster and make fewer mistakes. Good documentation
display maximizes the value of written documentation.

audits.name: Code Search Quality Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the code search capabilities available to developers including
IDE search, CLI tools (ripgrep, ag), and dedicated code search platforms
(Sourcegraph, GitHub code search). Assesses search speed, result quality,
and feature availability like regex, symbol search, and cross-repository search.
audits.why_it_matters:
Developers spend significant time searching for code - finding usages,
locating implementations, and understanding patterns. Poor search tools
slow down this critical activity. Good code search enables developers
to navigate large codebases efficiently.

audits.name: IDE Integration Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how well the codebase integrates with common IDEs including
VS Code, IntelliJ/WebStorm, and others. Assesses configuration presence,
extension recommendations, workspace settings, and feature availability
like IntelliSense, debugging, and refactoring tools.
audits.why_it_matters:
Good IDE integration dramatically accelerates development through features
like autocomplete, go-to-definition, refactoring, and integrated debugging.
Poor integration forces developers to work without these productivity
multipliers or spend time configuring their environment.

audits.name: Refactoring Support Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the automated refactoring capabilities available through IDEs
and tooling including rename, extract method/variable, move file/symbol,
and other code transformations. Assesses safety, coverage across file
types, and cross-project refactoring support.
audits.why_it_matters:
Safe automated refactoring enables developers to improve code quality
without fear of breaking things. Without it, refactoring becomes manual
and risky, leading to either code rot or unintended breakages. Good
refactoring support encourages continuous improvement.

audits.name: Symbol Navigation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the ability to navigate code using semantic symbols including
go-to-definition, find references, find implementations, and symbol
search. Assesses coverage across different file types, accuracy of
navigation, and cross-project/cross-file navigation capabilities.
audits.why_it_matters:
Symbol navigation is essential for understanding code relationships
and making changes safely. Without it, developers must manually trace
through code, which is slow and error-prone. Good symbol navigation
makes exploring and modifying code dramatically faster.

audits.name: Type Information Quality Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the quality and coverage of type information available in the
codebase including TypeScript types, JSDoc annotations, Python type hints,
and type definition files. Assesses how well types support IDE features
like autocomplete, hover information, and error detection.
audits.why_it_matters:
Type information enables powerful IDE features including accurate
autocomplete, inline documentation, and error detection before runtime.
Poor type coverage reduces developer productivity by forcing guesswork
and increasing runtime errors that could be caught statically.

audits.name: Async Communication Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates tools and practices for asynchronous technical communication
including threaded discussions, RFC processes, technical decision
documentation, and channels for non-urgent collaboration that
accommodate different timezones and work styles.
audits.why_it_matters:
Async communication enables deep work, supports distributed teams,
and creates searchable records. Over-reliance on sync communication
fragments attention and excludes those not in the room. Good async
practices balance responsiveness with focus time.

audits.name: Code Sharing Tools Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates tools and practices for sharing code snippets, examples,
and solutions among team members. Assesses availability of snippet
sharing, internal code examples, knowledge bases, and mechanisms
for capturing and reusing code patterns.
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective code sharing prevents reinvention, spreads best practices,
and accelerates problem solving. Without good sharing tools, solutions
get lost in chat history or recreated repeatedly. Good sharing tools
create a growing knowledge base of reusable solutions.

audits.name: Dev Environment Sharing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates capabilities for sharing development environments including
cloud development environments, preview deployments, and shareable
environment snapshots. Assesses how easily developers can share their
work context for collaboration or debugging.
audits.why_it_matters:
Sharing environment context accelerates collaboration, debugging, and
code review. "It works on my machine" problems disappear when environments
are shareable. Preview deployments enable stakeholder feedback before merge.

audits.name: Issue Tracking Experience Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the developer experience with issue tracking systems including
ticket creation, search, filtering, workflow, and integration with
development tools. Assesses whether issue tracking supports efficient
work planning and execution.
audits.why_it_matters:
Issue tracking is central to development workflow. Poor issue tracking
creates friction in planning, causes lost work, and makes progress
invisible. Good issue tracking enables efficient work management,
clear priorities, and historical context.

audits.name: Pair Programming Support Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the tooling and support for pair programming and mob
programming, including real-time collaboration tools, remote pairing
capabilities, and team practices around collaborative coding.
audits.why_it_matters:
Pair programming improves code quality, spreads knowledge, and
accelerates onboarding. Without proper tooling, remote teams cannot
pair effectively. Good pairing tools enable seamless collaboration
regardless of location.

audits.name: PR Review Experience Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the pull request review experience including tooling,
automation, review workflows, and feedback quality. Assesses how
efficiently and effectively code reviews happen, from PR creation
to merge.
audits.why_it_matters:
Code review is a critical quality gate and knowledge-sharing mechanism.
Poor review experience leads to slow reviews, rubber-stamping, or
reviews that don't catch issues. Good review tooling and processes
enable thorough, efficient reviews that improve code quality.

audits.name: API Documentation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the quality and completeness of API documentation including
REST API docs, library/SDK documentation, and internal module APIs.
Assesses accuracy, completeness, examples, and maintenance status
of API documentation.
audits.why_it_matters:
API documentation is the primary interface between developers and
your code. Poor API docs lead to misuse, support burden, and
developer frustration. Good API documentation enables self-service
integration and reduces time to productive use.

audits.name: Architecture Documentation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the quality and completeness of architecture documentation
including system diagrams, component descriptions, data flow documentation,
and Architecture Decision Records (ADRs). Assesses whether documentation
enables understanding of system structure and design rationale.
audits.why_it_matters:
Architecture documentation is essential for understanding how systems
fit together and why they were designed that way. Without it, developers
make changes without understanding impact, repeat past mistakes, or
create inconsistent designs.

audits.name: Code Comments Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the quality and appropriateness of inline code comments
including JSDoc/docstrings, explanatory comments, and TODO/FIXME
markers. Assesses whether comments aid understanding without being
redundant or outdated.
audits.why_it_matters:
Good comments explain the 'why' behind non-obvious code, making
maintenance easier. Poor comments either state the obvious, lie
about the code, or are missing where needed. The right balance
of comments improves code comprehension significantly.

audits.name: Documentation Freshness Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how up-to-date documentation is relative to the code it
describes. Analyzes documentation modification dates, identifies stale
content, and assesses processes for keeping documentation current.
Compares documentation changes against code changes.
audits.why_it_matters:
Stale documentation is often worse than no documentation, providing
false confidence and incorrect guidance. Keeping documentation fresh
ensures it remains a reliable resource. Measuring freshness helps
prioritize documentation maintenance.

audits.name: README Quality Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the quality and completeness of README files in the project,
including the root README and package-level READMEs. Assesses whether
READMEs provide essential information for understanding, using, and
contributing to the project.
audits.why_it_matters:
The README is often the first documentation a developer encounters.
A good README enables quick understanding and productive use. A poor
README creates friction for new contributors and users, wastes time
with unanswered questions, and can deter adoption.

audits.name: Runbook Quality Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the quality and completeness of operational runbooks including
incident response procedures, deployment guides, troubleshooting guides,
and maintenance procedures. Assesses whether runbooks enable effective
operations under pressure.
audits.why_it_matters:
Runbooks are critical during incidents when stress is high and clear
guidance is essential. Poor runbooks lead to longer incidents, missed
steps, and repeated mistakes. Good runbooks enable consistent,
effective operational response.

audits.name: Debug Experience Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the debugging capabilities available to developers including
IDE debugger integration, source maps quality, logging infrastructure,
error messages clarity, and debugging documentation. Assesses how
effectively developers can diagnose and fix issues.
audits.why_it_matters:
Debugging consumes a significant portion of developer time. Poor
debugging tools or missing source maps force developers to rely on
console.log statements or guesswork, dramatically increasing time
to resolution. Good debugging experience accelerates bug fixes and
reduces developer frustration.

audits.name: Dev Environment Parity Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how closely the local development environment matches
production, including service versions, configurations, infrastructure
components, and behaviors. Identifies gaps that cause "works on my
machine" issues or missed bugs that only appear in production.
audits.why_it_matters:
Environment differences are a leading cause of production incidents.
When local development diverges from production, bugs pass through
testing only to fail after deployment. The Twelve-Factor App methodology
emphasizes dev/prod parity as critical for reliable software delivery.

audits.name: Dev Server Performance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the performance of local development servers including startup
time, memory usage, CPU utilization, and stability. Assesses whether the
development server provides a responsive experience without consuming
excessive system resources.
audits.why_it_matters:
Slow or resource-hungry dev servers degrade productivity and can make
development on standard hardware frustrating. Long startup times add up
over multiple daily restarts. Excessive resource usage can cause system
instability or prevent running multiple services simultaneously.

audits.name: Hot Reload Performance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the performance and reliability of hot reload, hot module
replacement (HMR), and live reload functionality in the development
environment. Measures time from file save to updated application state,
state preservation quality, and failure modes.
audits.why_it_matters:
Fast feedback loops are essential for developer productivity. When hot
reload is slow or unreliable, developers lose context waiting for changes
or resort to full refreshes that lose application state. Studies show
that even 1-second delays significantly impact developer flow state.

audits.name: Local Data Seeding Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the availability and quality of local data seeding mechanisms
for development environments. Assesses how developers populate their
local databases with realistic test data, reset data state, and create
specific scenarios for testing features.
audits.why_it_matters:
Developers need realistic data to test features effectively. Without
good seeding, developers either work with empty databases, manually
create data repeatedly, or use stale production snapshots that may
contain sensitive information. Quality seeding accelerates development
and improves feature quality.

audits.name: Local SSL Setup Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the local HTTPS/SSL certificate setup for development,
including certificate generation, trust configuration, and tooling
support. Assesses whether developers can easily run local services
over HTTPS without browser warnings or manual intervention.
audits.why_it_matters:
Many web features require secure contexts (HTTPS), including service
workers, geolocation, and modern authentication flows. Without proper
local SSL, developers cannot test these features or must deal with
constant browser warnings. Production parity also requires HTTPS locally.

audits.name: Service Orchestration Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how multiple services are started, managed, and coordinated
in the local development environment. Assesses whether developers can
easily start the required services, manage their lifecycle, and view
logs across services.
audits.why_it_matters:
Modern applications often consist of multiple services that must run
together. Without good orchestration, developers spend significant
time starting services manually, debugging startup order issues, or
hunting through multiple terminal windows for logs.

audits.name: Access Provisioning Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the process for provisioning new developers with necessary
access to repositories, cloud environments, internal tools, documentation
systems, and communication platforms. Assesses automation level, time to
complete provisioning, and clarity of the access request process.
audits.why_it_matters:
Delayed or incomplete access provisioning blocks developer productivity
from day one. When developers cannot access systems they need, they
cannot contribute effectively. Manual, ad-hoc provisioning also creates
security risks through inconsistent access controls and orphaned accounts.

audits.name: Codebase Orientation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how new developers are introduced to the codebase structure,
key components, design patterns, and conventions. Assesses availability
of codebase tours, architecture documentation, code walkthroughs, and
resources that help developers understand where to find things.
audits.why_it_matters:
Large codebases are overwhelming for new developers. Without proper
orientation, developers waste significant time searching for code,
understanding patterns, or making changes inconsistent with existing
conventions. Good orientation transforms a codebase from a maze into
a navigable system.

audits.name: First PR Time Audit
audits.description:
Measures and analyzes the time it takes for new developers to submit and
merge their first pull request after joining the team. This metric serves
as a key indicator of onboarding effectiveness and development environment
maturity, encompassing environment setup, codebase understanding, and
workflow familiarity.
audits.why_it_matters:
First PR time directly correlates with developer productivity ramp-up and
satisfaction. Extended onboarding periods waste engineering capacity,
frustrate new hires, and can indicate systemic issues with documentation,
tooling, or knowledge transfer. DORA research shows that elite teams have
significantly faster onboarding cycles.

audits.name: Mentorship Program Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the structure and effectiveness of developer mentorship and
buddy programs. Assesses how new developers are paired with experienced
team members, the clarity of mentor responsibilities, support provided
to mentors, and outcomes of mentorship relationships.
audits.why_it_matters:
Effective mentorship accelerates onboarding, transfers tacit knowledge
that documentation cannot capture, and builds team relationships.
Without structured mentorship, new developers may struggle silently
or repeatedly interrupt senior developers with ad-hoc questions.

audits.name: Onboarding Checklist Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the existence, completeness, and effectiveness of structured
onboarding checklists for new developers. Assesses whether checklists
cover all necessary areas, are tracked consistently, have clear owners,
and are maintained as processes change.
audits.why_it_matters:
A comprehensive onboarding checklist ensures no critical steps are
missed, provides visibility into onboarding progress, and creates
consistency across new hires. Without checklists, onboarding quality
depends entirely on the memory and availability of the onboarding
coordinator.

audits.name: Onboarding Documentation Quality Audit
audits.description:
Assesses the quality, completeness, and accuracy of documentation
specifically designed for onboarding new developers. This includes
getting started guides, architecture overviews, codebase tours,
workflow documentation, and team-specific processes.
audits.why_it_matters:
Quality onboarding documentation reduces dependency on senior developers
for knowledge transfer, enables self-service learning, and scales
onboarding capacity. Poor documentation forces repeated explanations,
creates knowledge silos, and extends ramp-up time significantly.

audits.name: Setup Automation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the automation level of development environment setup processes,
including scripts, devcontainers, infrastructure-as-code, and dependency
management. Assesses whether a new developer can go from zero to a working
environment with minimal manual intervention.
audits.why_it_matters:
Manual environment setup is error-prone, time-consuming, and creates
knowledge silos. Automated setup ensures consistency across developer
machines, reduces onboarding time from days to hours, and eliminates
"works on my machine" issues. It also enables rapid recovery from
environment corruption.

audits.name: Developer Velocity Audit
audits.description:
Measures and analyzes developer velocity metrics including deployment
frequency, lead time for changes, cycle time, and throughput. Uses
DORA metrics as a framework for understanding engineering effectiveness
and identifying improvement opportunities.
audits.why_it_matters:
Developer velocity directly impacts business outcomes. DORA research
shows that elite performers deploy 208x more frequently than low
performers. Understanding velocity metrics helps identify bottlenecks
and measure improvement initiatives.

audits.name: DX Improvement Tracking Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how DX improvements are tracked, prioritized, and measured
over time. Assesses whether there is a systematic approach to improving
developer experience with visible progress and accountability.
audits.why_it_matters:
Without tracking, DX improvements happen randomly or not at all.
Systematic tracking ensures consistent investment in developer
experience, measures impact of changes, and maintains momentum
on improvements.

audits.name: DX Survey Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the implementation and effectiveness of developer experience
surveys, including survey design, frequency, response rates, analysis
methods, and how results drive improvements. Assesses whether surveys
effectively capture developer sentiment and needs.
audits.why_it_matters:
Surveys are primary input for understanding developer experience at
scale. Poor surveys waste developer time and miss issues. Well-designed
surveys with high response rates provide actionable insights for
improving DX systematically.

audits.name: Flow State Enablement Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how well the development environment and culture support
deep work and flow state, including interruption patterns, meeting
load, notification policies, and focus time availability. Assesses
whether developers can achieve sustained concentration.
audits.why_it_matters:
Flow state is when developers do their best work. Research shows it
takes 15-23 minutes to reach flow state and any interruption resets
the clock. Environments that protect focus time dramatically
outperform those with constant interruptions.

audits.name: Friction Measurement Audit
audits.description:
Identifies and quantifies sources of developer friction including
wait times, context switches, tooling issues, and process overhead.
Maps the developer journey to find pain points that reduce productivity
and satisfaction.
audits.why_it_matters:
Developer friction compounds throughout the day, significantly
impacting productivity and morale. Small frictions add up to hours
of lost productivity weekly. Identifying friction enables targeted
improvements with measurable impact.

audits.name: Toil Measurement Audit
audits.description:
Identifies and quantifies toil - manual, repetitive, automatable work
that scales with system size. Measures time spent on operational tasks
that could be eliminated through automation or process improvement,
following SRE principles.
audits.why_it_matters:
Toil consumes engineering capacity without providing lasting value.
Google SRE targets keeping toil below 50% of time. High toil leads
to burnout, technical debt accumulation, and reduced capacity for
improvement work.

audits.name: Test Data Management Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how test data is created, managed, and isolated in the test
suite. Assesses factories, fixtures, mocking strategies, and database
state management. Reviews how developers create test scenarios and
ensure test isolation.
audits.why_it_matters:
Good test data management enables reliable, maintainable tests. Poor
management leads to flaky tests, test pollution, and difficulty creating
specific scenarios. Easy test data creation encourages comprehensive
testing of edge cases.

audits.name: Test Debugging Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the ability to debug failing tests including debugger
integration, error message quality, stack trace clarity, and tools
for investigating test failures. Assesses how quickly developers
can diagnose why a test is failing.
audits.why_it_matters:
When tests fail, developers need to quickly understand why. Poor
debugging support turns test failures into time sinks. Good test
debugging tools reduce the time from failure to fix, encouraging
developers to maintain comprehensive test suites.

audits.name: Test Execution Speed Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the speed of running tests locally and in CI, measuring
full suite runtime, individual test speed, and time to feedback.
Identifies slow tests, parallelization opportunities, and
configuration issues that impact test execution time.
audits.why_it_matters:
Fast tests encourage developers to run them frequently, catching
issues early. Slow tests get skipped or batched, leading to delayed
feedback and larger debugging sessions. DORA research shows that
test speed directly impacts deployment frequency.

audits.name: Test Feedback Quality Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the quality and usefulness of feedback from test execution
including assertion messages, failure diffs, coverage reports, and
test result presentation. Assesses whether test output helps developers
understand what failed and why.
audits.why_it_matters:
Test feedback is how developers learn about problems. Poor feedback
requires additional investigation to understand failures. Good feedback
immediately points to the issue, reducing mean time to resolution and
making test-driven development more effective.

audits.name: Test Writing Ergonomics Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how easy it is to write new tests including assertion APIs,
test utility availability, boilerplate requirements, and patterns for
common test scenarios. Assesses whether the test authoring experience
encourages or discourages comprehensive testing.
audits.why_it_matters:
If writing tests is difficult, developers write fewer of them. Good
ergonomics lower the barrier to testing, leading to better coverage
and more maintainable tests. Poor ergonomics create friction that
compounds with every test written.

audits.name: Watch Mode Experience Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the test watch mode experience including file change detection,
related test detection, filtering capabilities, and performance. Assesses
whether watch mode enables rapid test-driven development cycles.
audits.why_it_matters:
Watch mode is essential for test-driven development, providing instant
feedback on code changes. Poor watch mode disrupts the development flow
with delayed or incorrect re-runs. Good watch mode enables tight
edit-test-fix cycles.

audits.name: Address Format Localization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates handling of international address formats including field labels,
field order, required fields, postal code formats, and display formatting.
Examines whether address forms and displays adapt to country-specific
conventions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Address formats vary dramatically by country. Japan puts postal code first,
UK has no state field, Germany uses 5-digit postal codes. Forcing US-style
address forms causes user frustration, data quality issues, and shipping
problems.

audits.name: Cultural Adaptation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates cultural appropriateness of content beyond translation,
including imagery, colors, symbols, examples, metaphors, and references.
Examines whether content resonates with target cultures and avoids
culturally insensitive or confusing elements.
audits.why_it_matters:
Cultural missteps can offend users, damage brand reputation, and reduce
engagement. A thumbs-up emoji is offensive in some cultures, white
symbolizes death in others. Truly localized content connects with
users culturally, not just linguistically.

audits.name: Image Localization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates localization of images including text in images, screenshots,
culturally appropriate imagery, image alt text, and locale-specific
visual content. Examines whether images are served based on locale
and contain localized text where needed.
audits.why_it_matters:
Images with embedded text cannot be translated without new images.
Screenshots showing English UI to German users create disconnection.
Proper image localization ensures visual content supports the localized
experience.

audits.name: Legal Content Localization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates localization and adaptation of legal content including Terms
of Service, Privacy Policies, Cookie notices, compliance disclosures,
and regulatory content. Examines whether legal content is properly
translated and adapted for each jurisdiction.
audits.why_it_matters:
Legal content must be accurate and jurisdiction-appropriate. Many regions
require legal documents in local language. Incorrect translations of
legal terms can create liability, compliance violations, and render
agreements unenforceable.

audits.name: Media Localization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates localization of media content including videos, audio files,
animations, and interactive content. Examines subtitles, captions,
dubbing, voiceovers, audio descriptions, and transcript availability
across supported locales.
audits.why_it_matters:
Video and audio content often contains significant information that
users in other languages cannot access without localization. Subtitles,
dubbing, and localized voiceovers make multimedia accessible and
engaging for international audiences.

audits.name: Phone Number Format Localization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates handling of international phone numbers including input formats,
validation, storage, and display formatting. Examines country code handling,
national vs international format, input masking, and phone type detection
(mobile, landline).
audits.why_it_matters:
Phone number formats vary significantly by country. US numbers are 10 digits,
UK numbers are 10-11 digits with different patterns, and Indian numbers are
10 digits. Rigid validation rejects valid numbers, and poor formatting
makes numbers hard to read.

audits.name: Calendar System Support Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates support for non-Gregorian calendar systems used in various
regions including Islamic (Hijri), Hebrew, Buddhist, Japanese Imperial,
Persian, and others. Examines calendar conversion, display, date input,
and holiday handling for these systems.
audits.why_it_matters:
Many regions use non-Gregorian calendars for official or cultural
purposes. Saudi Arabia uses Hijri calendar officially, Thailand uses
Buddhist calendar, Japan uses Imperial year. Supporting these calendars
is essential for user trust and market fit.

audits.name: Date Format Consistency Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates consistency and correctness of date and time formatting
across the application. Examines whether locale-appropriate formats
are used (MM/DD/YYYY vs DD/MM/YYYY), whether formatting is consistent
across screens, and whether the Intl API or proper libraries are used.
audits.why_it_matters:
Date format confusion causes real problems: 01/02/2024 means January 2
in the US but February 1 in Europe. Inconsistent formats reduce trust
and can cause data entry errors, missed deadlines, and scheduling issues.

audits.name: Date Input and Parsing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how the application handles date input from users including
date pickers, manual text entry, and date parsing. Examines locale-aware
input formats, validation, error handling, and the parsing of ambiguous
dates.
audits.why_it_matters:
Date input is a major source of i18n bugs. Users expect to enter dates
in their locale's format (DD/MM/YYYY vs MM/DD/YYYY). Parsing 01/02/2024
incorrectly swaps the month and day, causing significant data errors.

audits.name: Duration Formatting Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates localization of duration displays such as "3 hours 45 minutes",
"2h 30m", video lengths, time remaining, and elapsed time. Examines
format consistency, unit abbreviations, plural rules, and locale-specific
duration conventions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Duration formats vary by locale and context. Some locales use "h" for
hours, others spell out "hours", and plural rules differ. Video "1:30:45"
may need different separators or formats in different regions.

audits.name: First Day of Week Configuration Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether the application correctly handles first day of week
conventions which vary by locale. Most of the world uses Monday as the
first day of the week, while the US, Canada, and Japan use Sunday.
Some Middle Eastern countries use Saturday.
audits.why_it_matters:
Using the wrong first day of week in calendars, date pickers, and
weekly views confuses users and appears unprofessional. It affects
week number calculations and can cause scheduling issues.

audits.name: Relative Time Formatting Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates localization of relative time expressions such as "2 hours ago",
"in 3 days", "yesterday", and "last week". Examines whether these
expressions use proper locale formatting, handle plural rules correctly,
and update appropriately over time.
audits.why_it_matters:
Relative time is heavily used in modern UIs (social feeds, notifications,
file timestamps). Hardcoded English phrases cannot be translated, and
different languages have complex rules for expressing relative time
including different plural forms.

audits.name: Timezone Handling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how the application handles timezones across storage,
processing, display, and user preferences. Examines UTC storage
practices, timezone conversion accuracy, daylight saving transitions,
and user timezone detection and configuration.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incorrect timezone handling causes missed appointments, incorrect
deadlines, data inconsistencies, and user confusion. With users across
time zones, proper handling is essential for scheduling, auditing,
and communication features.

audits.name: Geo-IP Locale Detection Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the use of IP-based geolocation for locale detection and
content personalization. Examines accuracy, fallback handling, privacy
implications, VPN/proxy handling, and user override capabilities when
geo-IP is used for locale inference.
audits.why_it_matters:
Geo-IP can provide locale hints but is imprecise and can be wrong for
travelers, VPN users, and expats. Over-reliance on geo-IP without
override options frustrates users who see wrong language/currency
based on their physical location rather than preferences.

audits.name: Locale Fallback Strategy Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the locale fallback strategy when requested locales are not
fully supported. Examines regional to language fallbacks (en-AU to en),
language family fallbacks, and ultimate default locale handling to
ensure users always receive appropriate content.
audits.why_it_matters:
Not all locale variants have complete translations. A user requesting
en-AU should fall back to en if en-AU isn't available, rather than
showing blank content or errors. Good fallback strategy ensures graceful
degradation.

audits.name: Locale Negotiation Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the locale negotiation process that matches user preferences
against available locales. Examines algorithm for finding best match
between Accept-Language header priorities and supported locale list,
handling of partial matches and quality values.
audits.why_it_matters:
Proper locale negotiation finds the best available match for user
preferences. A user preferring de-AT, de, en should receive de-AT
if available, de if not, and en as last resort. Poor negotiation
might give en to a user who would prefer de.

audits.name: URL-Based Locale Handling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates URL-based locale handling strategies including subdomains
(de.example.com), path prefixes (/de/page), query parameters (?lang=de),
and content negotiation. Examines SEO implications, canonical URLs,
hreflang implementation, and locale switching behavior.
audits.why_it_matters:
URL structure affects SEO, shareability, and user expectations. Localized
URLs help search engines index content correctly, allow users to share
locale-specific links, and make locale selection explicit and bookmarkable.

audits.name: User Locale Detection Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how the application detects user locale preferences including
browser language settings, Accept-Language headers, IP geolocation, user
profile preferences, and URL-based locale. Examines detection accuracy,
fallback strategies, and user override capabilities.
audits.why_it_matters:
Proper locale detection is the foundation of localization. Detecting the
wrong locale forces users to see content in an unfamiliar language or
format, creating poor first impressions and increasing bounce rates.

audits.name: User Locale Preferences Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates how users can set and manage their locale preferences including
language selection, region settings, timezone, date format preferences,
and unit system choices. Examines UI for changing settings, persistence,
and sync across devices.
audits.why_it_matters:
Users should be able to override auto-detected locale settings. A Spanish
user living in Germany may want Spanish UI but German date formats.
Flexible preferences respect user diversity and improve satisfaction.

audits.name: Currency Display Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates currency formatting including symbol placement, number formatting
with currency, multi-currency support, and locale-appropriate display.
Examines whether $100, 100$, USD 100, or 100 USD is shown appropriately
per locale conventions.
audits.why_it_matters:
Currency formatting errors cause confusion and can impact purchasing
decisions. Different locales expect different formats: $1,234.56 (US),
1.234,56 EUR (Germany), or 1 234,56 EUR (France). Wrong formatting
appears unprofessional and damages trust.

audits.name: Decimal Precision Handling Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates handling of decimal precision for financial calculations,
scientific displays, and general numeric handling. Examines rounding
strategies, precision preservation, floating-point handling, and
context-appropriate precision levels.
audits.why_it_matters:
Precision errors compound in financial calculations, leading to
discrepancies. Different contexts require different precision levels:
currency needs exact cents, scientific data needs consistent significant
figures, and percentages need appropriate rounding.

audits.name: Number Formatting Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates localization of number formatting including decimal separators,
grouping separators, grouping sizes, and digit systems. Examines whether
the application uses locale-appropriate formats (1,234.56 vs 1.234,56)
and handles different numeral systems (Arabic-Indic, Devanagari, etc.).
audits.why_it_matters:
Number format conventions vary significantly by locale. In Germany,
1.234,56 means one thousand two hundred thirty-four point fifty-six.
Using wrong separators causes confusion, data entry errors, and can
affect financial calculations.

audits.name: Numeral Systems Support Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates support for non-Western numeral systems including Arabic-Indic
numerals, Devanagari numerals, Bengali numerals, Thai numerals, and others.
Examines display, input handling, and digit conversion for locales that
use different numeral systems.
audits.why_it_matters:
Some locales use different digit characters. Arabic-Indic numerals
(used in some Arabic-speaking countries) represent 1234 as .
Users in these regions expect to see and input numbers in their
native numeral system.

audits.name: Percentage Formatting Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates localization of percentage formatting including percent sign
placement, spacing, decimal handling, and locale-specific conventions.
Examines whether percentages like "25%" are displayed appropriately
per locale (25%, 25 %, %25, etc.).
audits.why_it_matters:
Percentage formats vary by locale. French uses "25 %" (with space),
Turkish puts percent sign before number "%25". Inconsistent or incorrect
formatting appears unprofessional and can confuse users.

audits.name: Unit Formatting Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates formatting of measurement units including length, weight,
volume, area, speed, and temperature. Examines metric vs imperial
preferences, unit abbreviations, localized unit names, and compound
units (km/h, ft/s, etc.).
audits.why_it_matters:
Unit formatting preferences vary by region. Most of the world uses metric
while the US uses imperial. Displaying kilometers to US users or miles to
European users creates confusion and can cause errors in shipping,
measurements, and data entry.

audits.name: i18n Bundle Size Optimization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the impact of internationalization on application bundle size
including translation files, i18n libraries, date/time libraries, and
locale data. Examines strategies for keeping bundles lean while
supporting multiple locales.
audits.why_it_matters:
Translation files and locale data can significantly bloat bundle size.
Loading all locales when only one is needed wastes bandwidth and slows
initial load time. Users in slower network regions are disproportionately
affected.

audits.name: Translation Caching Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates caching strategies for translation files and locale data
including browser caching, service worker caching, CDN caching, and
cache invalidation strategies. Examines how effectively translations
are cached to reduce repeat loading.
audits.why_it_matters:
Translations rarely change but may be requested frequently. Effective
caching reduces server load, decreases load times for repeat visits,
and enables offline functionality. Poor caching wastes bandwidth on
unchanged content.

audits.name: CDN Localization Optimization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates CDN configuration for serving localized content including
edge caching by locale, cache key strategies, geo-routing for locale
assets, and purging strategies for translation updates. Ensures CDN
optimally delivers localized content globally.
audits.why_it_matters:
CDN configuration significantly impacts performance for global users.
Incorrect cache keys can serve wrong locale, poor geo-routing increases
latency, and slow purging delays translation updates. Proper CDN setup
is essential for global performance.

audits.name: i18n Lazy Loading Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates lazy loading strategies for translation files and locale data.
Examines whether translations are loaded on-demand, how namespace
splitting is used, and whether locale changes trigger efficient
incremental loads.
audits.why_it_matters:
Loading all translations upfront delays initial render and wastes
bandwidth. Lazy loading ensures users only download translations for
screens they visit, improving performance especially for large
applications with many translations.

audits.name: i18n Runtime Performance Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates runtime performance of internationalization including translation
lookup speed, date/number formatting overhead, string interpolation
efficiency, and re-rendering behavior. Examines whether i18n operations
cause performance bottlenecks.
audits.why_it_matters:
i18n operations happen frequently during rendering. Slow translation
lookups, expensive formatting functions, or unnecessary re-renders
can impact application responsiveness, especially on lower-end devices
or with large translation sets.

audits.name: i18n SSR Optimization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates server-side rendering optimization for internationalization
including locale detection during SSR, translation hydration, locale
caching on server, and avoiding hydration mismatches. Ensures SSR
delivers properly localized content efficiently.
audits.why_it_matters:
SSR is crucial for SEO and initial load performance. Improper i18n
handling in SSR can cause hydration mismatches, slow server response,
or serve wrong locale content. Optimized SSR serves correctly localized
content quickly.

audits.name: i18n Functional Testing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates functional testing of internationalized features including
locale switching, date/time handling, number/currency formatting, input
validation, and locale-dependent functionality. Ensures features work
correctly across all supported locales.
audits.why_it_matters:
Functional bugs in i18n features can cause data corruption, broken
workflows, and poor user experience. Testing ensures date parsing works
in all locales, forms accept international input, and features function
regardless of locale.

audits.name: Linguistic Testing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates linguistic quality testing of translations in context including
contextual accuracy, consistency, terminology adherence, style compliance,
and cultural appropriateness. Examines in-context review processes and
linguistic quality assurance procedures.
audits.why_it_matters:
Translations that look correct in isolation may be wrong in context.
A button labeled "Run" could mean "execute" or "physical running" -
context determines correct translation. Linguistic testing catches
these contextual errors.

audits.name: Locale Coverage Testing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates test coverage across all supported locales including functional
testing, visual testing, and regression testing. Examines whether tests
run for each locale, what percentage of functionality is tested per
locale, and how locale-specific issues are detected.
audits.why_it_matters:
Testing only in the default locale misses locale-specific bugs like
truncation in German, RTL issues in Arabic, or date parsing problems
in European locales. Comprehensive locale testing ensures quality
across all markets.

audits.name: Pseudo-localization Testing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates implementation and usage of pseudo-localization testing to
identify i18n issues early. Pseudo-localization transforms strings to
simulate translation effects like text expansion, special characters,
and bidirectional text without actual translations.
audits.why_it_matters:
Pseudo-localization catches i18n bugs before translations are available,
including hardcoded strings, truncation issues, and concatenation problems.
It's faster and cheaper than finding issues after full localization.

audits.name: Right-to-Left Testing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates testing specifically for right-to-left (RTL) languages including
Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, and Urdu. Examines layout mirroring verification,
bidirectional text handling, icon mirroring, and RTL-specific functional
testing.
audits.why_it_matters:
RTL languages require special handling that general i18n testing may miss.
Layout mirroring, bidirectional text, and icon direction need specific
attention. RTL markets like Middle East represent significant revenue
opportunity.

audits.name: Localization Visual Testing Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates visual regression testing for localized interfaces including
screenshot comparisons across locales, layout verification, text
truncation detection, and RTL mirroring validation. Examines automated
visual testing coverage and baseline management.
audits.why_it_matters:
Localization often causes visual issues: German text overflows buttons,
Arabic layouts need mirroring, Chinese characters need different fonts.
Visual testing catches these issues before users see broken interfaces.

audits.name: Pluralization and Grammatical Gender Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the handling of pluralization rules and grammatical gender
across languages. Different languages have complex plural rules (Arabic
has 6 plural forms) and gender agreement requirements that affect
adjectives, verbs, and pronouns.
audits.why_it_matters:
Incorrect pluralization or gender creates grammatically incorrect,
unprofessional text. "1 items" in English or wrong gender in French
damages credibility and user experience in international markets.

audits.name: Right-to-Left Language Support Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates the application's support for right-to-left (RTL) languages
including Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, and Urdu. Examines layout mirroring,
bidirectional text handling, CSS/styling approach, and mixed-direction
content scenarios.
audits.why_it_matters:
RTL languages represent over 400 million native speakers. Poor RTL
support creates unusable interfaces, damages brand perception, and
excludes significant markets including the Middle East and North Africa.

audits.name: String Concatenation Issues Audit
audits.description:
Identifies problematic string concatenation patterns that break
localization. Examines sentence fragments, partial translations,
word order assumptions, and messages assembled from pieces that
cannot be properly translated due to grammar differences.
audits.why_it_matters:
String concatenation assumes English word order and grammar structure.
"Hello " + name + ", welcome!" cannot be translated properly because
languages have different word orders, and this pattern produces
grammatically incorrect translations.

audits.name: String Externalization Audit
audits.description:
Evaluates whether all user-facing text strings are properly externalized
